mnemonics.meaning: There is a cage with an axe in it above your house to show that you are an artisan. All of the artisans have to have this special sign somewhere near where they live to show they make things. Imagine looking down your street and seeing caged axes above all of the artisans homes and shops. You want a new chair? You want some pants mended? Go to one of those signs and you'll find the right artisan.
mnemonics.reading: Artisans have to be marked this way because the Shougun (しょう) says so. The Shougun doesn't want to have to put any effort into finding people to make things for him, so he created this new system. Picture the Shougun marching angrily down the street. His shoe suddenly snaps in half. With just one glance he'll be able to find the shoe artisan and make them fix his shoe for free.

mnemonics.meaning: You're tapping your fingers against a white wall when you realize the sound you're making is actually a sick beat. You keep going and start singing along. Boo boo boop. Boo do do do doop! Finger beats! Imagine yourself in a completely white room. All you have is the white walls, your fingers, and your beats. When you stop all you're left with is white noise. Yuck! Keep those beats coming!
mnemonics.reading: This beat is sick, but as you tap you realize you're hacking (はく) up the wall! Slowly but surely, your fingers are hacking out little bits of the wall. And the beats don't sound as good until you move to a new, clean white area. Imagine hacking the wall apart as you try to keep this beat going. The music is all you have, man! You can't lose the beat now!

mnemonics.meaning: Your specialty is dropping people with thread by binding them! You can drop anyone as long as you have enough thread to restrain them. It doesn't matter how much they fight, you'll get them to drop! Imagine if your specialty was dropping people by binding them with thread. You'd be such a weird person.
mnemonics.reading: If you're going to be a weirdo who likes to bind people, at least make sure that they land on their backs (ばく) when they DO drop. Landing on your head or your boobs really hurts. So please at least try to make them land on their backs! Imagine how you would bind someone so that when they drop they land on their back instead of somewhere more painful. How would you do that?

mnemonics.meaning: You eat and then wrap yourself into a ball because you're bored. You're also sated, because you ate just the right amount, but now you have nothing to do and it's soooo booooring. Haven't you ever been so bored that you just wrapped yourself up into a boredom ball?
mnemonics.reading: So now you're bored and stuck at home (ほう). You aren't hungry. There's nothing on TV. And you don't want to have to leave your home to do something, even though that would probably solve your boredom problem. Ehhhhhhgggg guys I'm stuck at home and I'm soooo bored. Heeelpp!

mnemonics.meaning: If you could stop spooning water onto that tree we could use it for brushwood. But if you don't stop, then it will be too wet to burn at all! Stop already! We need to use that brushwood to make a fire! So stop spooning water on it!
mnemonics.reading: You finally set the brushwood on fire and suddenly a Shiba (しば) Inu jumps out of the flames. So that's why they named this wood after them or... or vice versa? Shiba inu's come from setting brushwood on fire! That must have been how they got their name!

mnemonics.meaning: The insect that is amongst all the world's trees is the butterfly. They are always hanging around trees, those butterflies. Imagine any tree in the world with different kinds of butterflies fluttering around. Then go to another tree in the world that looks completely different. Once again, butterflies! They really are fluttering around every tree in the world.
mnemonics.reading: As you look at a butterfly, fluttering around a tree, a hand reaches out from the tree and grabs it, then starts plucking the wings off. An evil laugh comes from inside the tree, and you know it's Mrs. Chou (ちょう).  She grabs another butterfly and starts pulling off wings again, though this time you can see her evil face looking at you while she does it. "I hate butterflies," she says. "They are always dying in my tea."

mnemonics.meaning: The mysterious sound that comes from a bowstring when you pluck it is called a chord. It's still a bowstring though. You need strings to make chords, after all. Every time you touch a bowstring, listen to the chords it plays.
mnemonics.reading: The chord you're hearing right now is being played by Genji (げん). He's sitting under your window plucking bowstrings and singing. GASP! Genji is finally singing chords of love to you! Your dreams have come true and the most handsome, romantic man ever is finally yours!

mnemonics.meaning: You're trying to open the lid of a manhole that's covered in ice by jackhammering it a bunch of times but it's not working because it's just too cold. It's so cold that your jackhammer is starting to ice up too. But you need to get this lid open so you try time after time after time! Imagine if it was sooo cold that no matter how many times you tried to jackhammer the ice of the lid for this manhole, it wouldn't crack open.
mnemonics.reading: Each time the jackhammer hits the freezing cold ice it makes a high pitched ringing (りん) sound. It's actually really annoying to listen to but you really need to crack this ice open so you have to keep listening to it. If it wasn't so darn cold you wouldn't have to hear this horrible high pitched ringing sound because there wouldn't even be any ice to jackhammer through!

mnemonics.meaning: Under this canopy you have a brush and a task to complete with it. This is totally common.  This type of thing is common for almost every class or job you'll ever have. They sit you down under the canopy, put a brush in your hand, and say, "Here complete this task. I'll be over there."
mnemonics.reading: This is so common and familiar to you that you finish your task early and eat some yogurt (よう) while you wait for the guy to come back. As you eat the yogurt you think about how common yogurt is too. It's just a normal food, common in everyone's fridge.

mnemonics.meaning: This was pure gold long ago, but now it's not. Someone got confused and mixed it with something else. You could swear this thing was gold a long time ago. Now it's a mix of different things.
mnemonics.reading: It's mixed (and not pure anymore) because the confused person put it in that sack (さく) filled with various other things. Since it was in that sack for so long, it just ended up getting mixed with the other stuff in that sack. It was gold a long time ago, but now it's mixed with everything else.

mnemonics.meaning: When you drive a car, everyone under your roof is putting their life in your hands, even if they don't say it with their mouth—it's still under your control. It's really important to remember how many things are under your control when you operate a vehicle. It isn't just the people in your car either, it's everyone and everything in your way too.
mnemonics.reading: You have to maintain control of your car or you'll hit a bunch of cats (かつ). The roads are full of cats at all times. And if you lose control of your car for just a second, you'll hit at least two or three cats. If you don't want to think about hitting adorable cats with your car, you better maintain control. You're responsible!

mnemonics.meaning: If you can guard your soul from bad things you'll always feel delight and joy. It's hard to guard your soul from everything though, so take all the joy you can, while you can. Imagine guarding yourself from all the bad things in the world. No more politics, religion, internet trolls debating the two, it's all guarded from your precious soul. Ahhh, it's so joyous to be unburdened.
mnemonics.reading: The delight you feel is so great that it becomes permanently etched (えつ) in your soul and even your face. Picture joy etched on your own face. No one can get you down.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a hole in someone's body with a bow and they'll become destitute. You put a hole in them. They can't work. They can't take care of their house or their kids. They've lost it all. Picture a destitute person wandering in the streets with a hole in their body.
mnemonics.reading: You see this destitute person and decide to give them a cucumber (きゅう). They don't even remember that they're supposed to eat those, so they shove it in the hole you made with your bow. Picture a destitute person, sitting on the street, holding a cucumber. Putting the cucumber in their hole. Crying.

mnemonics.meaning: If when you speak it sounds like the power of a drum is coming out of your mouth, then people will hold you in high esteem. Anyone who has a loud, booming, powerful voice will be held in high esteem in this day and age. Look at all those awesome musicians who have booming voices! Imagine hearing someone speak and it's so powerful and loud that it sounds like they have a drum booming out of their mouth. You'll love them! You'll hold them in the highest esteem!
mnemonics.reading: You hold them in such high esteem that you give them your car (か). I ... I said you give them your car! Give them your car. Hey, hey! If you hold someone in high esteem you give me your- give them your car. Gimme!

mnemonics.meaning: Twenty penguins together are always evil. Penguins are seen in groups a lot, sure, but did you know that any time there are exactly twenty penguins in a group they're plotting evil things? Evil things like global warming. And how to eat all the fish in the world so humans can't have any. Imagine walking around in the arctic when you stumble upon an evil group of penguins. They'd be cute if they weren't holding papers with "Kill All Humans" on them and tiny guns in their penguin hands.
mnemonics.reading: The evil penguins can't let you tell the other human's what you've seen, so they murder you and hide your body in a haystack (へい). Your family will never know what happened to you. The penguins will get away with their evil plans. Only someone or, in this case, something truly evil would kill someone and hide their remains under some hay. That's really disrespectful and, well, evil.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a scooter that is a satellite, but it is far off and far away. Look up into the sky. That little moving light is the scooter satellite. It's just scooting along, far away from here.
mnemonics.reading: The scooter satellite is far off, but you can still hear it's horn go "har (はる) har har." The scooter satellite's only purpose is to make a "har har har" sound that is audible from far away. It's quite obnoxious.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami together with another tsunami is going to cause a massive flood. More than one tsunami will definitely result in a flood. Imagine the floody aftermath of more than one tsunami, arriving together.
mnemonics.reading: After the terrible flood, Emperor こういち comes to survey the destruction and offer hope to his people. But, instead he just tells the people that this flood happened because they didn't believe in the Crabigator's words, and because they weren't doing their kanji reviews. "This flood was caused by you! It is because you did not believe in the holy Crabigator! It is because you didn't do your kanji reviews. It's because you used ignore scripts and reordering scripts and you sinned, sinned, sinned!" こういち says to the scared, cold, now homeless people.

mnemonics.meaning: Your threads are humble and that makes you a perfect gentleman. You don't have to have fancy clothes to be a gentleman, just humble ones that don't stand out and show off too much. That shows how polite you are. Picture yourself as the perfect gentleman. You may not have a fancy top hat and tie, but you're humble about what you wear and you're kind to everyone.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, as a gentleman who dresses humbly, you're always getting kicked in the shins (しん) by rude kids (and occasionally rude adults). But you're a gentleman, so you don't kick their shins back, you smile and hold in the pain. No matter how bad your shins hurt, you never fight back!

mnemonics.meaning: You've learned that you can catapult things to give them to other people! Don't catapult rocks at buildings and walls, catapult gifts to the people you love. If you want to give someone something, use a catapult!
mnemonics.reading: Give food to your new friend Godzilla (ご) with the catapult! You and Godzilla understand each other now. He's just hungry. You give Godzilla old used cars, chunks of old buildings, and sometimes hamburgers. Godzilla is so happy you're giving him food, he doesn't destroy anymore!

mnemonics.meaning: A samurai hits the foreheads of grains with his weapon so the grains will pop off and into his mouth. He doesn't want to kill the plants, so he's just skimming the grain's foreheads so they'll fall off and he can eat them. Picture the samurai taking out his weapon and spinning in a lightning fast circle. The forehead grains pop off and come raining into his open mouth.
mnemonics.reading: Phew, all of this grain is making the samurai thirsty, so he reaches in his bag and pulls out an ice cold, refreshing Coke (こく). These grains aren't even cooked, they're just hard and raw, so the Coke really helps wash them down.

mnemonics.meaning: Put your fingers in your ears when there's an explosion in addition to all the other things you were told to do. You have to crouch under a desk, you have to stay away from windows, you have to close your eyes. But in addition to that, you need to protect your ears! Pretend you're in a class in the mid-20th century, watching a video on bomb explosion safety. In addition to putting your fingers in your ears, you have to do a bunch of other stuff. You can't just stop after the first step!
mnemonics.reading: In addition to all the steps you have to take to protect yourself, you can't forget that ears come in sets (せつ). You can't just stick one finger in one ear and have that be the end. You have a set of ears to worry about! In addition to ears, you have a lot of sets on your body to worry about. Sets of eyes, nostrils, legs, you get the picture.

mnemonics.meaning: On the roof above, is a small stool. Anyone who sits in that stool will be lonely. Imagine sitting on this small stool, waaaaay up there above the roof. You can't see anyone and you can't talk to anyone. You feel this awful emptiness inside. That's what it's like to be lonely.
mnemonics.reading: You're so lonely, you make up an imaginary friend: Jack (じゃく). Jack doesn't get rid of the lonely feeling because he isn't real, but he is a distraction at least. You're so busy talking to Jack, you don't hear the voices from below, "Aren't you lonely up there, miss? Do you want us to get a jack to get you down? Hello? I don't think she can hear us..."

mnemonics.meaning: Your roof is spicy because you're the manager. You're always testing new recipes in your house to share with everyone who works under you, but that makes all the spice stick to your roof (since it doesn't have good ventilation like a restaurant or a lab would). Picture yourself as the manager of a restaurant or a science lab. You have to test all of your managerial methods at home before you can bring them to work. And if you were to lick that roof of yours... it would be spicy from all of your experiments.
mnemonics.reading: You've finally done it. You're now the manager of a bunch of spicy new cyborgs (さい). You've been toiling away for over a year, but you've finally replaced the cyborg you lost, and now you can manage them properly without anyone getting in the way.  Unfortunately, you couldn't figure out how to make non-spicy cyborgs, but that's okay because you're going to be the best cyborg manager ever! No one will ever take them away from you again.

mnemonics.meaning: The only building you'll get frostbite in is a mausoleum. Mausoleums and tombs weren't made for living people, so they aren't insulated from the cold. No one cares if a dead body gets frostbite. Unfortunately, you're realizing this because you thought a mausoleum would be a good hiding place from the winter cold. Spoilers, it's not.
mnemonics.reading: You need to escape this mausoleum now but the only way out is on a row (りょう) boat over a creepy frozen pond. You've heard of these mausoleum row boats before, and you're pretty sure they're cursed. Imagine taking your frostbitten fingers and trying to get away from the mausoleum in this row boat. It looks like it was made of bones and it is not very seaworthy. But you row with all your might, because you don't want to end up a permanent fixture in this tomb!

mnemonics.meaning: You go to buy a table but it looks it has water damage from drops of water hitting it. This makes it a pretty mediocre table. The water drops haven't really damaged it that much, it still stands and you can use it, but it's kinda ugly, so it's just mediocre. You didn't expect to see water drop damage on this table so now your mood is mediocre too.
mnemonics.reading: You weren't expecting to see such a mediocre table so you go up to the guy who's selling it and say, "Hey, I have a bone (ぼん) to pick with you!" But he doesn't think there is a bone to pick at all, he doesn't think the table is mediocre like you do. Imagine having a bone to pick with someone because they're trying to sell you something mediocre and they just won't listen. Now you have a bone to pick with the person who recommended this guy to you!

mnemonics.meaning: Who loves their flag, using jackhammers, and precise measurements? Your military officer! He's always saluting the flag, jackhammering near all the new recruits to test them, and checking the measurement between the floor and their pants. Who else could it be? Picture a military officer doing all those things.
mnemonics.reading: That military officer's favorite bird is an eagle (い)! That should be obvious because the eagle is the bird of America! And that's the country he fights for! Picture the military officer saluting as an eagle flies overhead. Majestic.

mnemonics.meaning: Stand staring up at the blue sky and you'll feel more peaceful than you ever have. Blue is a color that promotes peaceful thoughts and feelings. That's why all the social media sites are blue. To stop you from being a jerk. Imagine how peaceful staring at the blue ocean, the blue sky, or the blue tumblr makes you.
mnemonics.reading: Now if someone asks you if the color blue makes you peaceful you should say "YES! (やす)" And you'll have us to thank for that! All those peaceful blue radicals. They're the easiest thing on the site, and if someone asks you if radicals make you feel peaceful say YES again! Yes! Peaceful blue radicals standing in a row. What's that? YES you do want more radicals added to the site. Well okay then, if it will keep you at peace, sure!

mnemonics.meaning: When small drops of water work together they gain respect for one another. If you end up working with someone long enough, and they end up being really great, you'll respect them too!  Imagine being a small drop of water and seeing other drops of water come to help you by working together. You'd really respect them, right?
mnemonics.reading: If you respect someone enough you'll even take up their hobbies. The person you respect most loves the Yankees. You don't really feel the same, but you respect that about them so you chant, "Ooh Yankees, Ooh Yankees うやうや with them during each game. Imagine respecting someone so much that you'll cheer ooh yankees over and over even though they're kind of a crappy team.

mnemonics.meaning: You take some thread, put your scooter up to a signpost, and sew them together. You don't have a lock, so sewing your scooter up to the signpost to keep it safe is all you can think of. Imagine slowly sewing your scooter to the signpost, passing the thread back and forth through the signpost's metal holes and your scooter's handles.
mnemonics.reading: You usually only sew at home (ほう), so this is a big exception for you. You're usually worried that if you sew in public people will judge your stitches, so this is a big step for you! Hopefully, if your scooter is still here later you'll be able to start sewing outside of your home more often from now on!

mnemonics.meaning: A boat that's white isn't just a boat, it's a ship. Boats don't need to be a bright white color. But, ships do! They're dangerous and big, so they paint them nice and white.
mnemonics.reading: A white-painted ship is a kind of hack (はく). It makes the ship more visible without costing much. You can also imagine hacking the ship's computer. "Look at me, look at me. You are the hacker now."

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to fit your fingers into a key hole, you have to squeeze them in. Fingers aren't exactly supposed to fit in key holes... they're for keys, after all. But you want to squeeze your finger on in there anyway to unlock the door. Imagine what it would be like to squeeze your fingers into a keyhole. Maybe try squeezing one finger really tight first. Did that hurt? Well it's going to be a lot worse in that key hole.
mnemonics.reading: Once you've squeezed your finger in the key hole to unlock this door you squeeze all the money and jewels and treasures you can fit into your sack (さく). Your stealing sack. You have the ability to squeeze your fingers into locks to open them, so of course you're stealing. And you squeeze those stolen goodies into your sack so you can take them with you.

mnemonics.meaning: An animal with horns is drinking our alcohol? Still? You keep checking outside to see if they have stopped, but they are still drinking. They haven't stopped yet.
mnemonics.reading: The animal with horns that is still drinking your alcohol is no animal at all. It is actually one of the local youths (ゆう) dressed up like a horned animal so they can drink as long as they want and you'll be too scared to shoo them away. You keep checking, but that youth is still drinking. Of course, you don't know they are a youth, so it's quite impressive an animal can drink this much.

mnemonics.meaning: Take a mole out of its hole and it will suffocate. They need to be in tight quarters, unlike us humans. So when you take one out of its nice, safe hole, it thinks it can't breathe and suffocates. Picture a poor little mole suffocating in your hand after you took it out of its hole. Put it back right away! Don't kill that little mole!
mnemonics.reading: As the mole suffocates it cheats (ちつ) and shoves its head into your closed hand. You realize what it's doing and squeeze your hand tighter so it's more like a hole. You can feel the mole breathing again now. Unfortunately, you can't use cheats on life, and the mole suddenly stiffens and suffocates to death anyway. You should feel bad about what you've done.

mnemonics.meaning: A stone drops from the sky into a rice paddy and then a cross drops on top of it. They've combined to form a tombstone! Wait, does that mean a body fell from the sky first and you just didn't see it? Imagine seeing a stone and a cross drop from the sky onto each other to form a tombstone right in front of your eyes!
mnemonics.reading: Now you're curious about what's under there but when you try to touch the tombstone it's radiating with intense heat (ひ)! It must have come from outer space and this heat is from when it entered our atmosphere! Can you feel the heat radiating off this space tombstone? Maybe there's a space skeleton sizzling under there too...

mnemonics.meaning: You shoot an arrow at the mouth of the sun so that it will grant you a gift of wisdom. You heard about a Greek hero doing this and the god in the sun gave him the wisdom to see everything. You're hoping it will work for you too. Imagine shooting an arrow at the mouth of the sun and then waiting for the wisdom of the world to hit you. Did it work? Will you know when it works? Probably...
mnemonics.reading: You're standing around waiting for the wisdom to hit you when something else does. In the head. Ouch! You look down and it's a wheel of cheese (ち)! At first you're angry, until you realize that this must be a sign. Cheese IS wisdom. And the key to wisdom is eating a lot of cheese! Picture yourself thanking the sun for teaching you that all wisdom comes from cheese. Now take a big bite!

mnemonics.meaning: Say furthermore again and you'll be saying it all the more.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あなたのことが尚更嫌いになりました。
I came to dislike you all the more.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone keeps saying furthermore and also over and over again. Just when you think they've stopped, they turn around and say "and yet," before going back to repeating furthermore and besides again and again. It's driving you crazy.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は、美しく、尚且つ頭も良いが、性格は悪い。
She’s beautiful, and furthermore, she's smart, but she has a terrible personality.

mnemonics.meaning: Hands beating together is actually applause. Though... you might be doing it wrong if you're actually beating them together.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 舞台が終わった後、拍手が鳴り止まなかった。
After the scene ended, the applause did not stop roaring.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You meet an artisan and they're tacking pictures on a wall to sell. You want the artisan to make a picture of you too so you yell, "TACK ME (たくみ)!"

sentences: この商品のデザインは、匠の技をもって初めて実現することができました。
This product’s design was the first time I was able to implement that technique.

mnemonics.meaning: A day you hold in high esteem is an auspicious day. That's a fancy way of saying it's a really lucky day!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 本日は、皇太子殿下御生誕の嘉日なり。
It’s the auspicious day of the Crown Prince’s birth today.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji refers to a beat and the 〜 lets you know this is a counter. So this is used as a counter for beats for when you're listening to or playing music.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 4分の4拍子の曲では、通常、1拍目と3拍目の頭に強拍が来ます。
For music in four-four time, the stress usually comes to a head at the first and third beats.

meanings: bitter enemies in the same boat

mnemonics.meaning: You give your rival information that will go beyond what you normally say and you realize the two of you are in the same boat on a lot of personal things. You are bitter enemies in the same boat! Or classic rivals, like you see in movies and read about. You never would have known if you hadn't gone beyond what you normally give people.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 舟 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What are bitter enemies in the same boat supposed to do? They shoot (しゅう) each other!

sentences: 利害が一致すれば、呉越同舟も厭わない。
If we can share mutual interests, I won’t mind being in the same boat as my rivals.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Snap all the bowstrings! Now none of the musicians can play their instruments. "You're too rude (つる)!" they yell, as they cry over the snapped bowstrings. They aren't wrong, that was just too rude of you.

sentences: ギターの弦が緩んでいます。
The guitar strings are loose.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 父は、毎日色の違う蝶ネクタイをしていた。
My father has a different colored bow tie every day.

mnemonics.meaning: The big military officer is in charge of everyone else. He's the captain. You can tell because he wears a really big captain hat.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大尉の死は決して無駄ではなかった。
The captain’s death wasn’t useless by any means.

mnemonics.meaning: Okay, so this is a stretch but stay with me! In addition to your family name, the first thing you need to learn as a child is how to understand centigrade. If you can't tell what temperature it is outside, or in your house, or in your body to tell if you're sick, you won't do so well with this living thing. So when you think back to the first things you learned in addition to your own family name, think centigrade! Of course, in reality, these kanji were simply chosen for their pronunciation rather than their meaning, but hopefully that mnemonic will help you remember which kanji are used here!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日の最高気温は、摂氏二十五度です。
Today’s maximum temperature is twenty-five degrees Celsius.
摂氏100度が水の沸点です。
100 degrees Celsius is the boiling point of water.
アメリカも早く華氏から摂氏に変えればいいのに。
I wish the US would hurry up and change from Fahrenheit to Celsius.

mnemonics.meaning: You're so mediocre that you're flat. That's really common. Look at most of the midwest. It's really mediocre and flat too. And there's a whole lot of it out there.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 平凡な毎日に退屈していたんです。
I’m bored with the ordinary every day.

mnemonics.meaning: A confused riot causes even more confusion. Soon there will be so many distractions happening, what with cars tipping over and fires starting, that no one will know which way is up!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 薬で意識が錯乱しているようでした。
Their consciousness seemed to be confused by the medicine.

mnemonics.meaning: You're full of delight. It's still delight though.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ご満悦のようですね。

mnemonics.meaning: An artisan has an idea and makes a brand new design!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これは、意匠が凝らされた素晴らしい作品です。

mnemonics.meaning: Destitute lands will be faced with a dilemma. Do they leave? Or do they try to make the best of it?

sentences: 窮地に追い込まれ、ようやく尻尾を見せました。

mnemonics.meaning: Fix your control over the planet by assuming direct control.
