sentences: それじゃあ、ここも政府が直轄している機関なんですか。
Well then, is there an agency the government has direct control over here too?

mnemonics.meaning: Destitute conditions lead to distress.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 役所に窮状を訴えたのですが、聞き入れてもらえませんでした。
I appealed to the government about the wretched conditions, but I didn’t receive a response.

mnemonics.meaning: Some things happen outside of reason. They happen in addition to it. That's called divine providence. You can't explain it, but something outside of reason definitely influenced the things around you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 誰も自然の摂理には逆らえないよ。
No one can defy the laws of nature.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to give clothes to other people, you have to buy draperies first and then sew them together. That's a fancy word for cloth.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は呉服屋の一人息子でした。
He’s the drapery store’s only son.

mnemonics.meaning: The evil damage you do has an evil effect on people. All that negativity can have a really harmful influence on them. You should think before you do things.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 子供にゲームをさせないことによる弊害も考えておくべきです。
You should also think about how evil it is to not let children play video games.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're exhausted by all the evil things in your life you might die of exhaustion!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 人口が増えない限り、地方経済の疲弊が回復することはないでしょう。
It seems that the local economy will not recover from impoverishment unless the population increases.

mnemonics.meaning: Take children from their homes and squeeze all their talent out until they have nothing left. That's called exploitation, and lots of companies make money off of it. It's not very nice though.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このエージェントは、ギャラをかなり搾取することで有名だ。
This agent is famous for considerably exploiting his guarantees.

mnemonics.meaning: If you still need more time to finish a project and you tell whoever is in charge beforehand you'll be able to get an extension. Then you'll be able to finish it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お前に三日間の猶予を与えてやろう。
I suppose I’ll give you a three day extension.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading! Just don't forget the か at the end.

sentences: その鐘の音は、遥か彼方まで響き渡った。
The chimes echoed from far away.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: おじいさんは、山で柴刈りをしていました。
My grandfather was gathering firewood in the mountains.

mnemonics.meaning: A military officer who's in the middle of their career has become a first lieutenant.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 我が軍の中尉が敵軍に拉致され、処刑されました。
Our army’s first lieutenant was captured by the enemy and executed.

mnemonics.meaning: A flood of water still makes a flood.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. But watch out because すい becomes ずい here.

sentences: 台風で川が氾濫し、洪水になりました。
The river overflowed from the typhoon and became a flood.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A foolish person will take the old road (おろ), instead of the new, safe one. You have to be really stupid to take an old road that's all cracked and full of scary people. Take the new one!

sentences: あいつも愚かなことをしたもんだよ。
He does such stupid things.

mnemonics.meaning: A cold cold person is so cold that they're super cool. They're sooo cool and gallant and manly. Touch a manly person and feel how cold their skin is. It's like that all the way down to their heart.
mnemonics.reading: Usually when you see 々 it means that the reading is two on'yomi readings repeating. Well this is a bit of an exception. Saying りんりん is kinda hard so just drop the んs and you'll have the reading りり!

sentences: 少年は、凛々しい青年に成長した。
Boys grow into gallant young men.

mnemonics.meaning: Gentlemen who are also samurai are still gentlemen. They just carry swords.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は、英国紳士の鏡のような人でした。
He looked like the spitting image of an English gentleman.

mnemonics.meaning: Grain things are grains and cereal!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このスープには五種類の穀物が入っています。
There are five types of grains in this soup.

mnemonics.meaning: Grains are types of grains! You thought they would be something else? Nope. Grains are pretty boring.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は穀類を毎食摂るようにしています。
I try to have grains with every meal.

mnemonics.meaning: Combine a grave and a tombstone and you make a gravestone.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 誰かが墓碑を倒したんです。
Someone knocked over the gravestone.

mnemonics.meaning: Just because there's a mausoleum on this hill doesn't mean it isn't still a hill. (It is. It's still a hill.)
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日は天気が良かったので、矢田丘陵を歩きました。
The weather was nice today so I walked the Yata hills.

mnemonics.meaning: You thought you memorized what this picture looked like, but suddenly everything looks confused and different. That's because it's an illusion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: それがまるで自分のもののような錯覚に襲われたんです。
I was assailed by an illusion that looked just like me.

mnemonics.meaning: A boat that comes from somewhere else is bringing imported goods.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 舶来のブランデーだと叔父はよく自慢していた。
My uncle often boasted that it was imported brandy.

mnemonics.meaning: You're bored but you keep eating. Maybe you're eating because you're bored. If you're bored all the time, eventually your main goal in life becomes satiation.  In modern Japanese, this word crops up most in 飽食時代, which could be roughly translated as "the age of plenty". 飽食時代 refers to the modern era in countries like Japan, which are characterized by an abundance of food, in contrast to the past, when food was scarce.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本は、戦後の食料不足から飽食の時代へ大きく変わりました。
Japan made a huge change from the postwar food shortage to an era of plenty.

mnemonics.meaning: The writing on a tombstone makes up the inscription or epitaph the family members decided to put there.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この慰霊碑の碑文は誰が考えたのですか。
Who thought of the inscription for this memorial?

mnemonics.meaning: Your body takes nutrients into itself in addition to all the extra crap you eat. It's called your daily intake. And it gets all of those nutrients in your body through absorption.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 一日の摂取カロリーを計算してみました。
I calculated my calorie intake for one day.

mnemonics.meaning: Whoever holds the pipe has control of the situation so you give them jurisdiction to do whatever they want. It's better than getting hit by a pipe.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ここは、南署の管轄です。
The southern police have jurisdiction here.

mnemonics.meaning: If you place control on someone you're giving them jurisdiction over whatever that thing is.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: とにかく、まずは所轄の警察署に連絡をいれましょう。
Anyway, let’s get in contact with the police station with jurisdiction first.

mnemonics.meaning: A lazy someone is a lazy person.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は会社で一番の怠け者だが、一番成績を上げている。
He’s the laziest person at the company, but he also gets the best results.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of lonely? It's still lonely!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: No one is as lonely as a sad bee (さび). The sad bee is sad because it has no friends and that makes is super lonely. Poor sad bee.

sentences: やっぱり一人暮らしは寂しいです。
As I thought, the single life is lonely.

mnemonics.meaning: An artisan who is a giant in their field is a master! Everyone knows their name! Or, they're just really large... like tall, so everyone calls them a master cause they don't want to get crushed.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この女優は、多くの巨匠たちを唸らせた。
This actress made many great masters grunt in admiration.

mnemonics.meaning: An artisan who's good enough to be a teacher has to be a master of her craft.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 師匠と呼ばせてもらえませんか。
May I call you "master?"

mnemonics.meaning: Mediocre and common things are still mediocre and common.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は凡庸な男ですが、愛に満ちあふれていました。
He was a mediocre man but was filled to the brim with love.

mnemonics.meaning: Squeeze an udder to get milk. Look at that, you're milking a cow!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 牧場で搾乳体験をしてきました。
I personally experienced milking at the farm.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're confused and you make a mistake, no matter how much you didn't mean it, it's still a mistake. You should ask for help next time you don't know what you're doing and you won't make these errors.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ちょっとそれは時代錯誤じゃないか。
Don’t you think that’s a little anachronistic?

mnemonics.meaning: You mix a bunch of ingredients into a confused mixture. That's going to be one weird cake, or whatever the mixture's for.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 色々な感情が交錯し、結論を出せずにいました。
Various emotions were mixed and we weren’t able to reach a conclusion.

mnemonics.meaning: Some tombstones are used to write down the thoughts of dead people. They're monuments. They can be really big or really small, but they have to be dedicated to somebody (usually a dead somebody).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これは何の記念碑ですか。
What kind of monument is this?

mnemonics.meaning: What wisdom waterfall is Nachi Falls, one of the most famous (and wisest) waterfalls in Japan.
mnemonics.reading: You learned all three of these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日曜日は、熊野古道を歩いて、那智の滝を見に行く予定です。
On Sunday, we plan to walk the Kumano Kodō and see Nachi Falls.
これは、この間行った那智の滝で一番よくとれた写真です。
This is the best photo I could get of Nachi Falls, which I went to the other day.
那智の滝は、国の名勝に指定されています。
Nachi Falls has been designated a national beauty spot.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: You notice a lot of neglect when it comes to old road soap cars (おろそか). If you drive down the old road you'll see neglected cars made of soap all over the place. It's sad, really.

sentences: 基本を疎かにしてはいけません。
You must not neglect the basics.

mnemonics.meaning: An element that can cause a person to suffocate is nitrogen. Too much or too little will cause it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 飛行機のタイヤには窒素が入っています。
There’s nitrogen in airplane tires.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a combination of the words 方向 and 音痴. When your sense of direction is tone-deaf, it means you have no sense of direction. You get lost no matter how hard you try.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は方向音痴で、すぐ道に迷います。
I have no sense of direction so I get lost immediately.

mnemonics.meaning: A mediocre person is an ordinary person. There isn't anything weird or interesting about them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あんたみたいな凡人が書いた本、誰が読むのさ。
Who would read a book written by an ordinary person like you?

mnemonics.meaning: An evil company is actually our company or our humble company. We're not going to say our company is virtuous, are we? That wouldn't be humble at all. So instead we call it evil, to show our humility.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この度は弊社のサービスをご利用いただきまして誠にありがとうございます。
Thank you very much for using our company's service.
キャンセルの場合は、お手数ではございますが弊社カスタマーサポートまでご連絡ください。
In case of cancellation, please contact our company's customer support.
本キャンペーンは、弊社の都合により告知なしに終了する場合がございます。
This campaign may be terminated without notice depending on our company's circumstances.

mnemonics.meaning: When your confused urges overthrow normal thoughts and feelings it's a perversion. Some are harmless, but some are not.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 倒錯思考はまず現実否定から始まる。
Perverse thoughts first negate reality.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 庶民 means "common people?" Well when all the common people like something it becomes popular!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ここの饂飩はこの庶民的な味がいいんだよ。
The humble taste of the udon here is good.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 歌謡 means "song," so when you add music to that it becomes a super popular song. It's not just a song anymore. It's in everything you hear! More broadly, this can refer to a whole genre of Japanese pop music from the Showa era. In other words, it refers to retro J-POP or Showa-era pop music. The word kayokyoku is sometimes used for it in English too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 心に残る昭和の歌謡曲ベスト100のリストが公表されました。
A list of the 100 best, most unforgettable, popular songs from the Showa Era was announced.

mnemonics.meaning: You'll be distressed and destitute if you're living in poverty.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 両親は生活に困窮していましたが、私にも彼らを助ける余裕はありませんでした。
My parents were living in poverty but I didn’t have the money to help them.

mnemonics.meaning: Towns destitute and scarce of food will end up in poverty and destitution.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 生活が窮乏して、仕方なく盗みを働いたんです。
He lived in poverty and committed theft as a last resort.

mnemonics.meaning: The person everyone comes to a mutual agreement about to be the manager of the country is the Prime Minister.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 相 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The first Prime Minister of Japan was actually the shogun (しょう). That was before everything got complicated.

sentences: 英国宰相から直々に手紙を頂きました。
I received a letter from the prime minister of the UK personally.

mnemonics.meaning: It's an injustice that so many people in this world are mediocre and we can't all be a prodigy at something. Everyone deserves to be unique, but it just isn't true.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: みんな、彼の非凡な才能を妬んでいたんだと思います。
I think everyone was jealous of his unique talent.

mnemonics.meaning: The beating in your veins is your pulse.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: すでに脈拍が止まっている。
The pulse has already stopped.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of respect? It's respectful.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji so you should be able to read this too.

sentences: 二人は神前で恭しく頭を下げた。
The couple respectfully bowed their heads before the altar.

mnemonics.meaning: Bind a bundle of sticks to a person as a type of restraint. They can't get away when they're tied to a bunch of sticks, can they?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼氏の束縛が厳しいんだよね。
My boyfriend’s confinement is too severe.

mnemonics.meaning: Rice grains make up the rice we eat everyday.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 我が社は、米国で米穀を売っています。
My company sells rice to America.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're so bored of peace because all there IS is peace, it's called saturation of the peace market. You've pretty much been soaked through with peace and now you want a little chaotic excitement!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 市場は今飽和状態になっているんだよ。
The market is saturated now.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who's only been a military officer for a few years hasn't been able to get very far in the ranks. They're an ensign, or a second lieutenant. That's still not a bad position to be in!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の曽祖父は、旧日本陸軍少尉でした。
My great-grandfather was a second lieutenant in the former Japanese army.

mnemonics.meaning: Sew to manufacture things by sewing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 縫製加工はこのミシンで行われました。
The sewing process was done with this sewing machine.

mnemonics.meaning: Sew so well that people will judge you to be the best and you'll be a champion at sewing!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 裁縫はあまり得意ではありません。
Sewing really isn’t my strong point.

mnemonics.meaning: The brushwood dog is the Shiba Inu. They're the same pretty orange color as brushwood trees, so that's how they got their name.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ニッカは柴犬ではなく珍島犬です。
Nikka isn’t a Shiba, she’s a Jindo.

mnemonics.meaning: A boat ship is still a ship.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その船舶は、どこの国に登録されているものですか。
Which country is this ship registered under?

mnemonics.meaning: If you're lonely and quiet you'll be surrounded in silence.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 赤ん坊の泣き声が静寂を破った。
The baby’s cry destroyed the silence.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of lazy? It's sluggish and dull.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you're feeling sluggish just turn on Darude's (だる) "Sandstorm" and it will perk you right up. But a world where people don't know Darude's "Sandstorm"  is full of sluggish, dull nerds.

sentences: インフルエンザによる高熱で、体が怠いんです。
My body feels heavy because of my high fever from influenza.

mnemonics.meaning: A tombstone made of a big stone is used as a stone monument. These stones are usually so big that they're used for multiple people who died together.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これが石碑に彫られていた文字です。
These are the words carved on the stone monument.
無人島のはずのこの島に石碑が建っているのはなぜですか。
Why is there a stone monument on this supposedly uninhabited island?
津波が襲った高さの地点に石碑が建てられているのです。
A stone monument was built at the site where the height of the tsunami hit.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 楽 was used in 音楽 and meant "music?" Well this is that 楽 again. Music made with a bowstring is string music.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 学生時代に数年ほど弦楽をやっていました。
I played string music for several years during my school days.

mnemonics.meaning: Suffocate to the point that you have no breath left and you'll die of suffocation. Chew your food and this shouldn't happen!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 死因は首を絞められたことによる窒息です。
The cause of death was suffocation due to strangulation of the neck.

mnemonics.meaning: The master manager rules over all of the other managers and he's in charge of their supervision. If anything goes wrong it will be blamed on him! He has to keep a close watch on them!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: いつか自分の劇団を主宰するのが夢です。
I dream of supervising my own theater troupe someday.

mnemonics.meaning: Don't yield to anything when you're destitute because it'll make things even more tight. Usually you have to be pretty rigid about what you can and cannot afford.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 窮屈な下着は体によくない。
Tight underwear isn’t good for you.
部屋が窮屈でごめんね。ここに座っていてくれる？今、お茶持ってくるから。
I'm sorry the room is so cramped. Can you just sit here? I'll get you some tea.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shock, so the verb version is to be shocked or to be amazed.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  If you were going to be shocked, you'd shout, "ACK (あき)!"

sentences: アイドルの度重なるプッツン発言に、世間はみんな呆れました。
The phrase the idol repeatedly snapped shocked the world.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bored, so the verb version is to get tired of or to lose interest in.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you start to get tired of something you can't help but yawn "Ahh (あ)." It doesn't matter how hard you try to hold back. The "A-ah's" keep coming out.

sentences: 新しい恋人に飽きてきたところなの。
I’m at a place where I’m starting to lose interest in my new lover.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sew, so the verb version is to sew or to stitch.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to sew yourself some clothes because if you don't you'll be completely nude (ぬ). You don't want anyone to see your bits! Sew quickly!

sentences: 家庭科の授業で、雑巾を縫いました。
We sewed dust cloths in home economics class.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means squeeze, so the verb version is to squeeze. The way that this word differs from 絞る is that 絞る means "to wring out" and 搾る means to squeeze or to juice fruits/vegetables or to milk a cow.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: After the farmer milks the cow, she bows (しぼ) to the cow to say thank you for letting her squeeze out some fresh milk.

sentences: レモンを唐揚げに搾ってもいいですか？
Can I squeeze lemon over the fried food?

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 逸らす means "to turn away," so this means that but also to stray.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You've already learned this mnemonic but here's a quick review:  If you're the type of person who starts to stray easily, you'll end up saying sorry (それ) a lot. Even if you don't do it often, if you stray, say sorry!

sentences: すぐ話が脇道へ逸れてしまう。
The conversation quickly digressed.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bind, so the verb version is to tie or to bind.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want to tie up? Your Shiba (しば) Inu! She's always running off and getting into trouble. You have to tie her up outside when you leave the house. It's sad, but at least it keeps her safe!

sentences: 靴紐が解けないようにしっかり縛った。
I tied my shoelaces tightly so they wouldn't come loose.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: そんな子供の姿を見て、智を開く思いがしました。
I looked at the figures of those children and I felt like my own wisdom was freed.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 報酬 means "compensation," so adding not to it means the person working isn't getting paid, aka working without pay.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 無報酬でもかまいませんよ。
There’s no pay, but I don’t mind.

mnemonics.meaning: You already know that 神社 means "shinto shrine," so add peaceful and country to it and you get a shrine that calls for the peace of the entire country. It's Yasukuni Shrine. If you watch the news you know that this name and everything it stands for is always a topic of current debates.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of two words. The first two kanji take the kun'yomi readings and the second two are the jukugo word 神社. You already learned all of these readings, so you should already be able to read this word!

sentences: 靖国神社に参拝したことはありますか。
Have you ever visited Yasukuni Shrine?

mnemonics.meaning: It looks like there is a dent in this box. When there is a hole or a dent in something it's called concave.
This looks like a box with something sticking out of it. When something is sticking out of something else it's convex.
The death of your eyes means that you've gone blind. Imagine what it would be like to have one of your eyes die. You'll be blind in that eye forever!
mnemonics.reading: When you're blind you probably shouldn't drive anymore because if you do you'll mow (もう) everyone over. Actually, don't mow your lawn either. Blind people probably shouldn't be driving anything. Imagine a blind person mowing over everyone in their car as they drive on the sidewalk. Eeek. At least they don't have to see this mess.

mnemonics.meaning: An alcohol nurse is someone who nurses alcohol. In other words, they brew it. Imagine a nurse brewing alcohol with the same attention they would nurse a human patient. But this brew is much more important than any person's health.
mnemonics.reading: A brew of alcohol is what Jourm (じょう) loves most after a long day. As you know, Jourm infiltrated your village and pretended to be a large, simple farmhand, only to bring destruction down upon you. After he was done, he sat down and drank a brew with his Viking buddies.

mnemonics.meaning: The concave radical and the concave kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: If you call someone concave the 王 (おう) will find out and he'll have his guards turn you concave. Watch your mouth around the 王. Have you ever seen a concave person? Yeah that's because they didn't live through it. 王s aren't very nice, you know.

mnemonics.meaning: You give a bow and a stick to your friend's family. This is because your friend died, and he loved bows and sticks. You give this to his family, to give our condolences. Imagine looking at the bow and stick as you slide them over to your deceased friend's family. This won't do enough, but it is a little condolence at least.
mnemonics.reading: More than a condolence, you want to avenge your friend's death. He was killed by Mrs. Chou (ちょう), and she broke his stick and bow, which is why you got the family a new set. Imagine her saying, "My condolences," as Mrs. Chou does him in.

mnemonics.meaning: The convex radical and the convex kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both. Study your radicals and you'll read good.
mnemonics.reading: Is this convex? It's totes (とつ) convex!  Tote bags are totes not convex though. Don't mix them up.

mnemonics.meaning: An altered bird is a crow! They look like birds but they're bigger and darker and smarter! See that bird? Wait, that's not just a bird, it's a crow!
mnemonics.reading: If you can't tell just from looking at it that it's a crow and not a bird, walk up to it and caress (からす) it with your hand! If it caresses you back, it's a crow! If it freaks out and flies away or pecks your face, it's a normal bird. Crows are really smart and like affection. That's what makes them so cool! How many crows have you caressed today?

mnemonics.meaning: An elf who ventures outside in winter has a lot of daring. Elf ears are very, very delicate, and the winter cold can really mess them up. So if you see an elf adventuring in winter, know that that particular elf is a really daring dude. Imagine how much daring it would take to go outside in winter knowing you could be freezing your precious elf ears off.
mnemonics.reading: The amount of daring you'd need is about equal to the amount Genghis Khan (かん) had. And he was really daring! Do you think you have the same amount of daring as an elf going out in winter and Genghis Khan? Tell the truth.

mnemonics.meaning: Even if you have a building, it will eventually turn back into dirt. Everything will degenerate eventually. A brick falls off here, a door comes loose there. Nothing can last forever. Imagine a time lapse video of a building degenerating.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch the building degenerate, you can't help but think of your dad (だ). You had to watch him waste away the same way of a degenerative disease. Why do people have to die, dad? This may not be a happy thing to think about, but it will help you remember this kanji better. Imagine your dad fighting a degenerative disease. Imagine helping him fight through this. Everything will be okay eventually. I promise.

mnemonics.meaning: You take a drum and a branch and... well, what else would you do? You would drum or beat them together. A branch is just like a drumstick, so of course you're going to drum them together.
mnemonics.reading: Who loves to drum things together and make a huge racket? 子s (こ), of course. Kids can't get enough of it. Anything that makes a loud drumming noise or anything they can beat together is fun for them.

mnemonics.meaning: You go to a big rice paddy and establish a prison right in the middle of it to restore the equilibrium of the area. There was a lot of crime right here in this rice paddy, so you just built a big prison right there to lower the crime rate so this region can experience equilibrium once again.
mnemonics.reading: To restore equilibrium in these parts, you throw all the 耕ing こういち clones into the prison.  The cloned こういちs were causing all the crime in these parts (or so Emperor こういち said), so by throwing them in a prison built right there just for them, this area could once again achieve equilibrium.

mnemonics.meaning: If the leader of your gang is a drunkard he'll try to have you fell trees thinking they're rival gang members. You all know they aren't but you can't argue with your leader, especially if he's drunk. Go ahead and attack the trees anyway. Imagine felling trees with a bunch of other guys, yelling things like, "This is what you get for stepping on my turf!" It's a little silly.
mnemonics.reading: As you attack the innocent trees with your chains and sticks, a bunch of bats (ばつ) come flying out and attack YOU! You have your own kind of bats so now you're all trying to fell the bats with YOUR bats! Bats attacking bats. Who will win on this season of Survivor?

mnemonics.meaning: Alcohol is a good teacher on the process of fermentation. Because alcohol is so good and addicting, people will work extra hard to ferment it properly. This makes it a good teacher to learn about fermentation. People are motivated to figure it out!
mnemonics.reading: Using fermentation, you are indeed making some alcohol. It will be drunk at a party put on by Emperor こういち. You are fermenting thousands of bottles of alcohol for Emperor こういち's big party.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a guard at your gate to get a good inspection of your neighborhood going. The guard will stand there all day inspecting everything and then report it all back to you. You won't have to do any of the inspection yourself! Imagine the guard doing his inspection in front of the gate all day long. He should have a nice report for you once he's done.
mnemonics.reading: His inspection is complete, but it looks like he's used an etch (えつ) a sketch to record all the results. That's not really helpful. If you shake it all the inspection results will disappear! If you hire a guard to stand at your gate and conduct an inspection of your neighborhood, make sure you tell him not to use an etch a sketch!

mnemonics.meaning: You're riding your scooter toward your yurt as fast as you can because someone is trying to get in there to boil your water and you want to intercept them. If you manage to intercept them before they can go in there to boil things, you'll be able to pick up all the clothes and comic books you left on the floor. You really don't want anyone to see those.
mnemonics.reading: You manage to intercept the shaman (しゃ) who was just about to open the door to your yurt, and instead you crash right into him. Phew, you intercepted the shaman in time (though she doesn't look very happy about being scooted into) and now you can clean up your yurt before they go in.

mnemonics.meaning: The moon is easy tonight, so you decide to cut it open. But, the moon wasn't the moon, it was your big, pale, round tummy. You just cut it open, and now you can see your intestines. Imagine the moon, then imagine it cross-fading into your big, round tummy. Then, cut it open because you think the moon is easy to cut. And finally, see your intestines as clearly as you can.
mnemonics.reading: All over the world, people are cutting their bellies open, because they think its an easy moon (versus a normal moon, or hard moon, presumably). This is because they have fallen victim to a spell by Mrs. Chou (ちょう). This scene was in all the omen radicals you've been seeing about her. If only you could have stopped her, then none of this would have happened, right? Perhaps it was all destiny, you think, as your intestines fall from your stomach and Mrs. Chou cackles over your weakening body.

mnemonics.meaning: The king will send his men with swords into your private rice paddy if you come across lapis lazuli. Even though this is your private land, he wants that lapis lazuli to make some new crowns and thrones for himself. Plus he's the king, so he can do whatever he wants. If you've never taken an art history class (or played Minecraft) you may never have come across lapis lazuli, but think of it as a pretty, blue precious stone that people really, really liked in the olden days. Watch the king's swords digging in your private rice paddy and digging up huge chunks of lapis lazuli. This isn't fair, that lapis should belong to you.
mnemonics.reading: You run up and ask how this lapis lazuli thievery isn't illegal and one of the swordsmen just shouts, "Loophole (る)!" What? What loophole? What law says that the king gets to steal your stuff? Imagine reading through a giant text called "The Law" and looking for this loophole the king's men claim to have about taking your lapis lazuli. You can't find it... but maybe if you search just a bit longer...

mnemonics.meaning: Your nose isn't the first thing people see about your face, it's the latter. They see your eyes THEN your nose, then your mouth, in order going down. Just label them A B and C and you'll never forget! Imagine saying A B C as you look down someones face at their eyes, nose and mouth. Their nose is B!
mnemonics.reading: If you don't have any cereal you have to eat your B breakfast option. Oats (おつ). You don't hate oats, but they're definitely not your first choice. Imagine running out of cereal so you have to eat your latter option of breakfast oats. They aren't awful but they aren't your A breakfast choice, that's for sure.

mnemonics.meaning: A tree that does well in the wind is a maple tree. Maple trees don't have fruit so the wind can't knock anything off of it. That's why they thrive well in windy places! Picture a bunch of maple trees being blown by the wind. They don't seem upset, they actually seem really happy.
mnemonics.reading: When the wind goes through the maple tree you know it's kite day (かえで)! Imagine your kite in the maple tree.

mnemonics.meaning: If you trap the moon in a greenhouse it will grow a creepy membrane around itself. The moon isn't used to the heat it would be exposed to in a greenhouse so that membrane is there to protect it. It's really gross looking though. Imagine seeing the moon with a membrane sitting stuffed in a greenhouse. It looks like something out of the Alien movies and you're starting to think putting it in there wasn't a good idea.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to open the greenhouse to check this moon membrane out but when you open the door the smell of big macs (まく) hits you in the face. Eww. Why does this membrane smell like a big mac... or does that mean big macs smell like a festering moon? Can you imagine if the moon had a membrane and it smelled like a big mac? How does that even happen? You should probably go ask that food chain what they use for their ingredients.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to turn your thread into a sweet color you just HAVE to go with navy or dark blue. That's the sweetest color in existence, everyone knows that. After all, blue raspberry flavor is dark blue and it's super sweet. Turn your thread a sweet navy color and people will be reminded of yummy blue raspberry. MmMmm.
mnemonics.reading: Now that your threads are navy colored you need to be careful that condors (こん) don't try to steal it for their nests. Condors love dark blue things and thread is perfect for a condor nest. Imagine a condor stealing your sweet navy thread right after you dyed it, flying off. Lame!

mnemonics.meaning: Flowers grown in a warehouse will be very pale. They never see the sun, so they don't grow to have bright colors. Imagine walking into a warehouse and seeing hundreds of pale flowers growing in it. It's subtle, but beautiful.
mnemonics.reading: When you grow pale flowers like this, they don't grow a soul (そう). Soul adds color to plants and flowers. That's probably why ghosts and dead bodies are pale too. Picture a bunch of pale, soulless flowers. You pick one up and it falls apart in your hands.

mnemonics.meaning: Tsunamis get blamed because they pickle everything in their path. That means that everything smells of pickles after a tsunami. Imagine a tsunami crashing over the land, being blamed by everyone. In its path is are piles and piles of pickles, as far as the eye can see!
mnemonics.reading: Looking at all those pickles, you bend down and pick up two (つ) of them. One in each hand. You look at the pickles in your hand and wonder whether to try one. Picture the two pickles and imagine what kind of pickles they are.

mnemonics.meaning: A drunkard has dirt in his mouth as he tries to talk to you. You walk over and he spits a question mark into your hand. It's covered in dirt and spit. Um... does this mean he's confused? He probably doesn't even know where he is. But how did he make this question mark and why was it in his mouth? Imagine having a drunkard spit a dirty question mark into your hand. You want to say, "Yes, I'm ??? too."
mnemonics.reading: The drunkard takes the question mark back and presses it to his head. He's wearing a Yankee's (や) cap. Oh come on. "Do you just want to know the Yankee's score in the game?" The drunkard nods. Picture yourself throwing the question mark at the drunkard who only cares about the Yankees. What a waste of time.

mnemonics.meaning: To the mountains you took your horned husband for you two to get married. (Society wouldn't accept a horned husband!) To hide even more from the prying eyes of society, you take your horned husband into a ravine. Imagine walking up the mountain in your wedding clothes so you can get married without anyone trying to stop you. Then, because you're still worried, you go into a ravine where you are read your marriage vows.
mnemonics.reading: The ravine is still in きょうと though, because if you went outside the city your marriage wouldn't be legal. So you found a secluded, local ravine. This ravine runs right through the middle of きょうと, though most people don't notice it. That makes it the best place for a secret wedding to a horned freak-husband.

mnemonics.meaning: When a shellfish becomes a drunkard and sees a cross, they'll become a robber. Because they'll steal the cross! Some people make really bad choices when they're drunk, and in this case, when a shellfish gets drunk and sees something it wants it'll just rob people for it.
mnemonics.reading: Once the shellfish has a taste for being a robber, he'll join a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang so he can keep stealing more and more crosses. He'll drink more, steal more, and get to ride cool motorcycles. Picture a robber shellfish in a Bosozoku bike gang. Look at him the wrong way and he and his gang will steal all your stuff next time!

mnemonics.meaning: Move your coat rack in one direction by shooting it with a gun. Then you can keep shooting it to get a good rotation going. If you think there is a better way to make your coat rack make revolutions, you're probably wrong.  Imagine getting your coat rack to make rotations in a circle just by shooting it with a gun!
mnemonics.reading: As you watch your coat rack's rotations a centaur (せん) barges in and takes the gun from you, stops the rotating coat rack and leaves. How rude! I guess centaurs don't like when things rotate. Picture that centaurs angry face. Convince yourself it was the rotation it didn't like.

mnemonics.meaning: The leader says spring is looking dry, so you'll need your salary in advance. The leader shows you the number, it's all of your salary for spring. "This way, if things dry up worse, you'll be okay for a while," he says. This is awfully nice, but very suspicious at the same time.
mnemonics.reading: Your salary is sent straight to your home (ほう) instead of the bank. Okay, something is definitely fishy here. You're sitting at home, and there is a knock at the door. A man in a suit, hat, and dark sunglasses hands you a briefcase full of money. "Here's your spring salary. Enjoy the dry weather." "T-thanks?" Welp, have fun at home with your stacks of early salary cash.

mnemonics.meaning: If you put your spoon in the sun while you're in prison, a mouth will appear to scold you. You can never see who the mouth belongs to, but considering you're in prison it's probably a guard. Either way, that person doesn't like what you're doing and they keep scolding you when you put your spoon out into the sun. Imagine trying to reflect some precious sunlight into your prison room with a spoon. Now imagine a mouth appearing in the way of the sunlight and it scolds you.
mnemonics.reading: One day you finally get fed up. You need to know who the mouth of the person who's scolding you is. You stick your spoon out into the sun and the mouth appears, scolding you right on time. You reach out and grab them. But in your hand is a pile of cats (かつ). WHAT KIND OF WORLD IS THIS THAT YOU'RE IN A PRISON WHERE CATS SCOLD YOU?!

mnemonics.meaning: You have a net of thread for catching a turkey. But, it must be spread out and you must arrange it first. The reason you'd use a net made of thread is because it's hard to see. But, it's only that way when you spread out the net. It's important to spread out and arrange your net otherwise the turkey will see it.
mnemonics.reading: You spread out your net and arrange it just so. You expect it to catch a turkey, but instead you catch the ancient Egyptian god Ra (ら). "Let me out of this net!" says Ra. "You arranged and spread it out just right so I couldn't see it!"

mnemonics.meaning: You have to put flowers in a bright place if you want them to sprout. If they're left in the shade they'll just rot. Picture your flowers sprouting out of the ground in the bright spring sun.
mnemonics.reading: You want to grow these sprouts in your home (ほう), not outside. So you need to find the windows in your house that are the brightest. Take a walk around your home right now. Can you find the best place to sprout flowers? Remember, it has to be nice and bright! Not dark and damp. Don't put them in your closet.

mnemonics.meaning: A tree melts into the ground after listening to loud music in the hot sun, so you have to find a nice big tank to scoop the melted tree into. The music made the tree vibrate at juuust the right frequency that it, combined with the hot sun, made the tree turn into a puddle. You can't just leave it being all blobby on the ground, so you find a tank for it. Imagine scooping a melted tree into a tank. It's a very strange sensation.
mnemonics.reading: You're staring at the big tank when an eerie sound comes out, "Oooh I am the soul (そう) of the tree! You've trapped me in this tank and now I'm going to haunt it!" You don't want to be haunted by a tank with a soul stuck in it. "Um, okay?" you reply to the soul, and walk away from the tank. "W-wait! Tanks can't move? Come back, let me haunt you with my tree soul!" It's a good thing there weren't wheels on that tank!

mnemonics.meaning: The amount of dirt you need to get some peace is a two mat area. Two tatami mats, that is. This is a pretty common measurement in Japan, so you should get really familiar with the amount of space that two tatami mats take up together. Picture how big a two mat area is. Lay down and feel the peace this much space brings to you.
mnemonics.reading: A two mat area also happens to be big enough to hold two bodies (つぼ). That's enough space to bring peace to two living, or dead, bodies! Try to picture a two mat area with two bodies laying in it. Whether they're alive or dead is up to you.

mnemonics.meaning: Riding a scooter to the library is a universal experience. People young and old have all, at some point, taken a scooter to the library, picked up a book, used the internet, sat in the comfy chairs, then left via that same scooter. Scooters and libraries are universally loved by all!
mnemonics.reading: Riding a scooter to the library is so universal, even hens (へん) do it.  The next time you scoot to the library look around. There are little hen scooters and hens there with their chicks. They're reading them books about grains and how to hatch eggs. It's a universally adorable thing to see.

mnemonics.meaning: The machine in your body that is powered by the moon is your womb, also called your uterus! Haven't you ever wondered why periods happen with the revolutions of the moon? That's because it powers your uterus and tells it what to do! The next time you're cursing your uterus for making you bleed, curse the moon instead! It's the moon's fault you're in pain.
mnemonics.reading: It kind of sucks, but there is no way to sever this uterus - moon tie (たい). But if you find a way please tell me, I can't take this anymore. Picture an invisible tie tieing your uterus to the moon. Damn you moon, stop pulling, it hurts!

mnemonics.meaning: A and B make A and B!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どちらも甲乙つけがたい出来栄えだ。
It’s hard to say which result is better.

mnemonics.meaning: If you degenerate a womb and there was a fetus in there, it's called an abortion, or feticide.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女が堕胎を拒んでいるみたいよ。
It looks like she refused an abortion.

mnemonics.meaning: The salary you get each year is an annual salary.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.

sentences: この選手は、破格の年俸をオファーされましたが、それを蹴ってチームに留まりました。
This player was offered an extraordinary annual salary, but he rejected it and stayed with his team.

mnemonics.meaning: Which of your guts is blind? Your appendix. That's why so many people have to get them out. It's in there blind, bumping around, messing things up.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 手術で盲腸を取ってしまいました。
My appendix had to be surgically removed.

mnemonics.meaning: Flatten out your equilibrium and you'll have perfect balance.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は突然体の平衡を失い、ひっくり返った。
She suddenly lost her balance and toppled over.

mnemonics.meaning: The tank you bathe in is a bathtub. Unless you're bathing in like... the town's water supply. If you are, please stop. I don't want to drink your bathwater.

mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 少女の顔が赤くなり、鼓動が高鳴りました。

mnemonics.meaning: A man in a leather jacket scolds you and is using fear tactics to get paid. He's blackmailing you! That's illegal. Come to think of it, he's probably a member of the yakuza. You should move.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 不倫をダシにヤクザに恐喝されています。
The yakuza is using my adultery to blackmail me.

mnemonics.meaning: Blind eyes will mean you suffer from blindness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私達は、盲目の犬を飼っているんです。
We have a blind dog.

mnemonics.meaning: A blind person is a blind person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その家には、生まれつき盲人の男が住んでいます。

sentences: 犯人は捜査の盲点を突いてきた。
The criminal hit a blind spot in the investigation.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a daring nature you'll boldly go where no one else has gone before! Note that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective!

sentences: あの男は、まるで自分の意志で敢然と難局に立ち向かっているつもりなのよ。
That man plans to boldly oppose the difficult situation with nothing but his own determination.

mnemonics.meaning: You have courage and daring! You're a brave and heroic hero of old. A samurai perhaps?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お前の父さんは、とても勇敢な戦士だったよ。
Your father was a very brave soldier.

mnemonics.meaning: Beer can only become brewed if you decide to brew it. Beer can't make itself, you know.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ここで酒を醸成しているんですね。
They brew sake here.

mnemonics.meaning: Create a brew of beer by brewing it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: スコッチの醸造所を見学してきました。
I toured the scotch distillery.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to look at and give a quick inspection of some stuff then you're just browsing. You don't want to buy yet, you just have to give a look.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このウェブサイトには閲覧規制がかかっています。
There are browsing restrictions on this website.

mnemonics.meaning: If you examine something too closely during your inspection you'll probably find a flaw and want to censor it. Put little black bars over all the flaws you find as you stare.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この国ではネット検閲が行われています。
Internet censorship is practiced in this country.

mnemonics.meaning: A ravine in the water connecting two seas is a channel or a strait.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このフェリーで海峡を渡ります。
We’ll cross the channel in this ferry.

mnemonics.meaning: You already know that 循環 means "circulation," so adding container makes it what holds things that circulate. They're your circulatory organs. They contain all the blood moving throughout your body like a container.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 当院には、循環器専門医が五人います。
There are five circulatory organ specialists in this hospital.

mnemonics.meaning: I want you to try to bear this truth and that's these kanji make up the word clownfish! Do you think a clownfish is this bear? I'm telling the truth! Maybe.
mnemonics.reading: This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for all the kanji. You haven't learned these readings for 之 or 実 yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you get too close to a clownfish, it will hide inside its stinging anemone and shout, "YOU DON'T KNOW ME (のみ)! It's true, you don't know this clownfish, but you want to. I guess all of them are afraid of strangers though... how will you know me if you don't give me a chance, clownfish?!

sentences: ニモやその家族は、隠熊之実という魚だよ。
Nemo and his family are fish called clownfish.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're only blind to color then you have color blindness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 色盲って治るんですか。
Can color-blindness be cured?

mnemonics.meaning: Spread out a needle in a tray of water after rubbing it with a magnet and you'll have made a compass! Try it at home kids! It really works!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は私にとって、人生の羅針盤だったのです。
He was my life’s compass.

mnemonics.meaning: Accept a child into your womb with conception. Now there's a baby in there!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: エレインという馬が、ステイゴールドの最後の子を受胎しました。
A horse named Elaine conceived Stay Gold's last child.

mnemonics.meaning: Express your unique idea of condolence by offering your condolences and sympathy to people who are going through hard times.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 弔意を表して花を贈りました。
I sent flowers to express my condolences.

mnemonics.meaning: Membranes that wrap around at an angle are in your eye. Eyes are round and the membranes have to bend around the front part at an angle. It's called your cornea.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: レーシック手術では、角膜をレーザーで削るんですよ。
In Lasik surgery your cornea is shaved with a laser.

mnemonics.meaning: Fall into the life of a degenerate and you'll probably get involved in lots of corruption. Stealing, stabbing, money laundering, that kind of stuff.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 兄は酒と女に溺れ、敢然に堕落した生活を送っています。
My brother nearly drowns in women and alcohol, and is buried in his horribly corrupted life.

mnemonics.meaning: If you spread out some netting enough you'll be covering everything. But you can only do that if you spread it out really far.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの男はたった一ヶ月で、ここでの業務を網羅した。
That man covered all the tasks here in just one month.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 烏がゴミをあさるんですよ。
Crows pick through garbage.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the adverb version of the kanji daring, so it means dare to or daringly.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're about to daringly jump off a cliff and you shout, "AAAHHH (あ)!" to get your courage up! You always have to yell AAHH before you dare to do daring things!

sentences: あなただからこそ、敢えて厳しいことを言わせてもらったんだよ。
I only dared to say something so intense because it was to you.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a thick drop of dark blue paint on a canvas and it will look like an even bolder dark blue.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 黒と濃紺のスーツが一着ずつあると便利ですよ。
Having one black and one dark blue suit is convenient.

mnemonics.meaning: You use your daring and just go! You made a decisive action by just going like that! It was go or not go and you chose go!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 本当にこの作戦を敢行するつもりですか。
Do you really intend to carry out this strategy?

mnemonics.meaning: A fat drum is still a drum. This word can be used for any type of drum, but a common one in Japan is the taiko. There are lots of different types of taiko, and most of them are big and fat, and make a lovely deep sound. They're super cool to watch and play! If talking about taiko drums specifically, you can also say 和太鼓 to be clear that you're not talking about any old drums.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの子供は太鼓で遊ぶのが好きです。
My children like to play with drums.
お腹がパンパンで太鼓みたいになっています。
My stomach is so full that it looks like a drum.
「太鼓の達人」っていうゲームにハマってるんだ。
I'm really into a game called "Taiko Master."

mnemonics.meaning: You can hear something beat because of a membrane in your ear called an eardrum. Make sure you don't stick your fingers too far in your ear or you could really hurt it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そんなに大声を出されたら鼓膜が破れるよ。
If you play things that loudly you’ll tear your eardrums.

mnemonics.meaning: A child that's still in a womb is a fetus.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: エコーで胎児が足を伸ばしたり縮めたりするところが見れました。
I was able to see the fetus stretch and shrink on the echo.

mnemonics.meaning: Spread out a complete row of numbers in the right order and you have enumeration!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 一見すると意味不明な文字の羅列のように見える。
At first glance, it just looks like a random list of words.

mnemonics.meaning: The one element you need to ferment something is an enzyme. That breaks whatever you're trying to ferment down in just the right way.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今若い女の子の間では、酵素ダイエットが流行っています。
Enzyme diets are popular among young women right now.

mnemonics.meaning: Equal out your equilibrium and you'll have solid equilibrium.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 不倫でバランスをとって、なんとか心の均衡を保っているんです。
I’m having an affair to keep my balance and my calm.

mnemonics.meaning: When you ferment something it makes a departure from what it originally was and transforms during fermentation into something new.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ワインの甘みを残して発酵を止める方法を教えてください。
Please teach me how to keep the sweetness in wine and stop fermentation.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're involved in a daring struggle you need to be strong and fight bravely. Even if you might get hurt, you should do your best!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 優勝候補を相手に、よく敢闘したと思います。
I think I fought pretty bravely against a favorite for the championship.

mnemonics.meaning: A tank of water can be used as a fish tank or a water tank for drinking. It really only depends on you and how many fish you have.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どのくらい頻繁に水槽の掃除をしますか。

mnemonics.meaning: A sprout that sprouts can thank germination for being able to sprout nice and big and strong.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 芽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When a plant sprouts out of the ground it's still a baby so all it can say is goo goo ga ga (が).

sentences: あなたの役目は、二人の恋の萌芽を絶つことよ。
Your duty is to suppress the germination of love between people.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, but wait! It's not an adjective, it's just a noun (tricky, tricky). The kanji means grief, so this word means grief or distress.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 憂える. Remember that and you'll remember this!

sentences: 彼女は、憂いを帯びた顔でこちらを見ていた。
She looked this way with a sorrowful expression on her face.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 腸の働きをよくする運動をご紹介します。
I will introduce exercises that improve bowel movements.

mnemonics.meaning: What do you hit to make a sick beat? A cool little hand drum.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You like to use your hand drum when two dudes meet (つづみ). You drum and tap it and it as they high five and it makes them super uncomfortable which makes you super happy. That's why you love your hand drum so much.

sentences: あの女性の鼓の打ち方は絶品だ。
The way that woman hit her hand drum was superb.
彼女は、袋の中に鼓を大切そうにしまった。
She put away the hand drum carefully in the bag.
そんな可愛い鼓、見たことないよ。もしかして、手作り？
I've never seen such a cute tsuzumi. Did you make it, by any chance?

mnemonics.meaning: What's universal? How many times do you think that question's been asked throughout time? Probably a lot of times.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because へん becomes べん here.

sentences: この映画は何遍みても泣けます。
No matter how many times I see this movie, I always cry.

mnemonics.meaning: The beat makes you want to dance. It's the inspiration you need to dance. The beat gives you encouragement to dance all night long. And without such a rockin' beat you would have lame dance moves.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの監督は、選手たちの士気を鼓舞するのがうまい。

mnemonics.meaning: If you intercept trade and cut off a country from the rest of the world they'll be stuck in a state of isolation or if they have some kind of disease like zombie-itus, it's a quarantine.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: サイトへのアクセスが遮断されました。

mnemonics.meaning: The big intestines are called the large intestine, or the colon. It's where your poop goes and comes from!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大腸がんが見つかりました。
They found large intestine cancer.

mnemonics.meaning: Press uneven carvings into paper to make the newest edition of your magazine. What you're using is a letterpress. This made mass printing nice and cheap(ish) in Japan!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because はん becomes ぱん here.

sentences: 我が社では、特殊な技術を用いて、樹脂凸版の直接製版を格安で行っています。
At our company we use special techniques to cheaply do resin relief printing and direct plate making.

mnemonics.meaning: Fell trees and gather them up. That's called lumbering. Or if you cut them all down and take every last one, it's deforestation and you should be ashamed!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 森林を伐採する際は、事前に届け出が必要です。
Notification is necessary before felling a forest.

mnemonics.meaning: If you can dedicate yourself to going to a bunch of meetings and dealing with everyone's problems you'll make a good magistrate.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned either of these readings yet. Sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you: The magistrate is the only person who's allowed to drink booze and eat gyoza (ぶぎょう). If you see someone simultaneously drinking booze and eating dumplings in Japan, you'll know that person is the magistrate!

sentences: 大岡忠相は、若くして江戸町奉行に昇進した。
Tadasuke Ooka was promoted to magistrate at a young age.
この羅針盤をあそこの奉行所に届けてくれないか？
Can you take this compass to the shogunate administrator's office over there?
鍋の時はいつも彼氏が鍋奉行してくれるんで、楽なんですよ。
When we have nabe, my boyfriend always takes charge of the nabe, so it's easy for me.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 楓の葉も色づいてきました。
The maple leaves started to change color too.

mnemonics.meaning: Maple sugar is maple sugar!
mnemonics.reading: This word is more often read as ふうとう. You can figure out the reading by looking at the 風 portion of the kanji, remember its reading, and apply it here (ふう).

sentences: 料理には砂糖の代わりに楓糖を使うことが多いです。
I often use maple sugar instead of sugar in my cooking.

mnemonics.meaning: If you follow the law of rotation while you play music you'll end up with a lovely melody. If you don't, you'll miss all the cues on beat that rotation gives you and it will sound like crap.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの家からは、いつも美しいピアノの旋律が聞こえていました。
I could always hear the melody of a beautiful piano from that house.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 牛乳を温めると薄い膜が張ることがあります。
A thin film forms when I warm milk.

mnemonics.meaning: When someone quits living you need to offer your condolences during their memorial address. Let it all out and tell everyone what you thought about that dead guy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 誰が弔辞を読むのですか。
Who will read the funeral address?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 少女の白い肌に、紺のワンピースがよく似合っていた。
The navy blue dress suits that young lady’s fair skin.

mnemonics.meaning: One universal event can only happen once. It's too rare to happen more than that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because へん becomes ぺん here.

sentences: 一遍だけでいいから、キャビアを食べてみたかったの。
I wanted to eat caviar but one time was enough.

mnemonics.meaning: Imperial tea the color of a crow's feathers can only be the famous, delicious Oolong tea. It came from the imperial people of China to Japan (probably) and there are lots of different variants. But the leaves are all that blackish/grey crow feather color.
mnemonics.reading: This word takes the on'yomi readings except for 龍 which is an exception (sorry). You haven't learned the on'yomi for 烏 yet either, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who loves Oolong tea more than anyone else? Oooo Ron (うーろん) Weasley from Harry Potter. He's British, so of course you'd think he loves tea, but Oolong is his jam. Just picture him and think, oooooh it's Ron, when you drink this kind of tea. And make sure you remember that, because this is also a written in katakana when the kanji isn't used, to type out the long mark ー when you enter your answer.

sentences: 烏龍茶を氷抜きでください。
Oolong tea without ice, please.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're pale white, you're pale, or pallid. This word is usually used to talk about the pallor of someone's face.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You learned those readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 遼太は怒りで顔面蒼白になった。
Ryota's face turned pale with anger.
患者は蒼白な顔をしていて、非常に弱々しく見えました。
The patient's face was pallid and he looked extremely weak.
一晩中起きていた元帥は、まるで幽霊のように蒼白な顔をして朝食の席についた。
The General, who had been awake all night, sat down to breakfast, looking as pale as a ghost.

mnemonics.meaning: Robbers who sail on the high seas are pirates! Arrr!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 航海の途中で海賊に襲われました。
During the voyage they were attacked by pirates.

mnemonics.meaning: Something comes out of a womb and is then put on a tray. It's the afterbirth. Yeah, yeah, eww. Grow up, it's a word you should know.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 出産後、妻の胎盤を食べてみました。
I ate my wife’s placenta after she gave birth.

mnemonics.meaning: A ravine in a valley is still a ravine. It can also be a gorge or a canyon. They're usually really big. Like the Grand Canyon!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 谷 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're going to travel through a huge ravine you have to stay hydrated. The best thing to bring is some taste, cold Coke (こく). Nothing quenches your thirst from sweating through a long, rough ravine like delicious Coke!

sentences: この峡谷に架かる吊橋を渡ったことはありますか？
Have you ever crossed the bridge that spans over this ravine?

mnemonics.meaning: A public building where you welcome VIP guests is a reception hall. Or a guest house if they're staying the night.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は、迎賓館に招待されました。
I was invited to the reception hall.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of frugal? It's regrettable or precious. If you're too frugal to buy something your actions are regrettable later when you realize you wanted that thing. If you're so frugal you only buy one single thing, it's very precious to you.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You made a regrettable decision. You didn't buy that clock you wanted and now it's been discontinued. The salesperson tells you this and all you can say is, "Oh..." (お) really really quietly. How disappointing.

sentences: 惜しい人を亡くしたものだ。
I lost a precious person.

mnemonics.meaning: A daring fruit is very resolute and bold! She's going to go out and be a fruit superhero or scientist or something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は、世界各地で果敢な取材をしていた。
He boldly collected data from all over the world.

mnemonics.meaning: The nerve netting in the back of your eye is made up of membranes called the retina. It's what lets light in to help you see!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 網膜とは、カメラのフィルムに似た、眼の奥の膜のことです。
The retina is a membrane inside your eye that resembles a camera’s film.

mnemonics.meaning: An inspection you make of your homework before school is a revision. Sometimes proofreading will help you find mistakes before you hand it in too. Just make sure you look everything over.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 原稿を校閲してもらえませんか。
Could you revise my manuscript for me?

mnemonics.meaning: It doesn't matter how many times a rotation goes around, it's still a rotation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ガレージで八の字旋回の練習をしてみました。
I practiced a figure eight turn in the garage.

mnemonics.meaning: Your boss says she's going to decrease your salary with a company-wide salary reduction. You should probably start looking for a new job that won't do salary cuts like this.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.

sentences: 会社から、三割の減俸を言い渡されました。
A thirty percent salary cut was announced by the company.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to find some coarse salt just dive in the sea and collect sea salt! The pieces are nice and big and lumpy, so you really taste it when you're cooking.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お風呂に粗塩を入れると体にいいらしいですよ。
