Putting sea salt in baths seems to be good for you.

mnemonics.meaning: If something is the latter, it can't be first, it has to be at least second. This works for lists too. So if you have A through D, it's going to be B. This word is also used as slang for おつかれさま, which is where the thanks meaning comes from. It can also be used as a prefix to mean chic.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: どーも、報告乙です。
Hey, thanks for the report.
合同会社トーフグを甲とし、ワニカニを乙として、甲の業務の委託に関して、次の通り契約を締結する。
We agree with the contract as outlined below with regards to the subcontract of the first company, Tofugu, and the second company, WaniKani.
こうして山頂から生まれ故郷を見渡すのも、また乙なものですねぇ。
It’s very neat to look over my hometown from the top of the mountain.

mnemonics.meaning: Look in the sea and you'll see what looks like a crow moving under the water and it's a thief! It's stealing from all the fish. As it comes closer you see that it isn't a crow, it's a squid. Or a cuttlefish? One or the other.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is completely irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: You call the fish police to arrest that thieving squid, but it jumps into it's eagle car (いか) and makes a swift getaway. In case you didn't know, an eagle car is an eagle moonlighting as a car. The eagle car is zooming up into the sky, so there's no way the fish police can catch it now.

sentences: 烏賊の刺し身が大好物です。
Squid sashimi is my favorite food.
今夜は烏賊の煮物を作ろうと思っています。
I'm thinking about making stewed cuttlefish this evening.

mnemonics.meaning: Intestines and stomach make up the stomach in your body.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 胃腸がそんなに丈夫な方ではありません。
My stomach isn’t very strong.

mnemonics.meaning: The cultivation of a question mark is something that only people called Takuya can do. Imagine a famous Takuya, like actor and singer Kimura Takuya (木村 拓哉 a.k.a. キムタク), or a Takuya you know, cultivating a huge field of question marks. Rows and rows of question marks. I wonder what he's going to do with all those question marks once they're ready to harvest. Other people who must have an abundance of question marks are pro baseball player Kinoshita Takuya (木下 拓哉 a.k.a. キノタク) and actor, model, and K-Pop star Terada Takuya (寺田 拓哉).
mnemonics.reading: You learned both of these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this name on your own.

sentences: 拓哉さんは殊勝な男性です。
Takuya-san is an admirable man.
茜色の空の下で拓哉と瑛斗は抱擁を交わしました。
Takuya and Eito shared a hug under the crimson sky.
タレントの木村拓哉は、日本ではとても有名で、キムタクという愛称で親しまれています。
The celebrity Kimura Takuya is so famous in Japan that everyone calls him by his nickname, Kimutaku.

mnemonics.meaning: A robber who steals is a thief. And still a robber, I guess.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今度こそ盗賊の隠れ家を突き止めてやる。
I’ll find the thief’s hiding place this time.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means brew, so the verb version is to brew or to distill.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to brew up some beer but not the regular boring stuff. You're going to make it from the water in the hump of a camel (かも). Camel beer is definitely not a horrible idea, right?

sentences: アイドルの大胆な発言が物議を醸している。
The idol’s bold statement is giving rise to public criticism.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means healing and the verb version means to heal something, to cure something, and even to quench a thirst, both literally and metaphorically. As you can probably guess, this last use has a poetic feel to it. Like many verbs ending in す, this verb is transitive, meaning it's being done to something. So you can use it when you cure an illness, heal a broken heart, or quench your thirst for adventure!
mnemonics.reading: To heal something it's sometimes necessary to do something いや (gross). Even if you dislike it, even if it's gross, you do it anyway, because you want to heal whatever it is.

sentences: 疲れを癒して、早く回復するために、一週間緑茶を飲んだりお餅を食べたりしました。
To cure my fatigue and recover quickly, I drank green tea and ate mochi for a week.
莉子ちゃんの優しい笑顔に癒された。
I was healed by Riko-chan's kind smile.
諒一郎は読書によって知識への渇きを癒すことができた。
Ryoichiro quenched his thirst for knowledge through reading.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means intercept, so the verb version is to intercept or to interrupt.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you want to interrupt and to intercept is your roommate's sighing guitar (さえぎ). He keeps playing it and all it does is make these horrible, long sighing sounds. You want to interrupt it any cost.

sentences: 人の話を遮るのは失礼です。
It’s rude to interrupt a person.

meanings: to hold a memorial service for

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means condolence, so the verb version is to mourn for or to condole.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You seem to mourn for things you really care about. Well then you would mourn for your toe mural (とむら). You had a mural made for your favorite toe so if anything were to happen to it, you would want to mourn for it.

sentences: ここには、殉職者の魂を弔う石碑が建てられています。
We’re building a stone memorial for the souls of soldiers who died in battle.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 鎮める means "to appease," but this one is what happens after they've been appeased. They start to quiet down.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you're in the library the librarian is always telling you to quiet down. She's (しず) so mean! She never lets you talk in the library. Who's mean to you? She's mean to you!!

sentences: とりあえず、今は父の怒りが鎮まるのを待ちましょう。
For the time being, let’s wait until dad’s anger has calmed down.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pickle or soak, so the verb version is to pickle or to soak.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You learned this reading with the kanji. Good for you!

sentences: こうやって醤油に漬けて食べてください。
Please eat it dipped in soy sauce like this.

mnemonics.meaning: See the continuation of universal trends with travels around the world. If you want to see and understand everyone on this planet you have to make a pilgrimage to see it all for yourself.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その浪人は、諸国を遍歴することにした。
That masterless samurai has decided to travel around various countries.
過去の男性遍歴を語ってくる女ってマジでうざいよな。
Don’t you think a woman who talks about her history with men is super annoying?

mnemonics.meaning: Fell trees in intervals, instead of all at once, and it's called tree thinning. That way there's still some forest there, but you get your wood to use for other things too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 間伐を行うことで、残った木は幹が太く枝葉がしっかりとした健全な木に育ちます。
Periodic thinning of forests makes the rest of trees grow thick trunks and tough, healthy branches and leaves.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: この土地は何坪ぐらいですか？
How many tsubo is this land?

mnemonics.meaning: A surface covered in convex and concave parts is going to be really uneven and rough.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 凹凸のはっきりした顔立ちですね。
It has distinctly uneven features, doesn’t it?

mnemonics.meaning: Something normal and universal is still universal. Normally.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 普遍的なテーマは、多くの人に受け入れられやすい。
Universal themes are easily accepted by many people.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 愉快 means "pleasant" or "happy," so add not to that and you're unpleasant and unhappy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このビデオは、見ていて不愉快です。
I watched that video and it was unpleasant.

mnemonics.meaning: You already know that 循環 means "circulation" or "cycle," so adding bad to that makes it a vicious cycle.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: まずは、あなたの心の悪循環を断ち切ることが大切です。
First of all, it’s important to cut off the vicious cycle in your heart.

mnemonics.meaning: You're only nearby while you are nearby, that's it.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: While you live as a normal human citizen you also have another life as a cutter walrus (かたわ)! That's a walrus that cuts fish up while eating. It's your secret double life. You do it at night while you are a human by day!

sentences: 新聞局で働く傍ら、夜間学校に通っています。
While working at the newspaper office, I’ve been attending night classes.

mnemonics.meaning: A rotation of wind forms a whirlwind, in both the physical and figurative senses. On the figurative side, it can also mean commotion and sensation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because ふう becomes ぷう here (hehe).

sentences: 海賊達の目の前で、旋風は嵐へと変わっていった。
The whirlwind changed to a storm right in front of the pirates.
この国では、『銀河旋風ブライガー』というアニメが若者達の間に大旋風を巻き起こしています。
In this country, an anime called "Galaxy Cyclone Braiger" has created a great sensation among young people.
トーフグは、日本語学習業界に旋風を巻き起こしています。
Tofugu is creating a whirlwind in the Japanese learning industry.

mnemonics.meaning: The mother of good fermentation is yeast! If you want to bake a pie or bread you have to have the best. And if you don't have any, maybe your neighbor has some extra that you can borrow?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 自作酵母を使ってパンを作っています。
I’m using my own yeast to make bread.

mnemonics.meaning: The building clown is the only clown allowed to accompany you. You hate all clowns, and so does the rest of your town. But this clown is really good at building buildings, and he's allowed to leave his part of town and accompany you while you fix buildings together. I know it's been a long time, but try not to mix this one up with 	部, if you can. Remember, the clown building is in another part of town and the clowns aren't supposed to leave. But the building clown is okay to accompany you through the rest of the city.
mnemonics.reading: He can only accompany you for so long though and soon it's time to say bye (ばい) again. Wave bye to the clown, he'll accompany you on your building job tomorrow, but right now he has to go home and be with the rest of his clown people. He can't accompany you after dark.

mnemonics.meaning: Put your fingers on your husband to aid him. There's something about a spouse's touch that just makes you feel better. Have you ever had someone rub your back while you were hurt or sick or sad? It's nice, right? Imagine rubbing your husband's back with your fingers to aid him. You want him to feel better. You want him to get that comforting feeling that this kind of touching gives.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, your husband wouldn't need your aid if he wasn't such a fool (ふ). He walks into doors, he falls down the stairs, he touches the plate when the waiter says it's hot. And every single time your fool husband hurts himself, you aid him. That's true love, my friend.

mnemonics.meaning: When your scooter has a fault, you need to get an alternate. Hopefully your insurance will cover it too. You have a scooter that you drive every single day, but if you notice a fault, you need to send it in to get it fixed. That's when you break out your alternate scooter.
mnemonics.reading: The alternate scooter is made entirely of 鉄 (てつ). It's hard and cold and not very comfortable when you sit on it. That's why you chose to keep it as an alternate and not as your everyday scooter. Imagine riding on your alternate 鉄 scooter. Feel the hard iron under your bum and the loud sounds it makes as you scoot down the street. I hope your normal scooter is fixed soon.

mnemonics.meaning: Your husband was wearing his cleats when he accidentally stepped on a bird. Luckily this particular bird is a chicken, and chickens are really durable! Picture the sad, stepped on chicken. It's angrily clucking and chasing your husband around your yard for what he did.
mnemonics.reading: The only way to stop the chicken from putting on your husband's cleats and stepping on him to death in revenge is to feed it the cake (けい) you were making. This cake was for your husband, but now he gets nothing. The chicken gets to eat all of the cake in front of him instead.

mnemonics.meaning: The king raked all the mountains down into flat land so he could see everyone in the kingdom from his castle windows. You should share your congratulations with him. Now, quick tell him this was a great idea. Imagine saying "Congratulations!" to a king who just ordered his servants to rake down all the pretty mountains in his kingdom.
mnemonics.reading: The moment you say "Congratulations!" you've already started to miss (みず) those beautiful mountains. But you can't let missing them ruin your congratulations! Don't let the king know! Imagine how hollow your congratulation sounds when you really miss those mountains. This king doesn't deserve your nice words.

mnemonics.meaning: Gamblers usually only see the sun at dawn. They gamble all day and through the night, and if they leave it's at the crack of dawn to get home, clean up, and then go back. I haven't known a gambler who's seen the sun ... well ever! Imagine being a gambler and seeing the bright dawn sun when you come out of the casino or pachinko parlor. It burns your eyes! Evil dawn, get back inside quick!
mnemonics.reading: If you're up at dawn you'll also see the あか (red) つき (moon). The あかつき only happens as the sun comes up at dawn so usually only gamblers see it. But if you get up early, you can see it too! Imagine getting up at dawn and seeing the あかつき in the sky near the sun. It's so beautiful!

mnemonics.meaning: A clown takes a knife and divides himself. First he divides himself into two pieces, then he's in four pieces, then... oh why won't he stop?! Instead of dying, the clown divides into slightly thinner clowns.
mnemonics.reading: The clown finally stops trying to divide himself, and you can't stand to look at all of him. You grab a bowling (ぼう) ball and bowl all of his divided parts over! The many clowns crash to the floor as the bowling ball plows through their... his(?) divided bodies. You can't bear to look anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: If you touch ice for too long you'll get frostbite and that's a really hard thing to endure. A lot of people can't, and die. Then again, you managed to endure touching ice long enough to get frostbite in the first place, so maybe this is baby stuff for you. Imagine having to endure the pain of frostbite because you were a jerk who put his hand on ice for a few hours.
mnemonics.reading: The best people in the world at being able to endure the pain are the shinobi (しの) ninjas! They train by hanging out in frozen areas all the time and don't complain at all. Maybe if the pain gets to be too much you can go ask them for advice. Imagine if you were one of these cool Shinobi ninjas that could endure the extreme cold and pain of frostbite!

mnemonics.meaning: You have to reach a certain number of flowers and tsunamis hits to become a legitimate fiefdom. At least in the old days. If you don't meet one of these conditions, like if you get hit by tsunamis all the time but you only have two or three flowers that will grow, you can't be your own fiefdom. Imagine being the person who has to check whether each fiefdom has enough flowers and tsunamis per year to keep their status.
mnemonics.reading: The most famous fiefdom checker is Han (はん) Solo. He takes his Millennium Falcon and swoops around checking for flowers and signs of past tsunamis and then he'll either say you can or cannot be your own fiefdom. Thanks Han Solo! Picture Han Solo flying around Japan checking to make sure all the fiefdoms are up to code.

mnemonics.meaning: If you say the lineup of your family members that have lived on this earth under the sun, you're really explaining your genealogy. This kanji has a second meaning too. It means score, as in a musical score or sheet music. So if your sheet music says the line up of chords, especially sunnny notes, that's the score of a song. Those sunny notes are loved by your ancestors. Say the line up of your family under the sun, then sing some sunny chords to match. You'll know your genealogy and a musical score!
mnemonics.reading: If you can't tell the difference between your genealogy and a musical score, you're a fool (ふ) and I can't help you. You aren't a fool, are you? You know the difference. Your family genealogy and a musical score aren't even close to being the same thing. Memorize these or everyone will think you're a fool.

mnemonics.meaning: The king wants you to make a rocket that looks glassy. It won't be very stable, and it probably won't work, but making it glassy and pretty is the only way to make the king approve. Imagine a king who won't accept a rocket that isn't made of glassy material. He's not very smart...
mnemonics.reading: You take the glassy rocket and try to stuff some thin reeds (り) inside to support it. But because it's clear and glassy the king sees them at the last second. Picture the king admiring himself in the glassy surface and then his face contorts. He smashes his fist through the rocket and rips out the reeds. "REEDS AREN'T GLASSY!" he cries, and starts hitting you with them.

mnemonics.meaning: You can only manage to avoid a tsunami by standing above it on a small stool if you are very graceful. If you aren't graceful enough the tsunami will knock you and the stool over and you'll be swept away like everyone else. Imagine being graceful enough to balance on a small stool above a raging tsunami! Sooo cool!
mnemonics.reading: No matter how graceful you are, the still tsunami shook (しゅく) the small stool. That's where your gracefulness came in. The stool shook, but you didn't. You balanced yourself and refused to go down.  It doesn't matter how badly the stool shook, you stayed graceful and didn't fall!

mnemonics.meaning: The leader does a dance on top of the tree to show his greatness to everyone around. If he dances all the way up there on top of the tree, then no one can deny his excellence! "Look upon your leader's greatness!" he shouts, doing a jig around on the branches.
mnemonics.reading: If you don't recognize the leader's greatness he will throw ketsup (けつ) all over you (it's a special mix of ketchup and catsup). And it's ketsup because it looks like blood. The blood he'll spill if you don't look up and clap at his great dancing. "Oh leader, your greatness is so... great!" you shout up at him. He's holding the ketsup bottle over your head and staring into your eyes as he dances in the tree. He isn't sure if he wants to dump it on you yet. He isn't sure if you really recognize his excellence.

mnemonics.meaning: A samurai puts his forehead on the table next to his weapon. He is just a husk of his former self. This shell of a samurai has nothing left. He's just sitting there, he can't even pick up his weapon or raise his head anymore.
mnemonics.reading: The only way to bring a husk of a samurai back to life is to have a cock (かく) crow right in his ear. "Co co co co cooooock!" the cock screams, shocking the samurai back into his lifeless shell. You did it!

mnemonics.meaning: This is a gold roof, correct? It's important to lock it up, then. It's only natural that you'd want to lock a gold roof so nobody can steal it.
mnemonics.reading: The person who locked the gold roof was Jourm (じょう). He's the big farmhand who turned out to be an undercover Viking in your town, only to pillage and destroy everything. Under the gold roof is where he locked up all your village's valuables, after wiping you all out.

mnemonics.meaning: A sweet woman sits under a tree and works as a mediator. If you're having a fight with someone, bring them to the sweet woman under the tree and she'll mediate for the two of you. Problem solved! Thanks sweet lady! Imagine the sweet tree woman being a mediator for you and your arch rival. What she says fixes everything between you two!
mnemonics.reading: You go to pay the woman for being your mediator for you two but she just says, "Bye ばい)." You try to hand her some money and she stares into your eyes. "Bye." Oh... okay, bye then. Imagine her refusing to let you pay her for her mediator services and just saying "bye" over and over until you leave. Weird.

mnemonics.meaning: If a tsunami gets into a net that's imprisoning a bunch of insects, the insects are going to get all muddy. The net gets dragged along with the tsunami water and the insects can't escape, so they just get covered in the yucky stuff. Picture a net prison full of insects being dragged by a tsunami getting muddier and muddier. Poor buggles!
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately for the insects, these muddy conditions have created the perfect habitat for ducks (だく). And muddy insects already imprisoned in a muddy net is a duck's favorite treat! Picture a bunch of muddy ducks munching on some muddy trapped insects, in a some muddy leftover tsunami water.

mnemonics.meaning: The only tree a turkey will live in is an oak tree. They really only do this because oak trees have really yummy acorns and turkeys loooove acorns. Imagine seeing a turkey sitting in an oak tree munching on acorns. You didn't even know turkeys could fly, but it got up there somehow.
mnemonics.reading: If you see a bunch of oaks but no turkeys just yell, "TWEET (つい)!" and they'll all come jumping out! Just because you can't see a turkey in there doesn't mean there isn't one! Imagine standing in a grove of oak trees and yelling TWEET! TWEET! Now watch as hundreds of turkeys come flying at your face! They think you have more acorns for them. RUN!

mnemonics.meaning: If you spill something red on yourself in winter you should pardon yourself immediately and try to find something else to wear. It's very dangerous to wear red in winter, and even if it seems rude, make sure you pardon yourself right away and get that taken care of! Imagine spilling red wine or red paint down your shirt. Quickly pardon yourself and get changed now!
mnemonics.reading: If you don't pardon yourself fast enough the winter shaman (しゃ) will burst in and cast a spell on you, taking away all the clothes that have red on them! Now you have to pardon yourself for being naked! Imagine not pardoning yourself fast enough and having the winter shaman spirit away whatever you got red on. That's embarrassing.

mnemonics.meaning: Throw a drunkard in a cage with a tiger and some spikes and the tiger will have the time of its life playing with them! Think of all the tiger play time possibilities!  If you were the tiger how would you play with the drunkard?
mnemonics.reading: If you aren't the tiger, watching it play is a little like watching someone's head get cut off with a guillotine (ぎ). In fact, you don't want to watch it play at all anymore. What would you rather watch? A guillotine at work or a tiger playing like this?

mnemonics.meaning: If someone gives you a sock you should receive it and thank them. You can't just say no or put the sock on the ground and walk away. You should always receive a sock properly, with both hands, when it's handed to you. Imagine Dobby reaching out to receive his first sock. Don't you want to be happy like that too?
mnemonics.reading: The best place to receive a sock is in きょうと. They're famous for their sock stores and schoolgirls who have too many socks. If you walk down the street someone is bound to try to hand you a sock in きょうと, and you should receive it happily. Imagine standing in きょうと and receiving sock after sock. People just keep giving and you keep receiving!

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to take a flag out of the mouth of a mantis you have to make a formal request first. Mantises don't like to just give things away, and they're kind of mean so if you try to steal the flag it will probably bite you. So make a formal, polite request if you want it. Imagine trying to request a flag from a scary mantis that has it sitting in it's mouth. Will it give it to you? Will it bite you? You'll have to wait and see.
mnemonics.reading: After you request the mantis give you its flag it shocks (しょく) you by actually spitting it out of its mouth at your feet. You didn't think your request would work, or even if the mantis understood human speech, but it shocked you by doing exactly what you asked! Imagine your shock at finding out the mantis not only understood your request, but agreed! This is great but also makes you wonder what other creatures can understand you...

mnemonics.meaning: You see a triceratops standing in front of a full moon and you can't help but see a really strong resemblance. The triceratops has that round frill thing behind its horns and it looks just like the round full moon. Who knew that a triceratops would resemble the moon! Look at the triceratops. Now look at the moon. See the resemblance? Uncanny, don't you think?
mnemonics.reading: The first person to see this resemblance was the Shougun (しょう). That's why he decided to put a triceratops head with the moon behind it on his mon (family crest). Now he's known as the full moon dinosaur shogun, and he's very famous. Imagine being the Shougun and seeing the resemblance between a triceratops and the moon for the first time. You'd put that on all your stuff too, if you were him.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a soul on a cross covered in flowers with shellfish at its feet and you suddenly resent them. It's not like you want to be the one up there on the cross, but so many people left flowers and shellfish for them. It should have been you... Picture the soul on the cross, flowers all around it and shellfish at its feet. Feel your resentment grow.
mnemonics.reading: You realize you resent them because it looks like they're having fun (ふん). You aren't having fun, and you wanna be! How dare they have fun when you aren't! You wanna have fun hanging out on a cross with flowers and all the shellfish you can eat. Your resentment grows and grows as you watch the soul having everything you suddenly want.

mnemonics.meaning: A tree is stuck in a prison under the ground and it's starting to rot and decay. Trees can't live without sunlight, and it's too damp underground in a prison. The water gets all moldy and the tree will rot and die.
mnemonics.reading: You get close to the rotting tree and see some rotten cucumbers (きゅう) hanging from its branches. No! This poor cucumber tree, left in this ground prison to rot. There's nothing worse than eating a rotten cucumber.

mnemonics.meaning: You're walking down the street when you see twenty big crosses lined up in front of you. Crosses creep you out and this is way too many for you to keep walking so you decide to run as fast as you can to get past them. Imagine trying to run down a street with twenty big crosses lining it. It's so scary that you keep running faster and faster as you go.
mnemonics.reading: You figure since you're already on the run that you might as well hone (ほん) your running skills while you make your way down this scary, cross lined street.  Imagine distracting yourself from the scary crosses by honing your running skills while you do it.

mnemonics.meaning: You hoist your towel above your table, drop into the water and sail away. You turned the towel into an actual sail and you're balancing on top of the table, which is now a boat. Imagine sailing out into the open sea, drops of water hitting your face, as the towel sail catches the air and carries you away.
mnemonics.reading: As you sail off into the ocean you hear a familiar voice shout out, "Ahoy!" Han (はん) Solo calls. He's also got a towel sail, but it's on the Millennium Falcon, which is half-submerged in the water. You sail nervously past Han Solo who also seems to be sailing, though in worse shape than you. But he keeps throwing you finger guns so you figure it's best to just sail on and pretend this never happened.

mnemonics.meaning: The flowers that grow on your roof that look like a sleeping bear is sedge. Sedge grow all over the world! You've probably seen them before, you just didn't know what they were called! Looks like a green sleeping bear bum, right?
mnemonics.reading: The next time you see a sedge bite into it. It tastes like sugar (すが)! Luckily, it don't taste like bear. Imagine biting into a sedge flower and tasting the yummy sugary taste. Mmmm.

mnemonics.meaning: Pour all of your alcohol in the pool to serve all your guests at once! They can all help themselves to as much or as little alcohol as they want! What a great idea! Imagine serving all of your guests their alcohol by dumping it all in the pool! Now jump in and drink all you want!
mnemonics.reading: As you serve your guests (and yourself) you look over and see Shaq (しゃく) also trying to serve them. And by serving I mean getting served because he's throwing them into the pool.  Picture Shaq serving your guests by tossing them into your alcohol filled pool. Thanks, Shaq... I guess.

mnemonics.meaning: Deep in your soul, you feel like you want to pull your fangs out by the root, but instead you let out a loud sigh. You're one of the only people you know that has fangs, and it weighs heavily on your soul. Imagine all of the other people staring and pointing, the kids making fun of you, no one seeing you as equal. And just... sigh. Deep down, you want to get rid of your fangs, but you can't do it.
mnemonics.reading: You sigh again and say, "I wish I was just a normal guy (がい)." I swear the rest of me is a guy like the rest of you. *sigh* Now you're staring in the mirror at yourself. You sigh loudly and take out the pliers. You'll be a guy like everyone else. S-soon. As soon as you can muster up enough strength to stop sighing and rip these fangs out.

mnemonics.meaning: Put thread in the mouth of a worm while the moon is out and it will poop out some silk. That's why they call them silkworms, didn't you know? But it has to be while the moon is out, otherwise normal thread will come right back out the other end of the worm. The moon is what makes the magic happen. Picture feeding some thread into the mouth of a worm as the light from the full moon shines in on you. See the silk come out of the worm's butt and into your hands.
mnemonics.reading: The biggest fan of silk is Ken (けん) the samurai. Everything he wears is silk, even his armor. Picture Ken with a silk helmet, silk fundoshi, and a silk sheath for his sword.

mnemonics.meaning: You see seven swords just sitting in a hole and so you decide to steal them. They were just left in that hole after all, it's not like anyone was using them. And even if they were, they'll never know you were the one to steal them, right? Imagine seeing seven swords just laying abandoned in a hole. Feel the urge to steal them all. Do it, do it!
mnemonics.reading: You steal the swords and realize they aren't just seven random swords, they're from the famous sword sets (せつ) they sell online. This particular set is from the Seven Samurai movie. Yes! What a great steal! Imagine your delight as you look up the different sword sets online and realize you happened to steal the best one!

mnemonics.meaning: There are stones that smell like trash in the river. You reach in and realize these rocks are made of sulfur. Even the flow of this water can't hide the stink of these sulfur rocks. If you haven't smelled sulfur before, it smells a bit like rotten eggs. Something that definitely belongs in the trash.
mnemonics.reading: You throw the sulfur rock as hard as you can, but it hits someone in the back of the head. Oh no, it's Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter. You try to apologize and explain that you just didn't want this stinky trash rock, I mean, sulfur rock near you. You didn't know he was there. Ryu looks down at you, holding the sulfurous rock in one hand. Then he uppercuts you with it! Shoryuken!

mnemonics.meaning: Help and aid someone and you will help and aid them! Good job, you're a good person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ほとんどの学生は、父母の扶助を受けて生活している。
Most students receive support from their parents to live.

mnemonics.meaning: Pardon someone out of the kindness in your heart and you'll have granted them amnesty. How kind of you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大統領は、七面鳥に恩赦を与えた。
The president granted amnesty to the turkey.

mnemonics.meaning: You resent someone so much that you sigh with anger whenever they're around. Everything they do makes you feel really strong resentment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 君の身勝手な言動に憤慨しているんだよ。
I resented your selfish actions.

mnemonics.meaning: Divide a body and untie its organs to perform an autopsy. You have to cut it all up and untangle the parts to see why this person or animal died.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 解剖をしてみないと何とも言えません。
We can't say anything until we perform an autopsy.

mnemonics.meaning: What is lapis lazuli glassy color? It's bright blue. If you've never seen the rock lapis lazuli, look it up and you'll see why this means bright blue!
mnemonics.reading: You learned all three of these readings when you learned the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 莉子は、瑠璃色のワンピースを着て諒一郎との待ち合わせ場所に現れた。
Riko showed up wearing a bright blue dress at the place she was meeting Ryoichiro.
ヒゴタイは、瑠璃色で丸い形をした、とても可愛い花です。
Bright blue and spherical in shape, the higotai is a very pretty flower.
ふと、瑠璃色の美しい宝石のような虫が目にとまった。
Suddenly, a beautiful bright blue insect that looked like a jewel caught my eye.

mnemonics.meaning: A butterfly with another butterfly added to it? It's still a butterfly, just a really big one with... with four wings. And laser eyes? Oh well, just go with it. It's a butterfly.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

sentences: 彼女は蝶々のように自由な女性でした。
She was a woman who was as free as a butterfly.

mnemonics.meaning: If a mediator touches people the right way, they will become a catalyst for change. This could be good or bad change depending on what they stuck their hands in.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: つまり彼は二人にとって触媒のような役割を果たしたということだ。
In other words, he managed to play the role of the catalyst for those two people.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone asks you to alternate what you're doing again, they want you to change. You need to switch it up if you want to make them happy, or they'll just ask you to redo it again.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 監督の更迭が求められている。
We’re looking for a replacement supervisor.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:  A chicken is a 庭 (garden) 鳥 (bird) (にわとり). It's a bird that you keep in your garden, after all!

sentences: 育てたひよこが鶏になりました。
The chick I raised became a chicken.
隣の家で飼っている鶏が毎朝起こしてくれるんですよ。
My neighbor's chickens wake me up every morning.
この鶏は雄鶏で合ってる？
Am I right about this chicken being a rooster?

mnemonics.meaning: A chicken egg is a chicken egg.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 卵 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who loves chicken eggs? Randy (らん) Savage! Especially when he eats them with slim jims. Mmm eggs and slim jims. You should give it a try.

sentences: 鶏卵は日本が自給自足できる唯一の蛋白源です。
Chicken eggs are the only source of protein in Japan that is self sufficient.

mnemonics.meaning: Foster a bunch of chickens and start chicken farming! They will be your best friends! Your only friends.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 養鶏経営の難しさを痛感しました。
I realized how difficult managing poultry raising is.

mnemonics.meaning: Chicken meat is chicken meat!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It also has the more common reading of とりにく. Remember how 鳥 is とり? Chicken meat is technically also just bird meat. You can say that too!

sentences: できるだけ鶏肉のささみを食べるようにしています。
I try to make sure I eat as much white meat from chicken as I can.

mnemonics.meaning: Write down the years of your genealogy in order and it makes a chronological record of your life. Look back on it when you're old and sigh about the old days.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この作家の年譜を作ってくれないか。
Will you make a chronological record for this author?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 暁の冷たい空気に、気持ちが張り詰めた。
I felt frozen in the cold air at dawn.

mnemonics.meaning: Elderly people start to decay and they get all decrepit and gross. Like a corpse. Bleh. Good thing I'll never be too old. Ho ho ho!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その建物はかなり老朽しているので、立ち入らない方がいい。
That building is pretty decrepit so you shouldn’t go in it.

mnemonics.meaning: A play that uses lots of intense, emotional music is a drama.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これは、戯曲を原作としたミュージカルです。
This musical was originally based off a play.

mnemonics.meaning: The energy of being shocked fills your body and leaves you dumbfounded. You're so taken aback by this surge of shock that all you can do is stand still and let the energy go through you.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for one kanji and the on'yomi reading for the other. Just remember that they're the two readings you didn't learn when you learned the kanji and you should be okay.

sentences: 彼女のおかしな言動に、みんな呆気に取られていました。
Everyone was taken aback by the woman’s odd behavior.

mnemonics.meaning: The earth's shell is called the earth's crust. You should have learned that in earth science. And if you didn't, at least you know now!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本列島は、千年に一度の大地殻変動期に突入しています。
The Japanese islands appeared after thousands of years of deformation of the Earth’s crust.

mnemonics.meaning: The best thing to receive and accept into your life is enjoyment! Don't block it out, let it in! Be happy!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 我が社は円安の恩恵をもろに享受しているんだ。
Our company is enjoying the benefits of cheap yen.

mnemonics.meaning: At night you are served an evening drink. It's okay to have a strong drink with dinner every now and then.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ダイエットのために晩酌を控えています。
I’m holding back from evening drinks because of my diet.

mnemonics.meaning: The master of a fiefdom is the feudal lord. We also call them Daimyo.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 藩主の墓に参ってきた。
We went to visit the daimyo’s tomb.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 江戸時代中期には、どこの藩も財政が苦しくなりました。
In the middle of the Edo period, fiefdoms also found financial affairs difficult.

mnemonics.meaning: You give your congratulations to someone a few times because they seem so fresh and vibrant. You feel like you should because it must be nice to be like that still. Someday it will be gone, so make sure you say it a few times right away.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is just the kun'yomi reading (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

sentences: 彼女の瑞々しい歌声が人々を魅了した。
Everyone was fascinated by her vibrant voice.

mnemonics.meaning: You play and play all day! What do you play? A game! Or a sport! Which are technically games!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 園児たちが音楽にあわせて遊戯をしています。
The kindergarteners played along to the music.

mnemonics.meaning: Write down the scores people get from taking all of their opponent's chess pieces and you'll be writing down game records. This is usually only used for old-fashioned Japanese games like go and shogi. Let's see who has the highest score at the end!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 棋譜の付け方を教えてください。
Please teach me how to record a game.

mnemonics.meaning: Your lineage and genealogy make up your genealogy, also known as your family history.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この巻紙に一族の系譜が描かれています。
I’m sketching my family’s genealogy on this roll of paper.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 紳士 means "gentleman?" Well when two men determine that the best thing to do is cooperate they form a gentlemen's agreement.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あいつらとは紳士協定を結んでいるはずだ。
They’re supposed to be tied to a gentlemen’s agreement.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  If you're trying to be graceful and polite you have to keep your secret sheep toe (しと) under wraps. You're kind of fond of your sheep toe (it's unique after all) but you're careful to hide it when you want to be all modest and gentle and all that.

sentences: カナエはとってもお淑やかな性格をしている。
Kanae has a very graceful personality.
母には淑やかさというものが足りない。
My mother lacks gentleness.

mnemonics.meaning: You want to lock this criminal's hands up so he won't go punching anymore grandpas. You need some handcuffs to make sure he doesn't go around being a criminal anymore. Then you can lock him up good.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for one kanji and the on'yomi reading for the other. You know them both, so this shouldn't be too hard to remember!

sentences: 犯人と間違われて手錠を掛けられたんだ。
I was mistaken for a criminal and handcuffed.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 縛る means "to tie?" Well if you tie something around someone's neck then it's called hanging. They'll probably die from it too, so it can also be death by hanging.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the words 縛る and 首. Both use the kun'yomi readings, so just change the る to り and it's pretty simple!

sentences: 江戸時代には縛り首という刑罰があった。
In the Edo period, there was a punishment called death by hanging.

mnemonics.meaning: If you look back in history and see someone of exceptional greatness, they're probably a hero. Not just a normal person, but an extraordinary person like Hercules or Mae Jemison.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本史上、 最強の豪傑は誰だと思いますか。
Who do you think the greatest hero in Japanese history is?

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who's shocked at everything all the time will seem like an idiot. At this point, putting your drinks in a glass shouldn't be surprising. I mean, come on. Only a fool lets himself be shocked by everything he sees.
mnemonics.reading: Remember when you learned 呆ける? Well just cut the る part off the end and it's exactly the same! If you can remember that, you'll remember this reading as well.

sentences: この呆け！ちゃんと前見て歩け。
You, idiot! Look straight ahead and walk.
それは呆けの言うことだ。
That is what a fool would say.

mnemonics.meaning: If it does not rot then it's immortal. It will live forever!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これは不朽の名作です。
This is an eternal masterpiece.

mnemonics.meaning: A mediator jammed in the middle of a group of angry people ends up becoming the intermediary between them. The mediator can't just ignore what's happening around them, and they have the tools to fix this.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 鳥が伝染病の媒介となると仮定しよう。
Let’s assume birds have become an intermediary for infectious diseases.

mnemonics.meaning: If you cleanse a lapis lazuli rock until it goes glassy, you can use it in a joruri performance. In case you haven't heard of joruri, it's traditional Japanese chanted storytelling, sort of like a ballad, that's accompanied by shamisen music, and often puppets.
mnemonics.reading: You learned all these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 江戸時代の娯楽は、浄瑠璃や歌舞伎だった。
Entertainment in the Edo period was joruri and kabuki.
人形浄瑠璃のチケットをもらいました。
I got a ticket for a ningyo joruri performance.
今回は、浄瑠璃人形の作り手にインタビューをしました。
This time, we interviewed a creator of joruri puppets.

mnemonics.meaning: Who is going to accompany the judge in deciding the results of the trial? The jury! They're the only other people besides the judge who can decide someone's fate in court.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本で陪審裁判が導入された経緯を教えてください。
Please teach me everything about the introduction of jury trials in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: A graceful woman is a proper, fancy lady.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 紳士淑女のみなさん 、こんばんは。
Good evening ladies and gentlemen.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: この薬を必ず一日一錠飲んで下さい。
Please take one tablet of this medicine once every day.

mnemonics.meaning: If you serve someone a certain quantity of understanding, you're making allowances. You're taking into consideration all extenuating circumstances.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You learned these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本の裁判には「情状酌量」とよばれるものがあります。
In Japanese trials there is something called "making allowances for extenuating circumstances".
情状酌量の余地はないと思います。
I don't think there's scope to make allowances for extenuating circumstances.
被告人には酌量すべき情状があると判断し、裁判官は刑を減軽した。
Concluding that the defendant's circumstances should be taken into consideration, the judge commuted the sentence.

mnemonics.meaning: Something you make that oozes with greatness is your masterpiece. The very best work you'll ever make in your entire life.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これはピカソの傑作だね。
This is Picasso’s masterpiece.

mnemonics.meaning: A mediator who works with someone who doesn't have a body has to use some kind of mortal media to record what they're saying. Print media? Sure. Electronic media? Alright? Ghost media? No! Humans can't read that stuff!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 紙媒体で仕入れた情報の方が何故か安心するんだよね。
For some reason I feel more comfortable getting information from paper media.

mnemonics.meaning: A muddy stream is a muddy stream!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 濁流に飲み込まれそうになったのを、彼が救ってくれたのです。
He rescued the things that were gulped down by the muddy stream.

mnemonics.meaning: On the surface of a score you'll find music. This is only written music though, so remember that this music has to be on the surface of some paper.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 譜面を無料でダウンロードできるサイトを探しています。
I’m looking for a site where I can download music for free.

mnemonics.meaning: You already know that 弦楽 means "string music," so add some pipes to that, like trumpets and saxophones, and you'll have orchestral music. You can't have a whole orchestra with just the string section!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 子供に管弦楽を習わせたいと思っています。
I want to let the children learn orchestral music.

mnemonics.meaning: Form a pardon with your mouth and actually pardon someone. Show your forgiveness with the words "I'm sorry."
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 罪人は容赦なく罰せられなくてはならない。
The criminal must be punished without mercy!

mnemonics.meaning: An excuse and a pardon is a pardon or amnesty.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は特別に罪の赦免が認められた。
He was granted a special pardon for his crimes.

mnemonics.meaning: A company requests consignment work and you take it to become a part time employee.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの人は、再雇用制度を利用した嘱託社員なんです。
That person is a part-time employee who used the reemployment system.

mnemonics.meaning: You take a dose of medicine but it gets locked in your throat because it's the kind of pill you chew, not swallow! You need to pay attention to which one is which or it won't help at all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 錠剤を飲み込むことができないので、砕いて飲んでいます。
I can’t swallow pills, so I smash and drink them.

mnemonics.meaning: If the air is muddy and dirty it's because there is too much pollution in that area. You should wear a mask and be careful of contamination.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 湖の水質汚濁を防止するために規制が設けられた。
A regulation was established to prevent the pollution of the lake.

mnemonics.meaning: Art that's so good it resembles a statue of a person is actually a portrait. Really, it resembles the original person, but it looks like it's a portrait of a statue of a person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの画家に私の肖像を描かせてみよう。
I’ll let the artist paint my portrait.

mnemonics.meaning: If you serve someone, you're pouring alcohol or pouring sake for them. You're filling someone's glass.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading with the kanji. Cheers!

sentences: お酌をさせていただいてもよろしいですか。
May I pour you some sake?
部長、女性社員だからという理由で酌をさせるのは差別ですよ。
Manager, it is discriminatory to have female employees fill others' glasses just because they are female.
何だ、お前、俺の酌を断るのか！？
What, you're gonna turn down me pouring you alcohol?!

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji resent, so it means resentment.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You feel some pretty strong resentment toward your roommate because you had to touch their icky door (いきどお) today and it was covered in what you hope was glue. Or frosting. UHG what an icky door. This is an outrage!!!

sentences: 職場では理不尽なことが多くて憤りを感じています。
There are many unreasonable things to feel resentment about at work.

mnemonics.meaning: If you bustle and run around all day from being busy you end up running about to get them all done. You'll be busy getting it all done, but your efforts won't be in vain!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの社長は資金繰りに奔走しています。
My company is busy running around financing.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When you sail in a ship you can't forget to bring a garden hoe (ほ). If you lose your sails or your paddles, you can always use a hoe to paddle your way back. Or if you wreck on an island you can use the hoe to garden so you won't die of starvation! Hoes are very handy!

sentences: そろそろ帆を替えなくちゃいかんなあ。
Looks like you have to replace the sail soon.

mnemonics.meaning: A sail runs boats along the sea by sailing! You can't run along the water unless the sail is out and catching the wind.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ほら、あそこにヨットが帆走しているよ。
Look, there’s a yacht sailing over there.

mnemonics.meaning: The kind of score that comforts you is a musical score. The music is really relaxing. So is reading sheet music. You should try it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ピアノは弾けますが、楽譜は読めません。
I can play the piano but I can’t read sheet music.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 縫う means "to sew." Well the only way you can see if a pair of jeans has been sewed with your eye is if you see a seam. If your eyes can't spot the stitches, then it probably wasn't sewed at all. Maybe it was superglued together.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the words 縫う and 目. Both use the kun'yomi readings so just change the う to い and it's easy! You'll also see this word spelled 縫い目 too. They're exactly the same!

sentences: 自分で縫ったので縫い目がガタガタなんです。
I sewed it myself, so the stitches are crooked.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Just remember that this word can be used for both animal and seed shells.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Shells come from (から) living animals. You can't have a shell — or a carapace (から) — unless something was once in there. They have to come from something. This word isn't limited to animal shells though! It covers seed shells, or husks, too.

sentences: 蟹の殻はこの皿に入れてください。
Please put crab shells on this plate.
麦の殻を取ったら、その次はどうするの？
What do we do after removing the husks from wheat?
種の殻を突き破って、芽が出てくる瞬間を捉えたビデオを見ました。
I watched a video that captured the moment when a seed breaks through its shell and sprouts.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Wearing silk is the key (き) to not being nude (ぬ). Wear it!

sentences: 妻は、美しい絹のガウンを羽織って死んでいました。
My wife put on a beautiful silk gown and died.

mnemonics.meaning: A silk thread is silk thread!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 糸 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who only uses silk thread in their clothes? Sheep (し)! Sheep can't wear wool thread, oh no, what are you, some kind of monster?! Sheep all wear clothes made from silk threads while they're waiting for their wool to grow back.

sentences: 西陣の糸屋で絹糸を買ってきてちょうだい。
Please go buy silk thread at the Nishijin thread store.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 縛る means "to bind?" Well, in Japanese being bound by gold means you're experiencing sleep paralysis, or temporary paralysis. Just imagine that you're waking from a dream where you're bound up in gold thread, and it's stopping you from moving.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the words 金 and 縛る. Both use the kun'yomi readings, but 金 becomes かな instead of かね. If you can remember that exception, this should be easy!

sentences: 金縛りにあったことはありますか。
Have you ever had sleep paralysis before?

mnemonics.meaning: Your height can only reach the size of an oak if you have a strong spine to back you up.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 交通事故で脊椎を損傷し、下半身不随になったのです。
My spine was damaged in the traffic accident and the bottom half of my body became paralyzed.

mnemonics.meaning: You already know that 楽器 means "musical instrument" so adding a couple of bowstrings to it will make it a stringed instrument.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の叔父は、弦楽器の修理をしています。
My uncle repairs stringed instruments.

mnemonics.meaning: Feelings that make you sigh out loud are really strong feelings. You wouldn't sigh if they didn't move you so much.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 感慨がこめられた彼女の歌声に感動しました。
I was deeply moved by the strong feelings in her voice when she sang.

mnemonics.meaning: Sedge field is both Sugahara and Sugawara, the Japanese family names. Sedgefield is a family name (and a place-name) in English too, so that might help you with this one! This is a very old surname, said to have originated with Nara period scholar Hanishi-no-sukune (土師宿禰) who changed his name to Sugawara-no-furuhito (菅原古人). Historically, the name has been associated with scholars and writers, including prominent Heian period statesman, scholar, and poet Sugawara-no-michizane (菅原道真) and noblewoman, writer, and poet Sugawara-no-takasue-no-musume (菅原孝標女), also known more simply as Lady Sarashina in the English speaking world.
mnemonics.reading: The only reading you haven't learned for this name is the irregular わら reading for 原, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Sugawara-san went to war a (わら) long time ago, but these days he enjoys a quiet life tending to his sedge fields.

sentences: 菅原っていう苗字、なんかかっこよくね？
Sugahara's a cool surname, isn't it?
あれ、菅原さん、風邪ですか？
Oh, Sugawara-san, do you have a cold?
菅原靴店で、オシャレな革靴を買った。
At Sugawara Shoe Store, I bought a pair of stylish leather shoes.

mnemonics.meaning: Mix sulfur and acid and you'll get sulfuric acid! That's how science works! How simple!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どこで硫酸を手に入れたんだ。
Where did you get your hands on some sulfuric acid?

mnemonics.meaning: Aid and foster someone to show your support for them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 扶養の範囲内で働かせてください。
Please let me work in support.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 猶予 means "extension?" Well the jury has a tenacious grip on the idea of trying to let you go and they request an extension, so they give you a suspended sentence until they can figure out how to do it properly. You might be set free! E... eventually.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あいつは執行猶予期間中に他の刑事事件を起こしたんだよ。
That guy caused other criminal cases during his suspended sentence.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 猶予 means "extension?" Well you wake up ready to sue people when you're told there has been an extension, meaning there was a suspension of indictment on your case. What the heck, you woke up ready for this! Now you have to wait to try and sue them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 起訴猶予処分がくだされました。
The suspension of indictment punishment was passed.

mnemonics.meaning: The child of musical beats is the tempo. You can only keep time if you have a good beat to guide you, like a father.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 拍 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You get the tempo and the rhythm going in your body. You can't help but sing out loud, "Heyo (ひょう), heyo!" Feel that rhythm and sing with me! HEYO HEYO!

sentences: この曲は、拍子を取るのが難しい。
It's difficult to match the tempo of this tune.
転んだ拍子に差し歯が抜けてしまい、恥ずかしい思いをした。
I was embarrassed that when I fell my false tooth fell out.
拍子抜けしてしまったよ。
Well that was anticlimactic.

mnemonics.meaning: You decided to steal... and then you steal again a few minutes later! Now you're wanted for theft. Stealing is wrong, you should have known better!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ストレス解消に窃盗を繰り返していたそうだ。
It seems that he keeps stealing for stress reduction.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a combination of the word 呆れる meaning "to be amazed" and 返る meaning "to be returned." You're so amazed at something that it keeps returning to your mind. It means to be utterly amazed!
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the words 呆れる and 返る. 呆れる becomes 呆れ and you just add 返る to it. So reading this should be pretty simple.

sentences: 部屋があまりに汚かったので、呆れ返ってしまいました。
I was utterly amazed because the room was horribly dirty.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decay, so the verb version is to decay or to die out.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The entire world would start to die out if there were no cookies (く) left! Can you imagine your life without cookies? The trees and animals would all die too. Because they love cookies. Not just us humans.

sentences: 結局成功もせず、女もできずに朽ちていくはめになった。
In the end, I didn’t succeed, never had a girlfriend, and now I’m going to die out.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure, so the verb version is to endure or to keep out.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: 貧乏な時は、雑草を食べて飢えを凌いでいました。
When I was poor I ate weeds to stave off starvation.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means muddy, so the verb version is to make muddy or to make cloudy.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  If you want to make muddy, meaning make yourself muddy, you should have your knees go (にご) first. When you have your knees go first the mud splashes all over you but you don't hurt your hands or your butt doing it.

sentences: 核心をついた質問に、社長は言葉を濁した。
At the heart of the problem, the company president was vague.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means serve, and the verb version is to scoop or to serve. It can also mean to take into consideration someone else's feelings or opinions. Kind of like you're scooping up the person's feelings and considering them!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What do you decide to scoop out for your guests? Cookies (く)! But not just any cookies. Cookie smoothies! They're delicious and you won't serve anyone anything else. They must drink your delicious cookie drinks.

sentences: ヒシャクでタルからお酒を酌んだ。
I scooped sake out of the barrel with a ladle.
ちょっとはあいつの意見も酌んでやったらどう？
Why don't you take his opinion into consideration a little?
急いでこのおちょこにお酒を酌んできてください。
Please hurry up and get the sake in this cup.

mnemonics.meaning: I'm so bored. On top of my boredom is くまでも. If you took this separately, it would mean "even as a bear." So it's like you're saying I'm so bored, even if I was a bear. If you're so bored that you'd be bored even as a bear, you're going to be bored to the last or to the end. Nothing will please you, you bored bear person.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 飽きる so you should be able to read this one too!

sentences: 飽くまでも、これは個人的な見解です。
This is a stubbornly self-centered opinion.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means play, so the verb version is to play with or to toy with someone.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Everyone always seems to yell at you when you start to toy with your towel and your towel moves (たわむ). Just because you don't have anything on under it doesn't mean you can't play with it! Right?!

sentences: 子犬と戯れている少女の写真を撮りました。
I took a picture of the puppy and the girl playing with it.

mnemonics.meaning: You must not use your body for anything wasteful, because that would be a waste. You're too good for that! This word is used in all kinds of situations where there's a feeling that something is going to waste, including food, money, time, talent, and opportunities. You can also use it to say that someone is too good for a job, or even for another person. While it's usually written in kana, you'll see it in kanji too.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji, except that もち becomes もっ.

sentences: 食べ物を捨てるのは勿体ない事ですよね。
It's wasteful to throw away food, isn't it?
折角日本に行ったのに、太鼓の演奏を見ることができないなんて勿体ないですよね。
It's such a waste that you went to Japan but never got to see a taiko performance.
綾乃ちゃんは、亮平には勿体ないよ。
Ayano-chan, you're too good for Ryohei!

mnemonics.meaning: If you're bored all the time it makes you tired and the weariness you feel will show on your face.
mnemonics.reading: Remember how you learned 飽きる? Well just take of the る and it's the same thing. If you can remember that, you'll know this no problem!

sentences: 私って、飽きっぽいのよね。
Well, I’m fickle.

mnemonics.meaning: Some day you'll run around, released from the world and its troubles and you'll end up running wild. All your actions will be completely uninhibited when you aren't tied to your school or your job. It will be great!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.

sentences: あの自由奔放な性格に惹かれてしまったんだ。
I was attracted to his free and uninhibited personality.

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means below.
The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both Asia. As long as you know the radical Asia, you know the kanji Asia.
mnemonics.reading: What's the first sound in Asia? It's A (あ). Nice and easy! A is for Asia!

mnemonics.meaning: The barracks radical and the barracks kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: Barracks are pretty big, so they weigh a ton (とん). And they probably take tons of materials to build. Imagine trying to lift some barracks. They weigh a ton! How are you supposed to do this? Why would you even try to lift something that obviously weighs a couple tons?!

mnemonics.meaning: You see a mountain in the shape of a turtle shell sticking out into the ocean. It's a cape! No, not the kind you wear, the geographical kind. When you're on land, most capes look like turtle shell mountains sticking out into the sea. Do you know any capes like that near where you live? Picture the turtle shell shaped cape. Feel the salty wind in your hair!
mnemonics.reading: You decide to walk along this cape because it looks like the perfect place to get rid of your old meat sack (みさき). It's starting to smell, but the ocean breeze from the cape pulls the meat sack out of your hands and off into the sky (then probably into the sea too). The next time you go to the cape, remember to bring your old, used meat sack. You can toss it right into the ocean and it won't bother you ever again! Just make sure no one sees you.

mnemonics.meaning: Take three measurements of gold and slide them into a mold to make a cast! You'll have cast three gold swords, or goblets, or ducks. Just make sure you follow those directions, or your casting won't come out right. Imagine yourself carefully measuring out the three portions of gold and sliding them into your mold to make a cast of whatever you want. I wonder what it could be?
mnemonics.reading: You open the cast to reveal your gold statue of Chewbacca (ちゅう)! It's life-size and now you have three! Your new gold Chewbacca casts are going to guard the entrance to your house. Picture your majestic Chewbacca casts. Carefully set them outside your front door to guard you. This was a great idea!

mnemonics.meaning: You have to use your fingers to make an exit because you're so clumsy. You can't seem to get the door to open, your hands just slip around on the knob uselessly. Instead, you take your fingers and stick them into the door frame, pulling the whole thing off the hinges so you can leave. Of course, you're too clumsy to do that right either, you accidentally threw the door backwards and hurt some people...
mnemonics.reading: After you make your clumsy mistake you realize that these doors come in sets (せつ). And now you have to try to open another door. And another door. So many sets of doors! Imagine trying to use your clumsy fingers all over the sets of doors. You keep falling over and hurting yourself. Why is it so hard to leave?!

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to say how eternity sounds you have to compose a poem. Or an essay. Or a song. Recite those deep thoughts about eternity and impress everyone who hears it. Try to compose a poem about eternity right now. Just jot it down somewhere.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to compose a poem about an acorn (えい). The tiny acorn is the perfect vessel for you to say how eternity feels to you. Let me recite the acorn poem to you now: Acorns start small Grow up big and tall Spread their baby acorns for all Live on for all eternity

mnemonics.meaning: If a pilot manages to land under a canopy with a helicopter that's pierced with a sideways barb in the heart of winter you should congratulate them! People should always be congratulated for doing good things, and this is one of the best things you've ever heard of! Can you imagine how hard landing a helicopter in just one of these horrible conditions? Congratulate them!
mnemonics.reading: Congratulate the pilot with cake (けい)! Cake is always the appropriate celebratory food.

mnemonics.meaning: You can only give a kiss of alcohol to dairy. If you add anymore than a kiss the dairy will curdle and you won't be able to drink it anymore. Bleh. Imagine trying to give more than a kiss of alcohol to dairy and watch it bubble and curdle and get all gross and chunky.
mnemonics.reading: Dairy isn't kept with other drinks, it needs to be placed on a rack (らく). I hope you've been using your dairy rack to store your dairy. If you haven't you should get one right away! Look at all your dairy products: milk, yogurt, cheese, all of it sitting nicely on your dairy rack.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone makes a bamboo horse, you know it's deliberate. You can't accidentally make an entire horse out of bamboo. Someone sat down and deliberately planned the entire horse out, collected the materials, and made it by hand.
mnemonics.reading: As you admire all the deliberate details in this bamboo horse, the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you! "I deliberately made this horse to show you how important being deliberate is. You should be absolutely certain and decisive about your decisions." Tokugawa Ieyasu then poofs out of existence and so does the bamboo horse.

mnemonics.meaning: Every leader will come to despise their followers. In the beginning everything is fine and dandy, but eventually the leader's followers will ask for more and more things, eventually ridiculous things, and the leader will really despise them for it. Imagine yourself as a leader who's come to despise every single one of their followers. Look down at them in disgust as they ask you to grant them all a pony.
mnemonics.reading: The more you despise them, the more booze (ぶ) you drink. This is not smart or healthy, but it's what this kind of hate does to people. This is not a healthy way to handle things! If you despise someone you should talk to them, don't turn to booze. Don't be like every leader that's come before you.

mnemonics.meaning: If there is dirt in a crab trap, it's a lot for the crabs to endure. Imagine a little crab getting stuck in a crab trap with dirt and other crabs. Endure the horror as long as you can, little friend.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to make the little crab that endured being stuck in a dirty crab trap your pet, and put a collar (こら) round its little neck. Imagine yourself putting a collar around the crab's neck, then adding a leash and taking your crab for a walk around your neighborhood.

mnemonics.meaning: A spirit wearing two mustaches must be evil. Everyone knows a mustache makes you evil, but two? And on a spirit? Yup, definitely evil. Look at the evil spirit with two mustaches on its spirit face. Imagine its face in detail, especially those mustaches.
mnemonics.reading: You're watching the evil mustache spirit when it starts to float toward your car (か). And it's... hey! It's trashing your car! You knew this guy was evil! Imagine running around, flailing your arms, trying to get the spirit to stop ruining your car. But your hands go right through him and his two mustaches. You can't stop his evil doings.

mnemonics.meaning: If you can stop a turkey by putting a spoon in its face you'll know it's a female turkey. A male turkey will peck the spoon out of your hand and run away. But a female turkey will wonder why you're putting a spoon there, stop, and look up at you wondering if you're okay. Picture the female turkey stopping when it sees you holding out a spoon. Why are you doing that human? it thinks. Are you sick?
mnemonics.reading: The female turkey then runs around making a mess (めす) of things trying to figure out what's wrong with you. She kicks around her hay, water bowl, and scratches at your pants, making more mess marks on them. But you don't move and she gets even more worried. Imagine watching a female turkey make a mess of her own cage because she thinks you need help. How sweet.

mnemonics.meaning: If you see someone eyeing your womb you're probably going to be weirded out by how friendly they're acting. You only let people who are really, really close to you look at your womb. So if this guy is acting that friendly he should have introduced himself first. Imagine having someone you aren't friendly with trying to have a look at your womb. No thank you.
