mnemonics.reading: This friendly guy comes up to you and start to introduce himself, "ぼく-" but you stop him. He's been getting way too friendly with your womb and you don't want to hear who he is. He can ぼく at someone else, you're out. Imagine only letting this guy start to introduce himself with ぼく before walking the heck outta there. Just because he was acting friendly doesn't mean he was actually your friend.

mnemonics.meaning: If you stay up for so long that you get to watch the moon go down and the dawn come, then people will say you have serious guts. Staying up that late is really hard, and not everyone can do it. If you don't have the guts to stay up, you'll just fall asleep and never see the moon and the sun switch places in the sky. Imagine the guts you'd have to have to stay up for so long that you see the moon and the sun switch places! A lot of guts!
mnemonics.reading: You were outside for so long, proving you had guts, that you also got a sweet tan (たん) out of it! It's a really deep tan though, and you probably need more guts if you ever want to do all that again. Imagine having the guts to stay outside to watch the moon and the sun and then getting a really deep tan from it.

mnemonics.meaning: You try to use your fingers to cast doubt on people by using them to imitate each other. Right now you're using your fingers as finger puppets, imitating one of your friends to the others. Picture your angry friend standing up next to your fingers, shouting, "I'm the real me! That's just an imitation!" The rest of your friends look nervously at each other. They doubt this person is real now.
mnemonics.reading: Everyone thinks the friend you were trying to imitate is the imitation now and they have them in a guillotine (ぎ). You even doubt if they're an imitation or if your fingers are the imitation. Okay, so that's a lie, Your fingers are definitely imitating them, but you don't want to end up in the guillotine so you keep your mouth shut.

mnemonics.meaning: What kind of tree is spicy? A Japanese birch, or birch, obviously. There's nothing spicier than a Japanese birch!  Imagine licking the trunk of a Japanese birch tree and feeling the heat on your tongue.
mnemonics.reading: You can only cut down a Japanese birch using a zoo saw (あずさ) because a regular saw can't handle how spicy these trees are. Imagine using a zoo saw to cut down a Japanese birch tree. What's a zoo saw? It's a saw that's used in zoos, to build all the animal enclosures. And to cut down spicy trees.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami hits a tree and your hat protects you from the water, but the hat itself is now covered in lacquer. You take it off and see that it's shiny and hard and protected. Picture your hat and all of the other things the tsunami + tree water touched. It's all been hardened with a thick coating of the lacquer.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to scoop up the rest of the lacquer water and use it on your furniture to protect it from your shih tzu (しつ). Now it can't bite or scratch or ruin any of your things anymore! Watch as your shih tzu tries to bite your now lacquered chair. It gets its teeth around the leg, but it's hard as a rock. The shih tzu starts sneezing and spitting, letting go. Looks like it tastes bad too. Perfect!

mnemonics.meaning: You see a gate with a tree growing through it and it reminds you that you need more leisure time. You walk up to the gate tree and curl up under its branches. No one will bother you because the tree is blocking the gate from being used. Imagine spending your leisure time curled up under a tree that's growing through a gate. It's so cozy and secluded!
mnemonics.reading: As you leisurely nap, you hear a gruff voice, "Ah, you're done too, huh?" It's Genghis Khan (かん)! He's spending his leisure time relaxing under this abandoned gate just like you. But wait. Isn't Genghis Khan dead now? He winks at you, "Leisure time is for the dead." He smiles, and fades away, disappearing into the tree.

mnemonics.meaning: Your soul stands in the village you long for. It's the village you're from, and no matter how far you go, no matter how old you get, your soul is still there, and you yearn for it. Have you ever been away from your village? Maybe you're far away right now, studying Japanese alone. Can't you feel your body longing for your soul back home?
mnemonics.reading: No matter how much you long for it, you can't go back because a cougar (あこが) is in the way. Whenever you try to return to your village to be reunited with the soul you yearn for, a cougar is back, and won't let you in. You long for a cougar to leave you alone! You yearn for a cougar to bother someone else!

mnemonics.meaning: You drop to the ground in a rice paddy, and then drop down in front of the cross you keep on you because you're trying to make yourself as lowly as you can in front of God. He said to lower yourself and this is the only way you can interpret that. Imagine dropping down in a rice paddy, then again in front of your cross. Be as lowly as you can make yourself.
mnemonics.reading: The only problem about being lowly is the heat (ひ). Everyone always told you that heat rises, but not here. The rice paddy is incredibly hot... unless oh no. Is that the heat of hell? You tried to make yourself lowly in front of God but this heat is probably a sign that you didn't do it well enough.

mnemonics.meaning: You meet a woman whose mouth is big and you instantly know this is the person you want to marry. When you think about the person you want to marry, picture their mouth wide in a big, beautiful smile, a wide-open laugh. That's the lady for you, alright!
mnemonics.reading: You marry this woman right away and you both go straight to an inn (いん) together! When you get to the inn all you do is make her laugh and smile so you can bask in her bright, big, mouth smiles.

mnemonics.meaning: If you only let oneself (yourself) into your heart, you'll end up mourning all of the loves and friendships you could have had but didn't let in. Picture yourself all alone. You never let anyone into your heart but yourself, and now you're mourning the life and friends you could have had.
mnemonics.reading: While you're in mourning, you feel a sharp pain in your crying eyes. A key (き) comes sliding out with your tears. You look around wildly, but you're still alone. Is this... the key of mourning? You try to push the key back into your body. Back into your eye, you even try to swallow it, but it comes back out. Finally you look down at your mourning heart and try the key there. It clicks. And opens.

mnemonics.meaning: When underground music makes it out into the light of the sun (the public), it finally becomes official. Music isn't really real unless people hear it outside of those secret underground concerts. Think of all that music you listened to underground but not in the light of the sun. None of that was official music. None of it!
mnemonics.reading: Once the music is official, you'll feel it in your soul (そう). When you listen to it outside, under the bright sun, your soul gets to finally hear it too. The official music penetrates into your soul, instead of just your ears, and it's affecting everyone else's souls too! Oh no... wait that's too many people. This was your song! No, it's too popular now, stop your souls from liking it! Ahhh!

mnemonics.meaning: If you're on a mountain looking from above to below that means you're on the peak of the mountain. Imagine standing right at the peak of a mountain looking at down from above and everything down below. You're really, really high up!
mnemonics.reading: It's only on this type of mountain peak that you'll be able to find the rare and adorable Tokyo gecko (とうげ). These tiny little critters can only be found on the ridges going above and below the mountains in Tokyo. There are like six mountains in Tokyo, so the next time you're scaling the ridges keep your eyes open for the Tokyo gecko! Picture yourself sitting on a mountain peak in Tokyo and watching a little Tokyo gecko run up and down on them. It's adorable and totally worth the climb.

mnemonics.meaning: We want you to say things with your mouth right now because it's recital time! Go, perform please. What do you mean you didn't know the recital was right now? Well, tough luck. Recite! The recital is happening now. So open your mouth and start already!
mnemonics.reading: Here, if you are too afraid to start the recital now drink this gin (ぎん) to get your courage up. But once you're done drinking it the recital starts! Drink gin before all your recitals! It'll help!

mnemonics.meaning: The stone that looks like a turkey boiling underwater is just a reef. It may seem like there are a bunch of turkeys under there, but it's just the shape the reef takes. Though I guess if you're looking from above the water it really does look like a bunch of turkeys freaking out.
mnemonics.reading: The reef is the Shougun's (しょう) favorite place to be nowadays. He sits next to the water, and stares down into it for hours. You don't know if the Shougun likes the reef because he likes the beauty of the ocean, or if he's fantasizing about turkeys boiling. He's a... complex man.

mnemonics.meaning: People think tsunamis are only made of water but they have a few pieces of sand in there too. There's actually more sand in the ocean than most people think. And tsunamis can't just have water and sharks in them. A few grains of sand will always slip in. Imagine how those few grains of sand feel to get swept up into a tsunami. They didn't ask for this. They just wanted to stay at the bottom of the sea.
mnemonics.reading: How do I know there's sand in there? Because I saw (さ) them!  I saw the sand, stop doubting me!

mnemonics.meaning: In a flowers net a drunkard slides down like a drop. There they stay, an icon of scorn and neglect. It's embarrassing to fall down a flowers net while drunk. Despite that, there you are. Everyone who goes by scorns you or neglects you.
mnemonics.reading: Every time you receive scorn and neglect from someone walking by, you say in your drunken voice: "I bets you (べつ) I can get up if I want. I bets you I can." You try to get up, but no matter how much you "bets you" someone that you can get up, you slide back down the flowers net. "I bets you I can do it next time," you say.

mnemonics.meaning: If the tsunami that's heading for your village is fat you should try to select a different one to hit instead. You don't want to select fat tsunamis because they do more damage. Imagine being at the tsunami store and selecting the least fat one there.
mnemonics.reading: If you're having trouble selecting which one is the least fat just check to see which tsunamis are eating tacos (た). Only fat tsunamis will be eating them, so just look for one without a taco. While you select the tsunami that's right for you. Keep an eye out for those fat taco-eating ones. And then stay away from them!

mnemonics.meaning: Move thread in the right direction and you'll end up spinning it into yarn. Then you can spin that yarn into a sweater or a scarf with your favorite half tofu half fugu mascot on it! Imagine spinning thread into whatever your imagination wants.
mnemonics.reading: While you're spinning you realize that you've always wanted to make your own bowling (ぼう) ball. And bowling ball cover. And bowling ball shoes. Picture all of these thread-made bowling items. You're a really big bowling fan, huh?

mnemonics.meaning: Going from a scooter to a helicopter that's big even for yourself (oneself), is a huge transition. It's an upward transition, so that's nice, but it's still going to take you a long time to get used to using a big helicopter instead of a scooter.
mnemonics.reading: You decide one transition isn't enough, so you transition to a centaur (せん) too. Now you're a big half horse-half human creature and you'll fit in the big helicopter better. A centaur is just a human halfway between transitioning into a horse, so it isn't even that hard to do!

mnemonics.meaning: There were lots of things that were above you when you were small that you would need a stool to reach, so you just asked your aunt or uncle to get them for you. Your parents didn't want you having those things, which is why they put them up high, but your aunt and uncle would always spoil you and get them for you.
mnemonics.reading: You ask your aunt and uncle to help you reach your special obi (お) from high up in the closet.  You aren't supposed to wear your obi unless it's a special occasion, but your aunt and uncle don't know that. Now you can run around with it on your head and your parents can't stop you by putting it up high!

mnemonics.meaning: Making a mnemonic for a crab trap is VERY hard. So hard that I couldn't come up with one. But it's very possible that one of you will! How hard is it to come up with a good mnemonic for a crab trap? Very hard!
mnemonics.reading: You know what else is very something? Jeans (じん). Jeans are very expensive. Jeans are very tight. Jeans are very popular. Jeans are very a lot of things. How many sentences can you make with very and jeans? More than me I hope.

mnemonics.meaning: The tsunami that is good. This fabled creature has never been seen, but you wander the lands in search of it. You wander everywhere, with no particular direction in mind.
mnemonics.reading: As you wander, you come across a clue. It is fish roe (ろう).  Wherever the good tsunami goes, it leaves delicious fish roe behind. That's what makes it a good tsunami.

mnemonics.meaning: Under the mountain's roof are people using jackhammers to worship the gods. The noise from their jackhammering echos up through the mountain and up toward the sky where the gods live. As long as each person uses their own jackhammer, the sound will be loud enough to reach them. Man your own jackhammer! (And worship the gods.)
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, the people who live around here can also hear you and the others worship in the mountain and they're going to sue (すう) you for the noise.  You try to argue that you can't sue someone for the way they choose to worship, but they say they're all deaf now, all the animals have gone, and no one sleeps anymore because of the shaking. Yikes, they might have a case!

mnemonics.meaning: A reef in the shape of a loop is an atoll. If you don't know what that is, it's a circular coral reef.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その時、日本のマグロ漁船「第五福竜丸」がたまたまビキニ環礁を航行しており、乗組員が被ばくしてしまった。
The Japanese tuna boat "S.S. Lucky Dragon 5" accidentally sailed around Bikini Atoll and the crew was exposed to radiation.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 一遍 means "once?" Well if you add に and make it an adverb, it becomes at once.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading you learned with 一遍 so you should be able to remember this too!

sentences: 一遍にいろんなことを言われても、分からないわ。
If you say a bunch of things at once I won’t understand.

mnemonics.meaning: An aunt on your mother's side is still your aunt. This aunt always has to be younger than her though.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 伯母 which means aunt too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one aunt, you know them all!

sentences: 叔母は学校の先生をしています。
My aunt is a school teacher.

mnemonics.meaning: A thing that happens that makes you want to congratulate the person who it happened to makes it an auspicious event. You'll remember this for a long, long time.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 親しい友人の慶事は自分のことの様にうれしい。
The happy events my close friends have make me as happy as if they were my own.

mnemonics.meaning: Japanese birch river is Azusa River or simply Azusagawa. Azusagawa is both the Japanese name for the Azusa River, and a Japanese family name.
mnemonics.reading: You learned both of these readings with the kanji. You just need to remember that rendaku turns かわ into がわ.

sentences: 普段の梓川はとても穏やかです。
The Azusa River is usually very calm.
週末は梓川の水の透明感に癒やされてきました。
At the weekend, I was soothed by the clarity of the water in Azusa River.
梓川さんの歌唱力が高いのは勿論だけど、曲の歌詞もすごくいいんだよね。
Of course, Azusagawa-san is a talented singer, but the lyrics of her songs are also really good.

mnemonics.meaning: You should congratulate a person who speaks lots of dialects because they have to be a really strong person, just like Mr. Benkei was. You think learning Japanese is hard now, just wait till you hear Osaka-ben and Hokkaido-ben. It takes a really strong person — a Benkei — to learn all those dialects, so congratulate them and tell them how strong they are! 弁慶 is the name of a Japanese historical figure who was really strong, so Benkei is the Japanese equivalent of Hercules or Achilles in Western languages.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 弁慶と牛若丸は清水寺で戦いました。
Benkei and Ushiwakamaru fought at Kiyomizu Temple.
家では威張っているが、外では従順になる人のことを「内弁慶」と言う。
A person who is arrogant at home but submissive outside the home is called an "uchi-benkei".
むこうずねは、ぶつけると弁慶ほど強い人でも涙を流すほど痛いことから、「弁慶の泣き所」といわれています。
The shin is known as "Benkei's weeping spot" because, if you hit it, it hurts so much that even someone as strong as Benkei would shed tears.

mnemonics.meaning: Grief shows in your eyes by making them look like you've gone through a lot of bitterness and hardship. You can always see it in someone else if you look them in the eyes too.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for the kanji. You kind of learned this reading for 憂, but not exactly. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:  The bitterness that shows in your eyes takes the rays (れ) of light out of them, leaving you with just the う part of the reading that you know. That's why this reading is just う and not うれ like the others.

sentences: 失恋の憂き目に遭いました。
I met with the misery of a broken heart.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have really big guts you're a super bold and daring person. In fact, you might even be superman. That's how big your guts are. Don't worry, I don't tell anyone I know who you are. It'll be our little secret.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: グループは、大胆にも真っ昼間から犯行に及んだのです。
The group is bold to commit crimes in broad daylight.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 岬の突端にカフェがあるんです。
There’s a cafe on the tip of the cape.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to create a cast you need to learn casting first. Then you can make lots of neat art, crafts, and counterfeit money. Wait, no, don't do that last one.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned both of them, so you should already know this word!

sentences: ここで、プラチナ・コインの鋳造をします。
Platinum coins are cast here.

mnemonics.meaning: Change and transition mean change and transition! Nifty.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 1996年から2013年までのトップ日本語学習サイト20の変遷を見てみましょう。
Let’s look at the changes in the top 20 Japanese language learning sites between 1996 and 2013.

mnemonics.meaning: You congratulate someone and celebrate by saying congratulations and having a celebration!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 慶祝の意を表して、乾杯！
To show our congratulations, a toast!

mnemonics.meaning: If you are saying congratulations and also giving your condolences then they are congratulations and condolences. Pretty easy, right?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 慶弔用の礼服は持っているのか。
Do you have ceremonial dress for celebration and condolences?

mnemonics.meaning: If someone is so dangerous that they deliberately hurt you, you're going to end up in critical condition. This wasn't an accident, they knew what they were doing and they didn't miss. Now you're on the verge of death. Hold on, kiddo.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 父が危篤だという電話がありました。
There was a call saying dad was in critical condition.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 遮断 means "isolation?" Well the machine that isolates you from a train is a crossing gate. That way you won't walk, bike, or drive your car into an oncoming train.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 遮断機が降りている時に、線路を渡ってはいけません。
When the railroad crossing gate comes down, do not cross the tracks.

mnemonics.meaning: Dairy farming is dairy farming!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ここは日本酪農発祥の地です。
This is the location of the origin of Japanese dairy farming.

mnemonics.meaning: The times when you are in mourning each year are for a loved one's death anniversary. They come around again every year. It's important you remember your loved ones at this time. You'll often see this used with a number before 回忌, indicating a certain anniversary. However, you actually start counting your 回忌 starting with the first period of mourning around the time of the person's death, which would be the 一回忌. Hence, 二回忌 would usually be translated as "first death anniversary", 三回忌 as "second death anniversary", and so on.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今年は祖父の三回忌です。
Today is the second anniversary of my grandfather’s death.
みんな忙しいので、各回忌に家族全員集まることは難しいです。
Everyone is so busy that it's difficult to get the whole family together for each anniversary.
死んだお嫁さんの一回忌もまだ終わってないのにもう再婚するつもりなの？
Your late wife only just passed away and you're already planning to remarry?

mnemonics.meaning: If you compose something with a sigh, it's because you're experiencing a deep feeling. You might express this deep feeling with an exclamation, as you marvel at the wonders of the world. This word can be used for a range of deep feelings, good or bad, and can also be used for the expression of those feelings, so you'll notice that the English translation varies quite a bit depending on the context.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You should be able to read it on your own.

sentences: その山の頂上から見た夕日の美しさに詠嘆した。
I marveled at the beauty of the sunset I saw from the top of that mountain.
この文には、「これが最後かもしれないんだなあ」という詠嘆の意味が込められています。
This sentence is filled with a deep feeling of "I wonder if this might be the last time."
和歌でよく使われる「けり」という言葉は、詠嘆の助動詞です。
The word "keri," often used in waka poetry, is an auxiliary verb of exclamation.

mnemonics.meaning: Usually if you're going to the left in Japanese, it's not a good thing. So if you transition to the left it's seen as a demotion. Going to the right is way better.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 田舎の支店に左遷されました。
I was demoted to a branch store in the country.

mnemonics.meaning: It's such a leisurely day that everyone has scattered and left the area deserted. It's just you now. Lounging in the shade.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 駅の南側は、いつも閑散としています。
The south side of the station is always deserted.

mnemonics.meaning: Your guts feel like they're falling when you experience a lot of discouragement. You know that sinking feeling you get in the pit of your stomach? That's your guts falling!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 息子は、受験に失敗して落胆しているんだ。
My son failed an exam and is discouraged.

mnemonics.meaning: Use attire that imitates your surroundings to create a disguise. Or throw on some camouflage so that no one will be able to find you in Walmart.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 食品会社の擬装を許してはいけません。
You must not excuse the food company’s disguise.

mnemonics.meaning: East Asia is East Asia! That's where Japan is!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 太平洋戦争のことを、大東亜戦争と呼ぶのは何故ですか。
Why is the Pacific War called The Greater East Asian War?

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 大腸 means "large intestines?" Well when you get bacteria in there you end up with E. Coli. Go to a doctor right away! You're gonna be stuck in the bathroom for a while. Sorry...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大腸菌を美少女に擬人化させたカードアプリ・ゲームがあります。
There’s a card app game that personifies E. Coli as a beautiful woman.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: この犬は雌ですか？
Is this dog female?

mnemonics.meaning: A female flower is a female flower!
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi, but you haven't learned this kun'yomi for 雌 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just think of someone asking you to differentiate female flowers from male flowers. Can you? "Meh (め), probably not." The reading of 花 is the rendaku version, so watch out for that too.

sentences: ヒマラヤスギは、樹齢30年を超えないと雌花を付けません。
Himalayan Cedar trees can't produce female flowers until they're over 30 years old.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 一周 means "one time around?" Well if you're mourning one time like this a year, then it's because it's the first anniversary of death for a family member. Maybe it was the death of your mom, your grandad or your goldfish, this is the first year since they died.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 七月には、妻の父の一周忌の法事があります。
In July we’re having the ceremony for my wife’s father’s first death anniversary.

mnemonics.meaning: If you only take daring and you don't have any yourself, you only have it for the time being. It will go away if you can't make it yourself.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for the kanji. You learned both of these already, so you should be able to read this with no problems!

sentences: 取り敢えず枝豆とビールをください。
Edamame and beer for now please.

mnemonics.meaning: If a parent is friendly enough you can form a friendship with them, not just a kid/parent bond.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 親睦を深めるためのパーティーを準備しています。
We are preparing for a party to strengthen our friendship.

mnemonics.meaning: Stones that form in your guts are gallstones. Sometimes you have to get them surgically taken out. Scary!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 胆嚢炎は、ほとんどの場合、胆石が原因です。
With inflammation of the gallbladder, the most likely cause is gallstones.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

sentences: お前はもう少し胆を練る必要がある。
You need to build up your courage.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 均衡 means "balance?" Well if you do not have any balance, you're going to have an imbalance instead.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 先進国と新興国・発展途上国間の経常収支の不均衡は是正されるのでしょうか。
Will the current account imbalances of developing countries be corrected between developed and undeveloped countries?

mnemonics.meaning: Food that imitates an imitation of some OTHER food, is an even worse imitation. You don't want to eat that. It's a sham! It's mocking real food! It's probably made of dust and cardboard!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 模擬試験の結果はどうだったの？
How were the results of the mock exam?

mnemonics.meaning: Another way to say something is very big is to say it is immense or enormous.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大型台風が甚大な被害をもたらした。
An immense typhoon brought on serious damage.

mnemonics.meaning: You despise this one guy so much that you want to humiliate him so you insult him in public. That wasn't very nice, but it did seem to embarrass him. I guess you won.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: こんな侮辱を受けて、黙っていろというのか。
Are you telling me to stay quiet and just accept the insults?

mnemonics.meaning: Lacquer black looks jet black, or pitch black. It's as black as black can be!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 漆黒の闇に青い地球が浮かんでいた。
The earth appeared in the black darkness.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You make lacquer out of uni root sh*t (うるし). You gotta get deep in the uni to the root of its sh*t and rub it into a paste to make the lacquer. Then rub that on wooden stuff! Yay! Uni root sh*t!

sentences: 漆の葉を触ると手がかぶれますよ。
If you touch a lacquer leaf you’ll get a rash on your hand.

mnemonics.meaning: Lacquer containers are called Lacquerware. Those pretty bowls you're eating out of? That shininess is because it's lacquerware!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 漆器の手入れの仕方を教えてください。
Please teach me how to maintain lacquer ware.

mnemonics.meaning: The official method of doing anything requires hiring a lawyer. They have to be there when you sign forms or sue people, or it isn't official at all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 法曹を目指そうと思ったきっかけは何ですか。
What made you pursue your dream of becoming a lawyer?

mnemonics.meaning: You worship someone who is so high above you that you can't help but be in awe of their loftiness. Their nobility is the reason you feel like you should worship them in the first place.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 自然の崇高な美しさに感動しました。
I was deeply moved by the noble beauty of nature.

mnemonics.meaning: Marry and marriage still make marriage. Congratulations! Wooh! Yay!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 婚姻届を役所に提出しました。
I submitted the marriage registration at the public office.

mnemonics.meaning: If you treat someone in a lowly manner because you think they're inferior to you then you're a mean person. Plain and simple.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 卑劣な手段を使いやがって。
You played a mean trick!

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 忌が明けたら、みんなで旅行でも行きましょうか。
When the mourning is over, shall we all go on a trip?

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to transition the capital to a new, better place, you need to move the capital. This used to happen a lot way back in Japanese history. It's actually pretty interesting so you might want to read up on it!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 来年は、遷都1500年記念のイベントが開催されます。
Next year an event is being held for the 1500 year anniversary of the relocation of the capital.

mnemonics.meaning: If you select to talk to nothing but sand for a really long time, you're neglecting to contact anyone else. Your relatives miss you! Stop talking to sand and call them!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ご無沙汰しております。
I haven’t seen you in so long.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You climb the peak and see adorable little Tokyo geckos (とうげ) climbing all over the place. They're climbing with you now!

sentences: この峠で転ぶと、三年だけしか生きられないという言い伝えがあります。
Legends says, if you fall off this peak you’ll only have three years left to live.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 漬ける means "to pickle," so if you add that to the end of a food word (and leave off the る) it means that food as been pickled.
mnemonics.reading: You already learned 漬ける meaning "to pickle" so just take the る off and you've picked whatever comes next! Easy peasy.

sentences: 胡瓜の浅漬けならありますよ。
These are lightly pickled cucumbers.

mnemonics.meaning: The soul and guts of a story lie in the plot!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あわよくばおこぼれに預かりたいという魂胆が見え見えだよ。
You are so transparent. I can tell that you’re plotting to get a share of the profits if you get the chance.

mnemonics.meaning: A composed song is a poem, or a song. This can also refer to the act of composing a poem or song, which makes a lot of sense given the kanji. This is used particularly when referring to waka poetry.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: みなさんは、誰がこの詠歌を書いたのが知っていますか？
Everyone, do you know who wrote this poem?
彼は、暗殺される直前に、一つの詠歌をしたためていた。
Just before he was assassinated, he had written a poem.
仏教の教えを和歌の形にして、旋律に乗せて唱えるものを御詠歌といいます。
Chanting Buddhist teachings in the form of a waka poem with a melody is called "goeika".

mnemonics.meaning: Leisurely quiet is the best kind of quiet. Even your brain gets to be quiet because you don't have a care left in the world.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この辺りは、閑静な住宅街になっています。
This neighborhood is now a quiet residential area.

mnemonics.meaning: A reef made of boulders is still a reef, but it's made of sunken rocks.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 岩礁を埋め立て、人工島に造り替えたんです。
The reef was filled up and replaced with an artificial island.

mnemonics.meaning: A dark reef is still a reef. It's just really deep underwater so it's kinda dark under there. Because of that it can also be called a sunken reef.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 船長は、暗礁に気をつけてと言って、僕に操縦を任せた。
The captain told me to be careful of reefs and then left the steering to me.
捜査は暗礁に乗り上げてしまったな。
The investigation went cold unexpectedly.

mnemonics.meaning: A young woman who is planting rice from early morning into the latter evenings is a rice planting girl. You'll see them out there all day long, from dawn till dusk, planting, taking care of, and picking rice. This is also a common family name, and on rare occasion, a given name as well. Some well-known people with this name include historical fiction writer Saotome Mitsugu (早乙女 貢), former pro-wrestler, model, and idol Saotome Miku (早乙女 未来), and stage and screen actor Saotome Taichi (早乙女 太一).
mnemonics.reading: This is a really weird exception, sorry. You've kind of learned these reading, but they're like... weird variations of them. Take the さ from 早速, the おつ becomes おと, and then the 女 kun'yomi め (hey that one's normal!). And you get さおとめ. You might need to just memorize this one.

sentences: 昔は稲の苗を水田に植えつける女性のことを「早乙女」や「植女」と呼んでいました。
Long ago, women who planted rice seedlings were called Saotome or Ueme.
早乙女勝元の児童文学作品の中では平和をテーマとしているものが多い。
In Saotome Katsumoto's children's literature there are many works with peace as their theme.
女優の早乙女愛はデビューした時に漫画 『愛と誠』の映画化で同じ名前をした主人公を演じ、そのまま芸名にしたらしいよ。
Apparently, when she made her debut, actress Saotome Ai played the lead character of the same name in the film adaptation of the manga "Ai to Makoto," then just adopted it as her stage name.

mnemonics.meaning: A person who wanders because their lord was killed, is known as a ronin, or a masterless samurai. Now they're just like the rest of us, but they can't stop wandering because they have nowhere they belong. In modern times, ronin refers to those who failed their university entrance exams, waiting until for another chance to take the test again.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 受験に失敗し、浪人生活に突入しました。
I failed the exam and entered the life of a failed student.
お前みたいな浪人の要求には応じられないな。
We are unable to comply with the request of a masterless samurai like you.

mnemonics.meaning: Evil's root is the root of evil. It's the source of evil things.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: できれば禍根を残すことは避けたい。
I want to avoid turning a blind eye to future trouble, if I can.

mnemonics.meaning: If sand is spread out you get the given name Sara. You've written your name in sand, right? Now imagine a Sara you know spreading out sand so that it spells her name. Or imagine a pro athlete, like wrestler Doshō Sara (土性 沙羅), judoka Asahina Sara (朝比奈 沙羅), or ski jumper Takanashi Sara (髙梨 沙羅) spreading out the sand. I bet they'd find some skillful ways to do it.
mnemonics.reading: This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji.

sentences: 沙羅さんと会釈をして別れました。
Sara-san and I bowed to each other and parted ways.
沙羅は拓哉と一緒に苗を植えるつもりです。
Sara is going to plant the seedlings with Takuya.
ものまね芸人の沙羅さんが名古屋出身だって知ってた？
Did you know that the impressionist Sara comes from Nagoya?

mnemonics.meaning: Despise someone and your scorn for them just becomes even stronger scorn.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 叔母の言葉は、いつも軽い侮蔑を帯びている。
My aunts speech always has light traces of contempt.

mnemonics.meaning: Lightweight scorn, no matter how light, is still scorn. Those feelings are pretty strong no matter what.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 軽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have more scorn and disdain for the KKK (けい) than any other group in the whole world. And I'm not going to argue with you, they're pretty hatable.

sentences: 私、あの人のこと軽蔑しているの。
I despise them.

mnemonics.meaning: If you tasted the air at a recital the flavor would taste like scrutiny. That's really what everyone is doing when they watch. They don't really want to hear you, they just want to judge you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 結婚相手はよく吟味してから決めたい。
I want to decide on a spouse after a lot of careful investigation.

mnemonics.meaning: Spinning exploits sheep, but you keep spinning anyway because you're cold and you need the sweater you're making.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 牽切紡績とは、化学繊維特有の紡績方法で、綿からの紡績ではありません。
Kensetsu bouseki is a spinning method particular to synthetic fibers not spun from cotton.

mnemonics.meaning: Spinning and weaving means spinning and weaving. Yay!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 織 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: While you're spinning and weaving you are always absolutely shocked (しょく) by what you make. You never really know when you start and then BAM! You made elephant slippers. That's just how it works and it shocks you every single time.

sentences: 日本繊維産業は、綿紡織、化繊を中心として復興しました。
The Japanese textile industry was revived mainly by cotton spinning and weaving and synthetic fibers.

mnemonics.meaning: What is a sprout doing? It's sprouting and budding. A crush you have on someone can sprout too.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Think about that newly sprouting moe (もえ) character you have a crush on. Yes, this is the same moe. Congrats, you already know it!

sentences: このブログでは、萌え系を中心に、僕の好きなアニメや漫画を紹介していきます。
This blog introduces me to the moe characters in my favorite anime and manga.

mnemonics.meaning: Resident soldiers live in barracks when they've been stationed in another country. They have to serve their occupancy for a certain amount of time before they get to go back home.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あそこには米軍が駐屯しているんだよ。
US armed forces are stationed over there.

mnemonics.meaning: A lowly person who yields to everyone is really subservient. They'll do everything people tell them because they don't have the nerves to speak up and just say no.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうしてすぐに卑屈になるの？
Why do you immediately become subservient?

mnemonics.meaning: Prohibition of something with a punishment so serious that you'll end up in mourning after is a taboo.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: よく、禁忌を犯すと手足をもがれると言われますが、これは本当でしょうか。
It’s often said that your hands and feet are plucked off when you commit a taboo, is that true?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hollow, so the verb version is to become hollow and to sink
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You feel like you've started to become hollow when you have a head cold (へこ). You may be all stuffed up, but it's making you so sad that you feel hollow somehow.

sentences: 失恋で凹んでいます。
I’m sinking in unrequited love.
早速新車を凹ませてしまって、凹んでいます。
I'm super sad because I made a dent on my new car already.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 漬ける means "to pickle," so this means "to be pickled."
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 漬ける, so you should be able to read this one too.

sentences: 温泉に漬かってゆっくりした。
I soaked and relaxed in the onsen.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means compose, so the verb version is to compose.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You want to compose a poem but all you have for inspiration is what's in your pocket. You reach in and find a yo-yo (よ). Ah yes, this will do. So you compose a poem about your yo-yo: One string to rule them all, One string to find them, One string to- hey wait a minute...

sentences: 俳句を詠む人のことを俳人と呼びます。
People who compose haiku are called haijin.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means despise, so the verb version is to despise.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Think of all the things you start to despise and to disdain. Now come up with some anecdotes (あなど) for each one of those things. Be sure to think in your head, "I'm coming up with anecdotes for things I disdain, why am I coming up with anecdotes?"

sentences: 子供だからといって侮らない方がいい。
You shouldn’t make light of it just because it’s a child.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure, so the verb version is to endure or to bear.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji!

sentences: この作品は読むに堪えない出来栄えだ。
In the end, I couldn’t bear reading the work.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means long for, so the verb version is to long for and to yearn after.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: あの先輩に憧れているんです。
I have a crush on that senpai.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scorn, so the verb version is to scorn and to despise.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You start to scorn your boss because she's been wearing that same sage suit (さげす) for a month now. She knows you want to wear a sage suit too but you can't wear the same color as her! It's really making you start to despise her. Uhg!

sentences: あの男は、無意識に人のことを蔑んでいるのよ。
That man unconsciously looks down on people.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spinning, so the verb version is to spin and to make yarn.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Before you start to spin you have to let out two moos (つむ) as tribute to the cows that gave you their fur to make yarn out of. Go on, two moos, right now. Hey, out loud, not in your head!

sentences: 昔はこうやって糸を紡いでいたんですよ。
A long time ago thread was spun in this way.

mnemonics.meaning: Pickled things are Japanese pickled vegetables! Or tsukemono if you've already been eating yummy pickled ginger, daikon, and umeboshi!
mnemonics.reading: You already learned 漬ける meaning "to pickle" so just take the る off there shove the け into the kanji. You read it still, but it's hiding. It probably shrunk in the pickling process. Stick some things (もの) on there are you know the reading! Not bad! By the way, sometimes you'll see this word spelled like 漬け物 too.

sentences: この漬物は誰が漬けたんですか。
Who pickled these tsukemono?

mnemonics.meaning: An uncle on your father's side is still your uncle. This uncle always has to be younger than him though.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 伯父 which means uncle too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one uncle, you know them all!

sentences: 叔父はこの学校の校長です。
My uncle is the principal of this school.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 凹凸 means "uneven?" Well spin something uneven around and it's still uneven! Just kinda backwards, just like this word!
mnemonics.reading: However, just because the meaning stays the same when you flip it, doesn't mean the reading does. Doing that actually made the reading change from on'yomi to kun'yomi readings! You haven't learned either of these yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you have the convex parts first and the concave parts second in something uneven it ends up looking like a deco box (でこぼこ). An art deco box that is. They have lots of stuff stick out of them on the outside, but you can open them up and put stuff on the inside.

sentences: 床がちょっと凸凹しているのが気になるね。
I’m worried that the floor is a little uneven.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 普遍 means "universal?" Well when you add like it's still universal! Easy!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: とても普遍的なテーマだと思います。
I think it’s a really universal theme.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with しい on the end, meaning it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of mourning? It's unpleasant or disgusting. Nobody said mourning was fun.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Your mourning is especially unpleasant because it's your pet eagle (い) you're mourning for. Your parents wouldn't let you bury him so you're just staring at his week old, dead eagle body. It's super disgusting, actually.

sentences: この忌まわしい記憶をどうか消し去ってください。
Please erase this disgusting memory somehow.

mnemonics.meaning: Clumsy and immature people end up being really unskillful. You can't do your job if you're always dropping things and whining, can you? They're usually also really childish, if you didn't already guess that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 稚拙な文章ですがもしよければ読んでください。
It’s not a very good article, but please read it if you’d like.

mnemonics.meaning: Wander from stream to stream and you'll get really used to wandering. You'll love it so much that you'll convert to nomadism. The open sky is your home!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 全てのジプシーが貧しい流浪の民というわけではない。
That doesn’t mean all Gypsies are poor, nomadic people.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who floats and wanders from place to place is a vagrant. They don't really have a home, but they keep hanging around yours. It's kind of annoying. (This word has a negative connotation, you wouldn't use it for someone who is just homeless, unless you're really mean.)
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 浮 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: All the vagrants you know are fools (ふ). They just left their homes and now they float around your city for no reason. You ask them why and they shrug. You've never seen a better definition of a fool before in your life!

sentences: 浮浪者でも7割の人は何らかの仕事をして日銭を稼いでいる。
70% of vagrants do some kind of work and earn a daily cash income.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  If you're very tired and very giggly, you'll try to say your friend's name but start laughing right away so it ends up sounds like,  "Hannah ha ha ha (はなは)."

sentences: そのようなことが事実だとすれば、甚だ遺憾である。
If that sort of thing is true, I’m very sorry.

mnemonics.meaning: Release your worldly ties and wander the world. You'll get used to wandering and you'll spend the rest of your days roaming the world until you die. It's quite the life! But you can only do it if you let go of everything else.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 当時は、逃げるように各地を転々と放浪していました。
In those days I had to wander from place to place in order to escape.

mnemonics.meaning: One of the most evil things about war are the war damages that happen during it. Whole countrysides, cities, and lots of people can die. So I'd say the ravages of war are the most evil thing about war. Period.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 戦禍を逃れて田舎に疎開した。
We escaped the ravages of war and evacuated into the countryside.

mnemonics.meaning: If you wander around doing nothing at your own expense it will be a huge waste of money. It's not like you were doing or buying anything important, you were just wandering around, after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 妻の浪費癖がなかなか治らないんです。
My wife’s wasteful habits were not easily cured.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 惜しむ means "to be sparing?" Well if you make that negative with ない, then you're doing it without sparing anything instead.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so you should be able to read this already too!

sentences: 目的を成し遂げるには、努力を惜しまないことが大切だと思います。
I think it’s important to spare no effort in fulfilling your goals.

mnemonics.meaning: Worship in the morning, worship in the night, worship all day! Worship that WaniKani poster. Do it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうして偶像崇拝を禁止するのですか。
Why do they prohibit idol worship?

mnemonics.meaning: If you long for something you'll get feelings of yearning and longing. Don't worry, some day you'll get whatever it is.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: 憧れのダービー、なんとしても勝ちたいです。
I long for the derby and I want to win no matter what it takes.

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means courage.

Set fire to a geoduck if you want to annoy it. Fire won't kill a geoduck, but have you ever been on fire? It's not really pleasant. So you'll just annoy it pretty badly. Imagine how annoyed you would be if someone set YOU on fire for no reason. The geoduck has every reason to find you annoying, dude.
mnemonics.reading: You know who loves annoying geoducks more than anyone else in the universe? Han (はん) Solo! If you watch Star Wars closely enough you can see him shooting geoducks with his blaster and catching them on fire for fun.  Think how annoying it must be to be a geoduck when Han Solo comes around.

mnemonics.meaning: "For the  samurai, it is a jackhammer that they will lack." That is the latest article of the law written about samurai, hundreds of years after katana were taken away. This article was written with great sincerity by the government. By writing up new articles and laws they keep taking things away from samurai. First the katana, now jackhammers?
mnemonics.reading: The one who wrote these articles with such sincerity was Genghis Khan (かん). Genghis Khan knew that samurai were a threat to his kingdom, so he took away their secondary weapon, the jackhammer.

mnemonics.meaning: Red insects only bite barbarians. If a red insect bites you then you have barbarian blood! Waaay back a barbarian was your aunt or uncle or great great grand pappy! But the insects kinda hurt, so it's a bit of a downside I guess. If you see a red insect follow it and see who it bites. Then you'll know that person is at least part barbarian.
mnemonics.reading: You follow the red insect and see it bite someone who must be a barbarian! You look up at their face but all you can see are giant Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses. You really want to look at his face to see what a barbarian looks like but those darn things are in the way! Thanks to those Ray Bans you still don't know what a real life barbarian looks like. After going to all the trouble of following a red bug too. What a waste.

mnemonics.meaning: Under this canopy is the Mona Lisa, being sold for cheap, what a great bargain! You never know what kind of bargains you'll find when you look under a canopy at the wares of a traveling salesperson. Look really closely at this Mona Lisa. Hmm, I don't remember her having a mustache, but I guess it is a little dark under this canopy.
mnemonics.reading: You want to make sure this bargain is as good as it seems, so you ask if you can get this Mona Lisa as a rental (れん). Just for now, so you can make sure it's real before you buy it at that low, low price. The salesperson pulls the painting away and mutters, "Ah, yes, well this is such a good bargain already! And besides... it's already a rental, you see. From the, uh, the Louvre. So you really should just take this bargain and buy it!"

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to slice the power out of someone just censure them. Then they'll be cut down in front of everyone and they'll feel super embarrassed. It's the best way to slice them down without actually cutting them and getting arrested. Picture yourself as you slice the power out of that senator you hate by censuring them in front of the world!
mnemonics.reading: Once you censure them and they lose all their power, they'll be just another guy (がい). A normal guy with everything lost to him. HAHAHA! Look at that guy now. What a loser.

mnemonics.meaning: If you think a tree looks sweet you have to be certain before you bite into it. Trees are really hard, and usually pretty bitter (believe me) so if you don't want a mouthful of broken teeth, sap, and sadness, you really need to be sure it's the one before you start munching. Which tree do you think is sweet? That one? Or that one? Are you absolutely certain? I hope you are!
mnemonics.reading: If you really want to be certain, and not just guess, take out your bowling (ぼう) ball and roll it as hard as you can into the tree. If its the right one it will let out a sweet smell, if it's not the tree will punch you. So now let me ask you again, are you certain, or would you like to try the bowling ball test?

mnemonics.meaning: An arrow is shot from heaven and hits right between your mouth and your mustache to correct your crooked smile. It also straightens your teeth and the crooked cut of your mustache too. Who told you that looked good? Well, it doesn't matter. The heaven arrow corrected it for you. An arrow from heaven will correct all your problems!
mnemonics.reading: These heavenly correcting arrows actually come from きょうと. They hate seeing people with crooked mustaches, so they shoot them out on the regular. It just looks like they're coming from heaven because they fall out of the sky. If you want someone to correct your teeth or mustache, just wander around きょうと, staring up at the sky. Then when you see an arrow, run for it and try to catch it with your face!

mnemonics.meaning: You ate some grains that made you so sick it feels like a knife is stabbing in your guts and all your poop is falling out. This is called diarrhea. Everyone's had diarrhea before, so you should know this feeling by now. Imagine back to the last time you ate something bad and it gave you diarrhea. It felt like someone was sticking you with a knife, didn't it?
mnemonics.reading: The diarrhea is here. It's happening. And it smells so awful you can't breathe. You have to take some hollow reeds (り) and shove them up your nose and out the bathroom door so you can get some fresh air in you. You learned this reed technique from a group of ninjas who use them to breathe underwater, and you never thought you'd use them like this.

mnemonics.meaning: If you ride a scooter with your fingers around an axe you're going to die. I mean, probably. There's a 99% chance you'll die. Picture someone else riding a scooter with an axe in their fingertips. That's so dangerous! One bump, one bad turn, and that axe slips and they'll die.
mnemonics.reading: You slip. The axe collides with your face. You die. But... wait! There's a bright, blue glow and suddenly you're un-dead. You watch in slow motion as your holy blue saber (せい) brings you back to life and takes the hit from the axe instead. Wait, no! It shatters. Your holy blue saber died for you. It saved you from certain death and now it died. After all you've been through together. All 60 levels. This is the end.

mnemonics.meaning: The animal that hangs out in melon patches is the elusive fox! They like to steal melons then come back into town disguised as human melon sellers. Foxes are tricky like that. Imagine seeing a red fox scampering through a melon patch trying to take melons with it.
mnemonics.reading: If you want to stop foxes from stealing your melons you can get one of those kits that neigh (きつね) when one is around. The kits neigh when they sense a fox, but because it sounds like a horse the fox won't run. But you'll be able to get out there and take your melons back! Imagine buying kits that neigh and putting them around your melon patch to warn you when foxes are around.

mnemonics.meaning: You're stuck in your car during a tsunami and all you have to break out is an axe. You whack and whack but you're only gradually making progress. You thought an axe would be an easy way to get out of a car but it's not working like you'd planned! You have to make more than gradual progress if you don't want to drown.  Imagine gradually denting your car door open with an axe while you're trapped in a tsunami. This isn't fast enough!
mnemonics.reading: As you're gradually making your door open with the axe you look up to see the New York Yankees floating by on top of their bus. You yell, "YO YANKEES (ようや) to get their attention. They see your gradual progress and start throwing balls at your car to help dent it open. YO YANKEES! Gradually yelling that saved your life!

mnemonics.meaning: You see twenty slides lined up like a grid. You don't know who put them here, but they almost look like the grid paper you do your maths homework in. But who would use a slide as grid paper? Picture twenty slides laid out in a grid system.
mnemonics.reading: As you stare at the slide grid you see some people come out and overhear them talk about their mass maths (ます) tournament happening later today. Oohhh it IS a giant grid. And they're going to use it to do maths later! You can make a grid out of anything if you set your mind to it. And you can do math anywhere as long as you have some grid paper!

mnemonics.meaning: Have you heard the tale of the woman who fell in love with a coat rack during a full moon and made him her groom? It's a true story! She even had a wedding ceremony and had more coat racks sitting in the grooms side. The moon will make people do craaaazy things. Imagine what it would be like to fall in love with a coat rack and make it YOUR groom.
mnemonics.reading: The best part of the story is that the only coat on the coat rack groom was a moose coat (むこ). So the groom was a really skinny stick with a giant moose hair coat hanging down it.  Could you love a moose coat enough to marry it?

mnemonics.meaning: This cage is full of flowers on the right side to hide the fact that you're in here too. You don't really want to be in this cage, but there were some things you didn't want to do today, so you hid. Luckily these flowers block the right side of the cage and hide you completely.
mnemonics.reading: As you hide the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu appears before you, inside the cage! His arms are crossed and he's shaking his head at you. "Do you think I managed to become the first shougun of Japan by hiding?" "N-no?" you respond. "Wrong! I hid all the time. There's nothing wrong with hiding, you're doing a great job." he says, and disappears.

mnemonics.meaning: You say something to a boot when you want to be humble. You're down there because you're bowing in front of the person you're humbling yourself before. Because of that, your face is really close to their boots and you're speaking directly at them, instead of at the person's face, so it's more discreet. Picture yourself trying to be humble. You're down on the ground talking to a pair of boots. You don't dare raise your eyes past that.
mnemonics.reading: You're being humble like this because those boots belong to the King (きん) of England. You can't just say whatever you want at eye level to a king. He'll have your head chopped off for insolence, or worse! Imagine saying something to the King. Get low down on the ground to be as humble as you can. Whisper into the King's boots. Lick them if you have to.

mnemonics.meaning: Flowers that you oversee are always indigo. You aren't sure why though... Imagine if every flower you were supposed to oversee was indigo. Indigo everywhere!
mnemonics.reading: Wait, maybe these flowers are only indigo because there is something wrong with your eyes (あい)! Maybe your eyes are indigo and that's why it's all you see! Can you imagine having indigo-only seeing eyes? I can. Because of this awesome mnemonic.

mnemonics.meaning: Carve a tree into a bar and lay it sticking out into the water to make a jetty or a pier. Now you can walk out on the jetty and go further into the water without needing a boat or getting wet. Imagine laying your tree turned bar into the water to make your own jetty. Innovative!
mnemonics.reading: You made this jetty so it would be easier for Santa-san (さん) to dock his sleigh. Oh, you didn't know? His sleigh is more of a speed boat now, so he needs a jetty to give you presents, not a chimney anymore. Picture Santa-san coming in from the water on his speedboat and docking on your jetty to deliver presents to you.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a yakuza member in a prison on the sun and he'll become a martyr to all the other yakuza still on earth. He died up there so the rest of them wouldn't have to. Because they definitely aren't getting caught now, if the penalty is a burning death in the new sun prison. Imagine all the yakuza coming out into the streets and holding up signs saying this guy was a martyr. A hero to all who do bad stuff in bad groups but don't wanna get caught.
mnemonics.reading: The only reason he ended up a martyr in the first place is because they put him up there in June (じゅん). Everyone knows the sun is way too hot for humans in June. It's summer! Really, it's not the fault of the people who put him there that he's become a martyr. It's the month of June. PUNISH JUNE! PUT JUNE IN THE SUN PRISON! (Is what I assume those yakuza are shouting.)

mnemonics.meaning: In the dirt, you find a lid under the table. You lift it to reveal a deep pit. Why is there a hole under your table? You pull away the lid and crawl inside. There is a ladder that takes you deep into the pit.
mnemonics.reading: When you reach the bottom of the pit, you hear someone scuffling around and the sounds of chains. You light a match and inch closer to see what it is. In the darkness, you see こういち, starved and chained in a pit under your table. After you've nursed こういち back to health, he explains that he was put here by a clone こういち–the very same こういち who became emperor. He tells you he can think of around 61-70 different pain levels of revenge, but also that "it probably wouldn't be worth it, so let's just hang out for a while instead. Ooh, are those cookies?"

mnemonics.meaning: You're in a net but you have the ability to quit playing along and leave at any time.  Your captors think they have you trapped, but you know you can leave whenever you feel like it.
mnemonics.reading: You don't know if you want to quit this charade until you feel an uncomfortable heat (ひ). You look down and the net you're in is being hung above a large fire. As the heat spreads you decide to leave. You hop out of the net and watch the shock spread in your captors eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: If the death of a woman occurs it's because she was being reckless. People don't just die out of nowhere! They have to have done something super crazy to cause it. Right? Yes... right. Picture yourself watching the news about a woman's death. The word RECKLESS?! pops up on your screen and keeps flashing. Huh, she must have been, you think to yourself.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch the news about this reckless woman you find out that she died from mowing (もう) her lawn. You're not sure how, but now you really believe that she had to be doing it really recklessly to die doing it. Imagine what reckless thing that woman had to have done to die while mowing the lawn. Eww.

mnemonics.meaning: As the tsunami hits your scooter and your car, it alters the wave, creating ripples. They're hard to see because a tsunami is pretty big, but your scooter and car do create ripples in the water as it goes past.
mnemonics.reading: Ripples come off of your scooter and car from when they were hit by a tsunami. More importantly, those things were rentals (れん), so ripples or not, it doesn't matter if they were hit by a tsunami. As you watch the ripples come off your car / scooter, be sure to imagine the relief you'd feel if you knew they were rentals and not something owned by you.

mnemonics.meaning: The flowers that wash up on shore in tsunamis that we make into syrup is seaweed. Okay, so it's more like soup or tea than syrup, but you can make them both out of seaweed. Seaweed is the flower of the sea!
mnemonics.reading: Seaweed is true soul (そう) food. Which means it's good for your soul. Didn't you ever read those books about chicken soup being good for your soul? Well that was a lie. Miso soup with seaweed is what's really good for your soul. Feed your soul with seaweed and it will thank you. Promise! <3

mnemonics.meaning: Tsunami's have a certain tendency to secrete things as they go back out to sea. When they bash themselves onto the land they just throw a bunch of sea water around, but there are only certain things that they'll secrete when they're leaving. Certain tsunami secretions are dangerous. Can you think of any?
mnemonics.reading: Most tsunami's secrete heat (ひ). It takes a lot of energy for a tsunami to crash onto the land so the water is really really hot, and it has to secrete that heat as it's going back out to sea. The next time someone asks you what does a tsunami secrete? You'll say heat!

mnemonics.meaning: Use your mouth to sing and a shellfish to stroke your shamisen, and you'll be performing a shamisen song just like that! Yes, it's that easy. Just go find a shell, open your mouth, and you'll be singing one too in no time! Imagine using your mouth to sing and a shell to play the shamisen to perform your shamisen song!
mnemonics.reading: A shamisen song is just an 歌 (うた) but with a shamisen. They're still songs so they're said the exact same way! A shamisen song is a song, yay!

mnemonics.meaning: Half of a rice paddy is always on the shore. Japan is surrounded by water, after all. So it only makes sense that half of every rice paddy is right next to the ocean shore, right? Picture a rice paddy. Half of it is trailing off into the shore. Hear the seagulls. Feel the ocean breeze!
mnemonics.reading: You decide to walk along this shore when you see Han (はん) Solo lounging in the sand. He's waving for you to join him! You get to lay on the shore with Han!! Imagine laying on the shore with Han Solo. Enjoying a cool drink. Smelling the fragrance of the rice paddy behind you. Yeah, this is the life!

mnemonics.meaning: The leader squid tells all of its squid people to be thrifty. Imagine the leader squid giving a speech about how you shouldn't buy new things, and how you should live with a roommate to save money. Every squid yen counts!
mnemonics.reading: Who is a thrifty squid? Ken (けん) the samurai's squid buddy, who gets carried around in a bucket and never pays rent. Ken's squid is always shaking his head at Ken the samurai's obsession with wearing all silk. He should visit Thrifty Threads, the second hand shop, and get some cotton clothes that would do the job just fine. Hint: Whenever there's a squid, remember that Ken (けん) the samurai is nearby.

mnemonics.meaning: You put your fingers in the coffin to tickle the beggar inside. What you're doing is a new form of torture. First, you put them in a coffin to make them think they're going to die. Then you tickle them with your fingers. There is no greater psychological + physical torture than this.
mnemonics.reading: The beggar you will coffin tickle torture is ごういち, a.k.a. Grandpa Koichi. He is a frail old man, and doesn't like to be tickled. He keeps screaming: "STOP THIS TICKLE TORTURE. I CAN'T TAKE IT JUST BURY ME."

mnemonics.meaning: Give alcohol to a demon and you'll see how ugly it really is. Demons need to concentrate to keep their disguises going. Even if it looked pretty when you met it, like super handsome, give it a few drinks and its facade will slide off and reveal its super gross demon face. Picture the drunk demon as its pretty face drips off revealing the ugly crap piled underneath.
mnemonics.reading: The ugly demon is drunk and taking off his shoes (しゅう) and swinging them around his head. And, oh no, he's drinking more alcohol out of the shoes. The demon drinking alcohol out of its nasty shoes is the ugliest scene you've ever seen.

mnemonics.meaning: Your forehead is in the sun, and you start seeing those creatures with lids for heads and  fins for feet again. Where on earth did they come from? They must have come from the underworld. Nothing like that exists in this life. Imagine the heat of the sun on your forehead as you watch these horrible creatures with lid-heads and fin-feet. There's no doubt that these are creatures from the underworld. You get out of the sun as fast as you can.
mnemonics.reading: The sun is unusually hot for the month of May (めい), which must be why those underworld creatures are running around. You make a mental note to always avoid the sun in May.

mnemonics.meaning: The tsunami swept away one of the cleats your husband just bought and creates an entire valley with it. Watch as the tsunami rakes your husband's cleat across the mountain, carving a valley and an easier path for itself. Nature is brutal.
mnemonics.reading: When the water clears, you and your husband go to the valley to look for the cleat and instead you find a bunch of cake (けい)! Maybe this is the tsunami's way of saying, "Thanks for letting me steal your cleat so I could make this valley shortcut."  Imagine yourself eating cake with your husband in this newly formed valley. You both agree that this should be called Cake Valley!

mnemonics.meaning: When you see a tsunami coming courage wells up inside you and you gain the power to save everyone you meet before they get washed away! Feel that courage boil and spread throughout all your limbs. You feel like you have super strength. This tsunami isn't going to hurt anyone while you're alive to stop it! Imagine what it feels like to have courage well up inside you. Courage in the face of certain death!
mnemonics.reading: Who does that courage well up inside? You (ゆう)! In fact, YOU feel like there is a never ending well of courage bursting out of you now. You are going to be a hero! Who wells up with courage? You do!

mnemonics.meaning: Under your own roof, a geoduck jumps out of the ground with a sword and stabs your husband/wife/marriage partner to death. Now you're a widow. Imagine the geoduck laughing and screaming, "Now you're a widow! Now you're a widow!" flailing the sword around. It's awful.
mnemonics.reading: You may be a widow, but that doesn't make you weak. You run outside, jump into your car (か), and run your entire house and the geoduck over. It's just you and your car now, living the widow life, driving on into the sunset and forgetting your past.

mnemonics.meaning: You're walking in a greenhouse when you see a small drop of water fall and it makes you yearn for the person you adore. You haven't seen them in so long. But something about being in this greenhouse and seeing that tiny water droplet made your heart burst with longing.  Imagine how it feels to yearn for someone else when you see the small water drop. Imagine how your heart feels.
mnemonics.reading: As you yearn for that person from your past, you look back at the drop and see... Bobo (ぼ) the clown?! Uhg. Apparently Bobo dropped that small drop of water. Now you yearn for being somewhere Bobo is not.

mnemonics.meaning: A certain country is a certain country!
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本に留学生を多く送りこんでいる某国で教えています。
I teach in a country that sends a lot of exchange students to Japan.
梓川さんは派遣員として某国大使館に勤めていました。
Azusagawa-san worked as a temporary employee at a certain country's embassy.
菅原沙羅が某国のスパイであるという嫌疑はぬぐえません。
We can't shake the suspicion that Sara Sugawara is a spy for a certain country.

mnemonics.meaning: A certain family name belongs to a certain person.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 審査員の某氏に会いました。
I met with one of the judges.
社長に近い立場の某氏は、「難しい状況にしてしまった」とコメントしている。
A certain person close to the president commented, "We've put ourselves in a difficult situation".
「こういちはいつか世界を征服する」と某氏が語っていた。
A certain person told me that Koichi is going to conquer the world one day.

mnemonics.meaning: No surprises here. A certain place is a certain place.
