mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 栃木県の某所で行われたイベントに行ってきました。
I went to an event held at a certain place in Tochigi Prefecture.
昨夜、某所にて、有名人による太鼓の演奏会が行われたようです。
Last night, there was a taiko performance by a celebrity at a certain place.
彼女と出会ったのは、都内某所の居酒屋で食事をしている時だった。
I was eating at an izakaya in a certain place in Tokyo when I met my girlfriend.

mnemonics.meaning: An article you write a promise on is an agreement. Make sure you read them thoroughly before you sign them!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: きちんと約款を読みましたか？
Did you read the agreement thoroughly?

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 解剖 means "autopsy?" Well you have to learn about anatomy before you're going to be allowed to perform an autopsy or dissect anything.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大学では解剖学を研究しています。
I study anatomy in college.

mnemonics.meaning: Hide your name for anonymity. There's lots of that here on the internet. In fact, you're probably using a pseudonym right now, aren't you? Yeah, you are. You can't hide THAT from me at least... uh... Ssssteve?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 匿名で投書をしました。
I wrote a letter to the editor anonymously.

mnemonics.meaning: Articles that determine the rules and regulations of your job or a company are called articles of incorporation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この雛形を作れば簡単に定款が作成できます。
If I make this sample I can easily draw up a company statute.

mnemonics.meaning: Barbarians go around and commit acts of barbarism! What else would they do? They're barbarians!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あいつらはそこで蛮行を繰り返しているんだ。
They repeated the brutality over there.

mnemonics.meaning: A groom gets a flower on his lapel and he's finally a real bridegroom! Before that he was just waiting to be one. The flower makes it for real.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 花婿が結婚式場から逃げ出したらしいわよ。
The groom ran away from the wedding!

mnemonics.meaning: If you annoy someone who's busy they're still going to be busy. You annoying them can't change them. Though now they're probably busy AND annoyed.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日々の煩忙から逃れ、ハワイにやって来ました。
I escaped from my busy daily life and came to Hawaii.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 某私立高校に伝わる、奇妙な噂があるんだ。
A strange rumor is circulating at a certain private high school.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a combination of the words 吸う meaning "to smoke" and 殻 meaning "shell" or "husk." The husk left over after you're done smoking is the cigarette butt. Or tobacco ashes if you just have a pile of them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the words 吸う and 殻. Change the う to い and don't forget the rendaku, and you should be able to remember this reading too!

sentences: 吸い殻が二本たまったら、すぐに灰皿を交換してください。
If two cigarette butts pile up, please empty the ashtray immediately.

mnemonics.meaning: If you think someone is trying to annoy you at random, just pay attention and you'll see that they have a complex annoying pattern they're using on you. Once you figure that out, it won't annoy you as much and you'll win!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 煩雑な手続きに苛々します。
I’m irritated by complex formalities.

mnemonics.meaning: Correct something you thought was already correct by making a correction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 歯の矯正をしていました。
I had my teeth corrected.

mnemonics.meaning: Die in the past and it was death that you suffered from!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 社長の逝去は本当に大きなショックです。
The company president’s death was a really big shock.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 感慨 means "strong feelings?" Well feelings so strong that you can not even think of a quantity to measure or explain how much you feel. These are really deep emotions. They fill you all the way up and you can't help but tell everyone about them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あんなに小さかった娘の成長を見て、感慨無量でした。
Watching the growth of my very small daughter was deeply emotional.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a combination of the words 感慨 meaning "strong feelings" and 深い meaning "deep." Something that makes you feel strong emotions deep down inside is deeply moving.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of a jukugo word and an i-adjective. You've learned both of them so just mash them together, with the rendaku making ふ to ぶ, and you've got the reading down pat!

sentences: 初めて自分の書いたものが出版されるのは、やっぱり感慨深いものがあります。
This is the first time my writing will be published, so of course it’s a deeply moving thing for me.

mnemonics.meaning: Reckless concepts are just delusions. You shouldn't dwell on them, they probably aren't going to happen.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: いつも大金持ちになる妄想ばかりしています。
I’m always just fantasizing about becoming a very rich person.

mnemonics.meaning: Diarrhea that goes below you is still diarrhea, unfortunately. I hope it's going down into a toilet...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 朝から下痢が止まりません。
The diarrhea hasn’t stopped since morning.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to become a martyr during your employment you need to die at your post. I don't know why you'd WANT to do that though.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その刑事は、銃弾を浴びて殉職しました。
The detective took a bullet and died at his post.

mnemonics.meaning: You quit your job but with a pretty good excuse to back it up, so you get a dismissal instead of just quitting outright. If you're in the army and you do this it's called a discharge.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの大臣は罷免されたよ。
That cabinet minister was dismissed.

mnemonics.meaning: Red diarrhea means there's blood in there and you're probably dying of dysentery! Have you been playing too much Oregon Trail? Either way, get to a doctor!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 赤 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know what dysentery isn't? Sexy (せき). That's right. If anyone tries to seduce you by saying they have dysentery and they'd like to share it with you, tell them how NOT sexy that is and get the heck away from them!

sentences: 男女計5人から細菌性の赤痢が検出されました。
The dysentery bacteria was detected in five men and women total.

mnemonics.meaning: If you do something gradually for a long time, when you finish it gives you that FINALLY feeling. It took so long and you worked so hard and you're finally done!
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is an exception, but you learned it with the kanji. Congratulations!

sentences: 漸く作家としてのスタートラインに立つことができました。
I was finally able to pass the starting line as a writer.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: かわいい狐が茂みからひょこっと顔を出した。
A cute fox suddenly poked its head out of the thicket.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 作文の書き出しは、一升空けて下さい。
Please start your composition in the first box.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 新年 means "New Year?" Well when you say humble congratulations on the new year, you're really saying Happy New Year!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 年賀状には謹賀新年と書いてありました。
Happy New Year! was written on the New Year’s card.

mnemonics.meaning: Hide and hide make hide! Lots of hiding going on around here. I think... I can't find anyone so I can only assume.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は犯人を隠匿していたんだよ。
She hid the criminal.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: こんないいお婿さんにもらわれて、娘は幸せ者です。
My daughter is very fortunate to get such a nice husband.

mnemonics.meaning: The final bullet of censure is impeachment. You've already been publicly humiliated and now you're being impeached because of it. Yikes.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大統領の弾劾を求める大規模な反政府デモが開かれました。
A large-scale anti-government demonstration was held for the impeachment of the President.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so you should know this too!

sentences: 藍染の藍は天然ですが、ジーンズに使われる合成インディゴは人工的なものです。
Indigo plant dye is natural, but the synthetic dye used for jeans is artificial.

mnemonics.meaning: The lake shore is the lake shore!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 夏は、静かな湖畔のロッジで読書をしています。
In summer I read in a quiet lake shore lodge.

mnemonics.meaning: A long shamisen song is a long shamisen song! They're also called nagauta, and they're usually pretty epic too.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 長唄教室に通い始めました。
I started to go to the nagauta class.

mnemonics.meaning: Buy something at bargain value and you'll be getting it at a really low price. Good for you!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 廉価版のゲームのパッケージって安物感丸出しだよな。
The game’s popular edition packaging feels cheap, doesn’t it?

mnemonics.meaning: The pillar the sail is attached to is called a mast. Without it the sail wouldn't do it's job and your sailboat wouldn't move at all.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned these readings with other vocabulary, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この木は帆柱にちょうどいいぞ。
This tree is perfect for a mast.

mnemonics.meaning: A stream that runs through a valley is a mountain stream. Valleys happen in between mountains, so just picture the river running through the middle of them in your head.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ラフティングで渓流を下りました。
We went rafting down the mountain stream.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of annoy? It's annoying!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What's noisy? That uni's rude sighing (うるさい). It just keeps sighing loudly over and over. It's sooo annoying!

sentences: 彼がポテトチップスを食べる音が煩くて苛々します。
The sound of him eating potato chips is loud and annoying.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 管弦楽 means "orchestral music?" Well the group that plays that music is an orchestra.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 小さな管弦楽団でバイオリンを演奏しています。
I play violin in a small orchestra.

mnemonics.meaning: Add a bridge to a jetty and you'll have a pretty cool pier. Put a ferris wheel on there and make some money!
mnemonics.reading: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 桟 and the kun'yomi reading for 橋. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!

sentences: 船は桟橋に繋いでいます。
The ship is tied to the pier.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 戯れる can mean "to play" or "to flirt?" Well this is when you play flirt! Or just make a joke.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: 戯れに文章を綴っただけなのに、賞を獲ってしまった。
Even though I only wrote it as a joke, I won an award.

mnemonics.meaning: The underworld king star is the dwarf planet Pluto. Since Pluto was the ruler of the underworld in classical mythology, this makes a lot of sense!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 冥王星の軌道は不規則で、太陽を一周する期間は約２５０年です。
Pluto's orbit is irregular, and it takes about 250 years to go around the sun once.
冥王星は天文学者クライド・トンボーによって、1930年２月18日に発見された。
Pluto was discovered on February 18 1930 by astronomer Clyde Tombaugh.
冥王星が惑星から準惑星に降格された理由を説明できますか？
Can you explain why Pluto was demoted from planet to dwarf planet?

mnemonics.meaning: The underworld dirt is another word for the realm of the dead, underworld, or Hades. Like the word 冥界 (also in this level), it's rather poetic, and mostly used in written contexts involving spirituality, Buddhism, and ancient mythologies. There are a few set expressions that only use 冥土, though. One example is 冥土の土産, "a souvenir to take to the realm of the dead". It refers to something abstract that is so valuable, it's worth taking to the underworld, such as the solution to a great mystery, or a happy memory. Another expression is 冥土の旅支度, which means "preparations for the journey to the realm of the dead", and can refer to the preparation of the deceased before a funeral, as wells as certain preparations made by Buddhists while they're still alive. You'll also see this word written as 冥途 sometimes.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どんなにお金を稼いでも、冥土には持っていけないんだよ。
No matter how much money you make, you can't take it with you to the underworld.
「冥土の土産に教えてやるよ。」と、男は銃を構えたまま秘密を話し始めた。
"I'll tell you something that'll be your souvenir for the realm of the dead" said the man, and began to tell me his secret, keeping his gun pointing at me.
仏衣や死化粧などの冥土の旅支度をして、故人は来世へと向かいます。
After preparing for the journey to the underworld by dressing the body in Buddhist robes and applying makeup for the deceased, they will go on to the next life.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 容赦 can mean "forgiveness" and "mercy?" Well add なく (basically making it NOT that), and it becomes relentlessly and mercilessly. The exact opposite of what it was before!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji (with なく attached to it). You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 父は弟を容赦なく殴りつけました。
Dad relentlessly beat my younger brother.

mnemonics.meaning: A sail boat is a sailboat!
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi readings. You know them!

sentences: 店内は帆船をイメージした内装となっております。
The interior of the shop is designed in the image of a sailboat.

mnemonics.meaning: Barbarians who live in fields, not even in huts or houses or anything, are called savage by people who DO live in huts and houses. They think if you live out in a field you're really uncivilized. But that's all a matter of opinion, I guess.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そんな野蛮な人たちと付き合ってはいけません。
You must not associate with such savage people.

mnemonics.meaning: What do you hear that is really ugly? A scandal. Scandals are the ugliest topics for gossip.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 誰がこんな根も葉もない醜聞を流したんだ。
Who spread this completely untrue scandal?

mnemonics.meaning: Sea seaweed is still seaweed!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この海藻は食べられますか。
Can you eat this seaweed?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Swim into a floating group of seaweed and shivers will go up your spine. It feels so gross and slimy that you can't help but moan (も) out in distress.

sentences: 藻が絡まってしまったみたいだ。
The duckweed seems to be twisted up.

mnemonics.meaning: Part of you is starting to secrete some kind of secretion. It's kinda gross, so maybe you should go to the doctor to check if it's normal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 胃液は1日1～2Lも分泌されています。
Around 1-2 liters of gastric juices are secreted each day.

mnemonics.meaning: Something with an ugly appearance is a shameful sight, or disgraceful behavior. You feel bad just looking at it. It probably feels bad too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あんな醜態を演じたのに、よく平気な顔で会社に行けるね。
How can you go to work without a care in the world after such disgraceful behavior?
とんだ醜態を晒してしまったよ。
They were exposed to an unimaginably shameful sight.
好きな子に醜態を見られたし、悲しみしかない。
A girl I like saw my disgraceful behavior and I can feel nothing but sadness.

mnemonics.meaning: Tell a widow to shut up and she'll be silent for the rest of the day. That wasn't very nice. You're a mean person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 寡黙で読書好きな男性がタイプです。
My type is a guy who likes reading in silence.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means certain, but when it's used as a standalone word, or after a family name, it means things like someone or other, you-know-who, or something. It's basically a vague way to refer to someone who's name you've forgotten, or you don't want to mention for some reason.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi of the kanji, and you haven't learned that yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You bump into someone or other, and just as you're wondering what on earth her name is, her nanny gashes (なにがし) her on the leg. It looks like it hurts. Poor you-know-who, whatever her name is. The nanny looks horrified, and is trying to patch her up.

sentences: これは、山田某の話である。
This is the story of Yamada someone or other.
たしか、鈴木某とかいう人じゃなかったっけ？
Wasn't it a guy named Suzuki something?
あそこの劇団の某がまた何かやらかしたらしいぞ。
I heard you-know-who from that drama troupe has done it again.

mnemonics.meaning: A shamisen song is a shamisen song, yes. But did you know it's also... a song?! Oh, you did? Well okay then.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: この唄は、私と兄が一緒に作りました。
I wrote this song with my older brother.

mnemonics.meaning: Your daughter's groom will become your son in law. He's a great guy! Congratulations!
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: いずれは娘婿を社長にするつもりです。
Sooner or later, I intend to make my son in law company president.

mnemonics.meaning: Southern barbarians are called Southern barbarians! While it originally referred to the people of Southeast Asia, the term Nanban was used to refer to Western traders who began arriving in Japan in the 1500s. There's yummy food named after them too!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: チキン南蛮の簡単でおいしいレシピがあれば教えてください。
If you have a good, simple recipe for chicken nanban, please let me know.

mnemonics.meaning: A well of water that pops up naturally is called a spring and that water is spring water.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 地下水が地表に自然に出てきたものを、湧水といいます。
Underground water that naturally comes to the surface is called a spring.

mnemonics.meaning: Measure that shape on the paper with your eyes. It's got four sides.. it's.. it's a square! Or a box from above maybe... But it's definitely the kind you fill in on a graph.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 升目を数えると、全部で400ありました。
When I counted the boxes there were 400 total.

mnemonics.meaning: Sulfur that's yellow is still sulfur. It smells like rotten eggs, which are also kinda yellow.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: This sulfur smells like an eagle's OOHHH (いおう)!! Oh no. Sulfur smells... it smells... like an eagle's... OH.. Oh eww no.

sentences: この温泉には硫黄が含まれています。
There’s sulfur in this hot spring.

mnemonics.meaning: A bad kind of playing is when you tease or prank someone. It's mean and you shouldn't do it! Depending on the context this can sometimes have a far more negative connotation and mean lewd behavior.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you tease someone with a prank that makes them eat zoo rats (いたずら), you're a jerk. That's less of a prank and more like abuse. Cut it out.

sentences: 今子供達の間で流行っている悪戯ですよ。
Pranks are popular among children right now.
もう！悪戯するのはやめてください！
Come on! Stop teasing me!
面白い悪戯のアイデアをヤフオクで販売して生計を立てています。
I make a living by selling interesting prank ideas on Yahoo! Auction.

mnemonics.meaning: I promise this will be a really thrifty place because it's a thrift store! They wouldn't lie about that!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: いくらマイホームを買いたいからって、度を過ぎた倹約を強いるのはどうかと思います。
I don’t think it’s a good idea to force a higher amount of frugality on yourself just because you want to buy your own home.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means yearn for, so the verb version is to yearn for. But that sounds kinda old fashioned, so you can just use to adore too.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You realize you're starting to yearn for someone way more than you used to. "Sh*t (した)... " you say to yourself. This wasn't supposed to happen. Anytime you start to adore someone like that you always know you're getting into a bunch of sh*t you don't want to deal with. Damn these emotions!

sentences: 私は彼のことを兄のように慕っていました。
I adored him like an older brother.

mnemonics.meaning: You already know that 濁す means "to make muddy," but this is when you're the one getting muddy. It means to become muddy.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as 濁す. If you can remember that one, you should be able to remember this one.

sentences: 煙草の煙で部屋の空気が濁っています。
The air in the room is getting cloudy with tobacco smoke.

mnemonics.meaning: The verb form of compose is to compose. This particular verb is usually used in relation to poetry, and can also mean to recite or to sing, though more in the sense of singing someone's praises than singing a song.
mnemonics.reading: This word shares the same origin as 歌う and 唄う, and they share the same readings as well.

sentences: これは、彼が恋人のために詠った愛の詩です。
This is a love poem he composed for his girlfriend.
この叙事詩では、壮大なロマンが詠われている。
In this epic poem, a grand romance is recited.
彼女はいつも、詠うように言葉を紡いだ。
She always spun her words as if she was composing a poem.

meanings: to pour each other a drink

mnemonics.meaning: 酌む means "to serve" and the kanji 交 means mix. What happens if you serve and mix together? You're going to pour each other a drink because you plan  to drink together.
mnemonics.reading: You haven't learned this reading for 交 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: All the bars are closed so you and your friends are going to drink together in your car (か). You set up a little bar in the back of your car and settle down for some drinks. It's cramped but cosy.

sentences: あの日、ここで酒を酌み交わしたこと、覚えているか。
Do you remember the day we drank sake here together?
そして、二人は杯を酌み交わし、兄弟の誓いを立てた。
Then they poured each other a drink, and drank to a vow of brotherhood.
いつか、親子で酒を酌み交わす日が来るのかなあ。
I wonder if one day we'll be able to share a family drink together.

mnemonics.meaning: Torture may be a problem but that doesn't stop people from using torture to get their way.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 俺の姉は、マフィアから残虐な拷問を受けたんだ。
My older sister was brutally tortured by the mafia.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means Shamisen song, so the verb version is to sing.
mnemonics.reading: Remember how 歌う means "to sing" too? Well it has the same reading. If you know that one, you know this one. Yay!

sentences: 私のおじさんは、唄うアコーディオン弾きです。
My uncle is a singing accordion player.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means well, so the verb version is to well up.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You're fishing in a hole in the ice when suddenly the water starts to well up and to gush forth out of it. A huge walrus (わ) splashes out and jumps on you. No wonder there weren't any fish! This is a walrus hole.

sentences: 悔し涙が湧きました。
Bitter tears welled up.

mnemonics.meaning: A pit that's used as a road is called a tunnel. Or a mine, if they're taking valuable things out of it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 地下20mのところに坑道が掘られています。
They’re digging a tunnel somewhere 20 miles underground.

mnemonics.meaning: Ugly, bad things are ugly, mean, and offensive.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「被害者たたき」ってほんと醜悪だよね。
Victim-blaming is really ugly, isn't it?
「醜悪な文章は健全なディベートの害になるか」というテーマの研究を行っています。
I'm conducting research on the topic, "Is offensive writing detrimental to healthy debate?"
老婆の幽霊が、醜悪な顔でこちらをにらんでいた。
The old woman’s ghost glared at me with her ugly face.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of ugly? It's ugly still!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The most ugly thing you've ever seen was a mini cookie (みにく). Why would any one want a tiny cookie? Cookies should be huge, and enough to fill you up. The more you look at the mini cookie it seems to become uglier and uglier to you.

sentences: あの女は、顔は美しいが心は醜い。
That woman’s face is beautiful but her heart is ugly.

mnemonics.meaning: The underworld world is the underworld, Hades, or the realm of the dead. This word is a bit poetic, and mostly used in writing, particularly in contexts like Buddhism, spirituality, and ancient mythologies. It's usually interchangeable with 冥土 (which is also in this level), but 冥土 is used more in certain set expressions, which we'll mention in the page for that word!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned those with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 冥界に入れるのは死者の魂だけだ。
Only the souls of the dead can enter the underworld.
ヘカテーは、ギリシャ神話に出てくる冥界の女神です。
Hecate is the goddess of the underworld in Greek mythology.
冥界から、冥界神のメッセージが聞こえる。
I can hear a message from the god of the underworld coming from the realm of the dead.

mnemonics.meaning: The containers your urine secretes into are your urinary organs.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 泌尿器の病気で入院することになりました。
I was hospitalized from a urinary organ disease.

mnemonics.meaning: A valley in a valley is still a valley!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 温泉湯舎から渓谷美を一望することができます。
We can overlook the beautiful valley from the onsen’s bath huts.

mnemonics.meaning: A widowed wife is a widow.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 寡婦控除について詳しく教えてください。
Please explain widow deductions to me in detail.

mnemonics.meaning: If you can't stop thinking about how much you yearn for someone, that yearning can drive you crazy. Try to keep it in check, and enjoy how you can hold such deep affection for someone.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 異国の地で、母への思慕を重ねています。
Being in a foreign country, I constantly yearn for my mother.
